review:
Very impressed with Amazon's delivery on a SUNDAY, at that!  I pre-ordered and assumed I'd get it on Monday or Tuesday with my Prime delivery, but was surprised at to see it at my door today!

As for the tablet itself, so far it has been a breeze to use!  Connected to my WiFi right away and it seems pretty speedy...of course I haven't bogged it down with a bunch of junk yet.  ;-)  I logged in with my google account and before you know it, my apps were all synched over while it was charging.  I didn't want a full size tablet, this is much more portable, yet big enough to be easier to read than my Samsung Infuse for browsing, games and Kindle books. Love it so far!

Like the first review, I wasn't planning on buying this today...but after playing with the Fire and Nook and being underwhelmed with their performance, I almost left Best Buy empty handed. We stumbled upon this, and I loved it. My main problem with the other two was that they seemed very sluggish (compared to the iPad2 my fianc has). This on the other hand, is finally a quick and responsive 7" tablet at nearly the same price as Fire. Apps just launch, graphic intensive magazine pages flow, and the touch screen keyboard is easy to use with my relatively large hands. What's more is you aren't locked into anything, get a very accurate GPS, a smart remote, bluetooth, and a nice and bright screen. I'm sure I'll be adding more praises as time goes by.

Only issue I'm having is that the compass is always 90 degrees off, it always points West instead of North. Sounds like a software issue, but time will tell. When using the GPS enabled apps, North is dead on (as you'd expect). That's the only reason I gave it four stars (I'd actually rate it a 4.8 or something, but I had to point out the issue).

I purchased this tablet months ago when they first came out, and pretty much totally satisfied/happy with it. It has become real competition for the others and has set a new standard in quality and price. Excellent quality high resolution screen and works well. Not perfect, but close to it. I did have one problem, when using Angry Birds Rio (free version). It would re-cycle back and start over again during play. By researching blogs I found the solution. TURN ON AIRPLANE MODE during play, and the problem is gone. I have a 16GB microSD memory card in it, have downloaded 4 full length movies so far and they look great. I would recommend a 32GB card since it will accept it.  This tablet is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. (This review updated December 31, 2012.)

So this device just came out this morning, and I hadn't planned on buying it but I was down at my local best buy store and played with it just to see what it was and loved it! Let me say I used to have all apple stuff, apple computer, iphone, ipad, etc. Over the last year my apples have rotted, went bad and needed to be replaced. Instead of paying high dollar for all new apple stuff I went back to a windows PC, an Andorid Galaxy S2 phone, still had the iPad but it was in need of replacement.

So I got to Best Buy they didn't have these out yet but they pulled one out and let me play with it while they set up the are for the demo unit to go. I liked it, very snappy, great screen. The device comes preloaded with ICS on it, it's VERY snappy with zero lag so far.

The screen while not a retina display like the iPad is still clear enough for me. After all I'm not holding this inches from my face. if you do you get a chance to play with 1 of these before you buy go to the movies app on the device and play the life demo to see how clear and crisp the display is.

It quickly synced up with my Google account and I was already able to start downloading apps from the play store within minutes of getting it turned on.

So far this device is excellent. It feels like it's built well, the back is not as fancy as the Galaxy S2 phone however I plan on getting a case for this so the back battery panel to me doesn't matter much.

I'll update this later after I get more time to play with it, so far though for $250 this is a great deal. I also played with the Kindle Fire and the Blackberry playbook both which were available for $199, but I opted to spend the $50 more for the Samsung as I've been impressed with Samsung quality over the years. (Currently my TV's, blu ray players, computer monitor, phone and now tablet are all samsung brand. They make good products in my opinion.)

--UPDATE 8 hours later--
I used the GPS on this earlier and google navigation/maps to get me to the hardware store. Ok I didn't NEED it but I wanted to test it out. I found that you MUST have internet for google maps to give you directions, I had a hotspot in my car so I turned it on and navigation worked perfect. If you don't have wifi you can still use GPS, it does lock on fast however it can't query to get you directions. If you used an offline GPS program like navigon or something that would do the trick, but YES gps is accurate and fast.

I also used the bluetooth on this to stream music from the Tab 2 to my car, quality was excellent.

Apps and stuff, so far every app I have tried is compatible with the exception of one, and I can't remember what that one was so it was one I really didn't use much at all I guess. I have put a few games on to test it, so far so good and still no lag.

Hows the keyboard? It comes with stock ICS keyboard and it works well, if you start typing fast there is a tiny lag between hearing the click of the feedback and seeing the character appear, however all letters make it without any vanishing. I am looking for another keyboard though as spelling isn't built in it appears... I am probably switching to Swiftkey or swype both which appear compatible with the device.

Also, the IR Blaster = awesome! I was going to buy a $100 harmony remote for my entertainment system, well this Galaxy Tab 2 has an IR blaster built right in and the application for it is simple to configure. Less then 3 minutes I had it set to turn my TV on, control my bose sound system and also control my Tivo HD and Blu Ray player. Very slick!

More to come, if you have questions on how this works please leave them in the comments and I'll do my best to answer them quickly. Also, if you find this review helpful please make sure to mark it as such!

--UPDATE--

Morning after, do I regret buying it? Nope, still a fantastic device and I'll tell you a few more things I found out.

1. I use Dropbox on my home computer and put the app on this tablet. I also use a tivo at home and thought about how could I get my shows on my tivo to my computer then to my tablet? Well I use TivoToGo to transfer shows to my computer, then I place them in a drop box folder and they sync automatically to my dropbox account. I then on the tablet have an app (free and paid versions) called "Folder Sync" and I have that set to every hour check my drop box Tivo folder and download any latest tv shows my computer has copied. This means that in the morning when I leave for work my tablet has all my shows from the previous night I didn't get to watch on it so I can for instance watch one or two on my lunch break, without having to have a wifi connection at work!

2. Need to make a phone call? Unfortunately this device doesn't have phone support. However Skype works great with both video calls and audio calls. You can pay for a phone number from skype (it's cheap if you wanted it) and actually treat this like a phone assuming you have wifi wherever you are. I did try google voice app, that will not allow you to make calls and use the tablet as a handset, it instead asks you what phone in your account it should call.

---UPDATE 2/20/2013---

I see a lot of activity on my review, big thanks to everyone that found it helpful and I love the activity. I wanted to provide an update. While I really liked Galaxy Tab 2, I did make the jump a few months back to the Google Nexus 7 and have to say that tablet has taken over as my primary device. The Galaxy Tab 2 and Nexus 7 ARE similar, however I really like the pure google/android experience that the Nexus provides. If you are on the fence, I would recommend going with the Google Nexus over the Galaxy Tab 2 at this point.

Overview:  I bought this Tablet for my wife and after a couple of months, she quit using it and just went back to using her Samsung Galaxy S5 phone for everything because it does everything this tablet will do with the only downside being that it is smaller.

Pros:
  Battery lasts for about 4-5 hours of video and/or 7-8 hours constant internet use.
  Galaxy Tab 2 includes both a front and rear-facing camera.
  It is very well built.  So Tablets I have used in the past seemed very fragile, but this one feels very solid & has been dropped often with no damage ( I did use a good after-market screen protector).
  Has a larger screen than a smart phone.
  It will synced up with your Google account so you can bring over the same app's you use on your other devices & your contacts.

Cons:
  Really does not do anything your smart phone can't do and actually does less as it won't make calls.
  Has a proprietary charging cord.  would prefer a micro USB or some other universal cord.  If it breaks it will cost you much more to replace.
  Does not have HDMI video out capability
  No Flash for camera, takes good pictures but only if you have good light to work with.
  Even with the microSD port you are still very limited on storage (App's can only be saved on device not on SD card).

Final Analysis:  If you are in the market for a tablet, the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 is a great choice but truthfully if you own a good smart phone and a good laptop... There really isn't much point to a tablet.  They do less than either and have less storage space and are the hardware is not upgradeable so they will be obsolete every few years (much like your smart phone).  But they are great for entertaining young children and keeping them away from the devices that you really care about.

Final Note:  I don't get paid to review products and bought this device with my personal finances.  I hope this review is helpful and would be glad to answer any questions regarding my experience with this or any other produces I have purchased on Amazon.

I think the Tab 2 is a fairly useless product. I owned a 7" Tab 2 for 3 years and found it wasn't capable enough to do work, and wasn't fast/usable enough to use video chat or Facebook, and wasn't big enough to enjoy a Netflix movie.

I disliked the quick accelerometer (unless turned off, the display flipped from horizontal to vertical with just slight moves), disliked the version of Android it ships with, disliked the stock keyboard and several other keyboards I tried, disliked the sound quality, and disliked the look/feel of the screen and metallic case.  The brightness/contrast levels of the screen annoyed me.  In particular the display gave me a headache.

In contrast, in 2015, I find the iPad Air to be a very capable device for most purposes (kind of like a Swiss Army knife), I think the Surface with TouchPad is a perfect reader and laptop substitute, and either the iPhone 6 or the modern Android phones can do anything that a 7" tablet can do.

Samsung missed the mark with the Tab 2 and I was mostly disappointed.  I did like three things about it:
(1) long battery life that did not fade throughout a long period of ownership,
(2) a screen that seemed durable and did not crack (although the side frame did chip several times),
(3) a super-loud, easy to adjust alarm clock (which is all I ended up using the Tab 2 for, and why I kept it around after spending a year trying unsuccessfully to use it for more.)

It might be okay for a kid, or for someone who just uses it for games or entertainment.  That user is not me.  For the price, you can do better.  I'm surprised that used versions are still selling at this price point.

I am a laptop user for years so I finally bought a tablet. I chose the 7 -inch Samsung Galaxy 2 after reading reviews that seemed to indicate to me that Android was better than Apple. My sister has the Ipad. After using my tablet for a few months now, and witnessing my sister's use of her Ipad, I will say that neither device is without problems. My sister's Ipad screen freezes up and she needs to use the factory settings reset quite often. I had an Apple Itunes player that always froze on me and would stay in that state for hours. Apple seems to have this problem.  I think I made the best choice going with Android as it seems to be more convienient and allows more options where as the Ipad seems restricted to only Apple compatable options and downloads. I don't like to be held prisoner to using only Apple recognized applications and downloads. As stated, both devices have problems. I do not think the tablets are as well designed as the laptops. Tablets are much less vulnerable to virus attack, which has always been the main problem with laptops. This is good. Unfortunately, tablets are geered towards commercial companies charging fees to download and install their "applications" in order to do the same tasks that could be done for free with laptops. I believe that was one reason they created touch screen tablets, so that users would need to pay more. Laptop use was too "free".  Leave it to Microsoft, Apple and Samsung to come up with products that now charge user fees to do what "obsolete" laptops did for free. My Galaxy works well enough for email and Facebook. I'm having to get used to the touch screen as it is super sensative and I have fat fingers. It's easy to fumble when trying to type using the keyboard. Listening to music, my Galaxy lasts about 13-14 hours before needing recharging. I wonder how long before the battery wears out. The music player does not play my mp3 songs well. In the middle of songs, they sometimes "skip" which is a big disappointment. After reading up on possible fixes, I understand to correct this, one must download a better music player such as Winamp, as the standard player that comes with the Galaxy is flawed. Many other users have complained about this. Who wants to listen to their music skipping and cutting out in the middle of songs? The other problem I have found is with the movie player. It will not play Mp4 movies. You get half way through a movie and then a pop up appears that states the file cannot be played. It seems to play AVI and some other movie formats okay as long as they are short clips. I am still looking for a "fix" for this problem, although I'm afraid it will not be a free fix. Did they deliberatly design it with these flaws so I would need to pay to download programs that work properly? Again, tablets require downloading "apps" which cost money. Buy a tablet and get ripped off just to be able to keep using it? Otherwise, I am using it only for email and Facebook and not downloading any "apps" if I can help it because they all want my credit card. I guess I  expected any new device to work as well as a laptop and be as free to use as a laptop is. I'm not finding this to be the case with tablets.  I'm being generous giving it 3 stars. Hope these tablets improve.

My employer provided me an iPad and I had to return it when I left.  So I found myself without a tablet and not enough money to afford a new iPad.  These Samsung tablets were very inexpensive and highly rated, so I thought I would delve into the Android world by trying one.

I love the size - 7 inches is perfect for a tablet, in my view.  iPads are too big.

The operating system is fine; I enjoy how flexible and configurable Android is.  There are a few things it does clearly better than iOS.  App selection seems to be fine, although there is a weird thing going on with Amazon Prime Instant Video that probably relates to the Kindle.

As a music player, this device sounds very good - much better than any iPod or iPhone I have tried.  Not many people mention that.

But - the hardware is terrible.  It is so bad that it profoundly affects how I use this device.

The touchscreen is inaccurate.  I find myself pecking around trying to get the thing to recognize what I am trying to touch.  Often, I mistakenly touch whatever is next to what I aim for, sending me on an unplanned journey.

The device is S  L  O  W - slow to respond to keyboard input, slow to render web pages, slow to run applications.  Lots of latency in everything.

The device lacks adequate processing power to run a video application and send its sound to a connected bluetooth device at the same time.  It can do one or the other, but not both without skipping and freezing.

I used to use Evernote on my iPad as a notetaking device in meetings and at conferences.  Evernote is available on Android, but using it on this device is a non-starter because of the latency and keyboard response problems.

I think this may have been a nice device when it was released; perhaps the OS and apps we are running in 2013 and 2014 are handing it more than it was designed to accommodate.  Whatever the reason though, I cannot recommend this tablet at any price.

2/1/2014 UPDATE: At someone's suggestion, I completely reset the device, wiped all apps and data from it, and returned it to its factory condition.  I have noticed some performance improvement - possibly 15% to 20%.  At its current level of performance, I improve my review of the tablet by one star and admit that it is a price-acceptable tablet if not exactly a stellar performer.

I've been helping my little nephew to use and maintain his galaxy tab 2 for over a year now, and I've generally been very happy with how things have gone. The skin Samsung designed for their version of Android isn't my favorite, but that's just personal taste and not really any specific problem. Anyway, it's been easy enough to use that a kid is getting along with it fine, so that's certainly a good sign.

I'm also giving them credit for the fact that he's not always gentle with his stuff and not always good about being careful with what he tries to install, and the little tablet is still chugging along doing its job without hardly any issues or complaints in more than a year. He uses it as a place to play games, a way to send messages to family members, a means to watch movies when we're sick of hearing the same movie for the 5th time and we don't want it on the television, and occasionally a place where he reads electronics books from online stores or our region's library.

It has 8GB of storage space, which may be a little tight for some people. On the other hand, you can add a lot more space as needed using SD cards.

On the whole, I wouldn't say this is necessarily the very best that Android tablets have to offer, but I certainly can't argue with how well ours has held up and done its job. It's still running well enough and running recent enough versions that (barring mishaps) I wouldn't be terribly surprised if we manage to get another year of useful life out of it. With the Tab 3 being around, the Tab 2 is down to price levels that make it a really good buy as something that's good enough to be useful, but affordable enough that you don't have to be so afraid it might break that you hesitate to carry it around and actually use it.

I bought this a little over a year ago.  I bought a 32 GB microSD card to go with it.  About 11 months after I bought both the card and the tablet, the tablet basically destroyed the card.  All I attempted to do was move files from the internal memory to the external card, and it became hopelessly corrupt.  I flushed the stupid card down the toilet (and filmed myself doing so), I was so angry.  I should have tossed the damn tablet into the garbage.

Instead, I bought another microSD card.  32 GB, this time a PNY card.  Well, last night Samsung issued an update to the OS.  I just ignored it (BIG MISTAKE) and let it do it's thing, because it was late and I had to go to work early in the morning.

I come home and turn on the wretched tablet, and what do I find?  That some apps had been installed onto the SD card, even though I NEVER install apps onto the SD card!  How do I know this?  Three apps had a funny icon instead of the usual icon, indicating that it had been installed onto an SD card, but could no longer be accessed because the SD card was no longer being detected by this stupid pile of uselessness.

The microSD card had once again been completely and utterly destroyed by this stupid worthless tablet.  I put it in my Macbook Pro - wouldn't mount.  I put it in some old Sansa mp3 player I had lying around.  Wouldn't mount.  I even put it in my old Dell laptop running Linux Mint Olivia and it still would not mount.  AT ALL.

This is the second card this stupid wretched tablet has destroyed.  I am not wasting any more money on it.  Fortunately, I didn't have anything terribly important on it that hadn't been backed up somewhere else.  I am warning others though - do not buy this tablet if you intend to use it for something important, unless you're willing to live without an SD card.  I am certain it will just completely and utterly destroy whatever card you put in it.  It's only a matter of time.

All other benefits of the tablet do not outweigh this one major problem.  This thing is a POS.  At least Apple had the good enough sense to realize that slapping an SD card slot onto their devices would only cause problems.  Even Google knows that, which is why their Nexus tablets do not have SD card slots.

Avoid any tablet or smartphone that runs Android and comes with a SD card slot, as they're nothing but trouble.  I am so angry right now.  I'm tempted to pitch the stupid thing straight out the window.

The Galaxy Tab 2 is an okay tablet and I would likely think more highly of it if I could do a large portion of the tasks with it that I bought a tablet for.

I ended up getting the Tab 2 7.0 almost sight unseen when they were being discounted in the wake of the Tab 3 coming out and what I saved in that initial purchase price will likely be lost in functionality and features.

While the Tab 2 is fine enough when it comes to the average Android experience, using it for internet and reading purposes, the decision by Samsung to release with a proprietary connector for charging results its ease of use throughout different environments more difficult.  Unlike the similarly proprietary design of the various Apple connectors, the Samsung variation on the theme is nowhere near as available at a moments notice.  Losing a cable means being required to order online.

Finally, the tablet's inaccuracy on the touchscreen with the use of a stylus renders it completely useless for such tasks.  If you have any desire to use the tablet with a number of drawing apps with a stylus, the results are so horrible as to be frustrating and disheartening for someone who wants an affordable, portable digital sketchpad.  Even using a stylus with routine, non-detailed work is sometimes an exercise in futility.

No stylus performs well on this tablet that I can find, producing mostly jagged, broken, undesired and unnatural results.  Oddly enough, a quick test of a Galaxy Tab 3 and a few other, now-comparably-priced, tabs seem to show a much greater degree of sensitivity and accuracy with a stylus.  It's possible that this is a combination of a hardware/software issue that Samsung might release an update or an app for to rectify, but with the Tab 3 already out and the relative lack of support they appear to have already given the Tab 2, I doubt it.

In the end, the flaws of the Galaxy Tab 2, for me, outweigh its features, and will likely cause me to move on to another tablet that much sooner, which is a shame because I probably accept and live with the proprietary power connectors if the stylus controls were as good as my fingertip control.

Bought here on Amazon a few months ago.

The good:
This tablet continues to run great. I have it loaded with apps it runs with no problem, and have yet to find a good app it cannot run. If I let it sit and just use it to answer calls, texts, and email, with the occasional surf on the web, I get a whole day on one charge, and then some. If I get going on a game, or playing music steadily, a charge lasts me about 5 hours. The screen is plenty clear enough for me, and although I stuck in an old 32 gig card I had laying around, you could probably get by just fine for most tasks with the onboard 8 gigs, or maybe a 16 gig card would be ideal costwise. Wifi connections are strong, and it takes a beating from a toddler pretty good on occasion. I find the cameras adequate for my needs.

The bad:
This tablet has power problems. It thinks it is charging when it is not, and vice-versa. When hooked to my PC through the USB cord/AC adapter, it connects and disconnets itself randomly. Jiggling the cable sometimes has effect, sometimes doesn't. The problem is in the power connection, where you input the AC adapter plug into the tablet. This was found out after buying a separate cord.

Summary
Samsung customer support was my resort because my Amazon refund time has passed. I received a very nice email within hours of my email to them, asking me to send them the machine for service. Apparently this power problem is documented online in several places and Samsung is aware of the problem. Since my machine is running fine otherwise, and it is accepting a charge intermittently, I am going to keep it rather than send it in for repair, which could take some time. I think this could be a manufacturing defect.

Device has two problems that keep it from being a five star.

First Problem:  The SD card is only given limited function in Samsungs version of Android.  Only a very few apps can even find it.  Samsung includes an "SD card (emulated)" directory that most apps will find and save things to, but that's really on your internal 8GB of memory.  Only a few File Manager apps can find the actual card and move stuff there.  This includes most movie, music and graphics viewing apps.  The only apparent reason for this is to bring on the date where the eight GB internal memory becomes limiting and force you to upgrade sooner. (new $200 tablet instead of a new $20 SD card)  I can't imagine any other benefit to Samsung for limiting the usefulness of their product in this fashion.

Second Problem: The digitizer can't be used to draw with a stylus in art programs or for handwriting entry.  It gives wavy lines when drawing diagonally.  This includes sketching (drawing lightly back and forth).  In other tablets this doesn't happen, including the little $56 7inch things the local radio shack sells.  Tried this with 6 different styluses at a local store with a VERY understanding manager.  All the same.  Tried it with several different note taking and art apps.  Samo Samo. Go to customer supplied images for this product and click "all images"  I've uploaded the one that looks like just a bunch of Black, Red, Green, Blue and Yellow lines.  All the lines drawn should be straight and smooth like the black ones.  If you draw horizontally or vertically with a stylus the line comes out all wavy like the red and yellow lines, unless you draw the line really fast (not always practical).  There are comments about this on the web in various user forums, but none on any of the professional reviews for this product or on Samsung's own forum for this product (suspicious?).

IF you're sure you're not going to do anything that requires a stylus, art or note taking mainly.  AND you're sure that eight GB will be enough until you're wlling to buy something bigger.  THEN this is an Ok tablet at an excellent price.  Otherwise, move along, move along.  Find something else.

Let me start with a warning that I probably expect more, or at least different things, from a tablet that most buyers.  My primary reason for buying a tablet is to use it in my Jeep for off-road navigation, music and entertainment while otherwise off-the-grid.  So a key factor was great 4G performance.  As an AT&T customer for over 20 years, I've heard all the amazing claims about Verizon's network coverage.  So I went with Verizon this time and, frankly, I am far from impressed.

First of all, Verizon's coverage appears to be no better than AT&T's, at least not in the NY/NJ/PA area that I frequent.  So much for the improved service.  Making matters worse is that Verizon charges more for the its monthly data plans than AT&T.  Finally, even when I have a solid 4G signal, the data throughput is absolutely abysmal.  This little experiment with Verizon has decidedly caused me to abandon any ideas of switching my family's phone service from AT&T.

But more important is that Samsung has done something strange with the headphone jack on this tablet.  Normally I can plug an auxiliary audio cable from the headphone jack to the aux input on my car stereo and have all the sound go through the Jeep's speakers.  This tablet acts as though nothing is plugged-in; all sound continues to go through the internal speaker.  I contacted Samsung support and they could offer no insight or solution.  Thinking this was possibly a defective unit I returned it, and the replacement behaved the same way.  Odd, because we have a wifi-only SGS Tab 2 7" that did not have this problem, nor does my SGS 3 phone.

The other odd thing on this (and all other Samsung tablets prior to version 3) is the proprietary sync connector.  While the rest of the world (except Apple, no surprise) has adopted the micro-USB port as a standard, this tablet still uses a proprietary connector.  Not a huge deal, because you can buy extras for around $9 each.  Unless you forget to bring your cable on a trip and can't find anyone else with a Samsung tablet, and then you can't charge your tablet.

It is unfortunate that the only 4G Android tablet on the market has such fatal flaws (at least for me).  At this point I'm probably going to give the Tab 2 7.0 to my daughter and buy an Acer tablet and get a MiFi hotspot to use 4G.  I hate to have to carry yet another device, but unless someone steps up with an alternative (that is not a $700 iPad) I see no other options.

First off, all I can say is that I am absolutely amazed with this tablet. When I got it, it was very easy to get it up and running. When I received this tablet is was running Android 4.1.2 Jelly Bean. A few days later it upgraded to Android 4.2.2 Jelly Bean and runs even better than it did before. As for this video review, it is for the camera quality of the tablet, testing out the 3 MP (1280x720) 720p rear facing and the VGA (640x480) 480p front facing camera. Pros: -It is very light yet sturdy. -Comes with everything you need to get it up and running. (i.e. cords, and manuals) -It has a very elegant design. -The curves on the side are very nice, they don't hurt your hands like some other tablets will. -7 inches may seem small, but it is very usable, with a 1024x600 screen resolution -The text is very clear and easy to read. -Pinch to Zoom works really well... All hand gestures work very well. -The IR blaster is very nice, it sends signals from over 30 feet away, so it can be used as a nice universal remote -Power/Volume buttons are very easy to press. -The Microphone quality is exceptional, as seen in the video review. -The two stereo speakers are very loud and clear. -The data port is very nice and secure (When plugged in). -32 GB of external storage is a nice plus, because you only get 4 of the 8 GB stock. -The Accelerometer is extremely accurate. -GPS is sort of accurate, will go into detail in the Cons. -The Battery Life is exceptional, they advertised 8 hours when in constant use, I played a CPU intensive game for four hours and the battery was only down to 85%, so if it were to sit idle with the screen on full blast, it would last a lot longer than 8 hours. -Voice recognition, I would give about a 97% success rate, there are times that it has a hard time putting what I say because of my Oregonian Accent; but it does alright. -Abundant source of app and widgets with Google Play -You can Synchronize just about any account with this tablet, whether it be Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Vine, YouTube, and of course Google. -This tablet also has a light sensor, but I don't use it so I really don't know how well it works. Cons: -It is not an anti-glare screen, so reading outside is almost impossible; but it's not a deal-breaker. -Since the release of Android 4.1.1, they have taken the snapshot button away (that is a knock on Android, not Samsung) and now you have to hold down the power and volume down button to take a snapshot. -The GPS is not all the accurate when using offline map data and when using it when walking. -The virtual keyboard can be a bit finicky, but I have Paul Bunyan fingers. These are the only Cons I can think of because I have only had the tablet for a week, but from a weeks use; I can tell that it is a very durable with a lot of battery life, this is defiantly a great tablet for anyone who wants one for a very in-expensive price, keep in mind that the tablet that I am doing this review on is a WI-FI only tablet. The 3G-4G tablet will probably work a little differently. I guess that I am at the end of this review. Would I recommend this to a friend? Yes I would, but I would say spend the extra $30 and get the newest model (Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 7.0) Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 (7-Inch, Gold-Brown)

Have been using this tablet for a while, however, recently updated this fantastic tablet to 4.2.2 Jelly Bean and it runs very smoothly. Very impressed with the performance of this tablet. The Tab 2 is excellent for my everyday basic computer functions at home and on the road. And it is much easier to travel with than my heavy laptop. For you the reader, my goal here is to give you everyday and practical uses regarding the Tab 2 7.0 WiFi model.

PROS:

- EXTERNAL SLOT FOR MICRO SD CARD -  For me, I added a 32GB SD card. However, there are those who add a 64gb SD card, however, you will have to format it inside the Tab 2 and it will then be ready to add files. *With my new update to 4.2.2, I have successfully moved some of my personal apps to my External SD card. This you cannot do if you still have 4.1 as they store in INTERNAL SD Card area or the main internal area.

- WiFi Connecting/Speed of WiFi - Very, very fast! This tablet connected to my home router in seconds and even if I am very far from my home router, the internet is strong. This I tested using my home router and on the go at many hotspots with WiFi. . Other hotspots: No problems at all connecting and staying connected on these. And I found the speed still high at home with several devices connected to the router, no loss in speed. **Note that I had other tablets before this one and for me, none gave me the quick connect and overall speed over WiFi as the Tab 2. **Even when I have many devices running, the speed of WiFi is fast on this tablet.

- Internet & Webpage & Video Viewing - The stock browser does a great job, however, I use Maxthon Browser with great internet viewing results and it renders webpages quite fast for me. And I suggest the free app called Pocket from the Playstore so you can read internet articles later offline. Even TODAY after almost ten months of ownership, I still enjoy using this tablet for viewing internet pages, videos and more.

- Reading/Creating/Editing Word, Excel, Text Files and much more on this tablet: This comes with a OK app for reading Office documents, however, I prefer Kingsoft Office which is a free app from Playstore. It is the best I have ever tried and I am very picky about so called Office programs. It is very compatible with MS Office as it reads, edits and creates Office files and reads PDF files, and it has more features of any other Android Office program that I tried. This app is a MUST have for tablet owners in my opinion.

- Printing Using the Tab 2 - Yes, even with my older home printer, I print documents, photos, etc that are on my Tab 2 using the app Cloud Print and PrinterShare Mobile (both free from Playstore. In addition, there are many apps in the Playstore that will allow you to print using the Tab 2. (If you have questions about printing using the Tab 2 or any question, please ask in the comment section and I will answer).

- Watching Online Flash Videos Directly From Maxthon Browser (regular one not the tablet one is best) - If archived flash is installed and Maxthon Browser or other good browsers, I can play videos online. Also, as I May 21, 2013, (with installed Archived Flash), I once again get Amazon Videos to play even in full screen. All videos I have tried have played just fine. ***Please ask me in the comments if you need more details regarding watching online videos of any kind on the Tab 2 and also instructions on archived flash,etc...

- Home Videos - The stock video player is OK and plays MOST home videos, however, may I suggest QQ Player (Free App from Playstore and the ONLY one I recommend as it plays every home video I tried).

- Music Player/Sound Quality - Stock player has clear sound through the outside "speakers" and very clear using headphones. To sync easily with Windows Media Player may I suggest the Playstore app free) WinAmp for the tablet as it is very highly rated and the sound is SUPERB!

- Battery Life- Excellent! This is what I have found: When I am on WiFi, I go to the websites I need and then as soon as I am done (reasonable time), I exit the browser (or YouTube, etc) and TURN OFF WiFi. However, I run my brightness at 100%. So on an average day, I get at least 8-12 hours using the tablet before I charge it (depending on how long my WiFi is connected).

- OTG USB Compatible - You can add an optional OTG (On the Go adapter cable to the Micro port for copying files to your flash drive and from your flash drive to the Tab 2). You can also plug in a mouse, I tried it and it worked. *Note that portable external hard drives and portable DVD/CD drives will not work using OTG in the Tab 2 because these both require a lot of power to be compatible with the Tab 2 and most tablets that have the OTG. However, it is still good to know that you can easily plug in your flash drive and copy files to the Tab 2 and from Tab 2 to PC--what a time-saver.

- Bluetooth Speed and Performance - The Bluetooth paired quickly with several devices and copied files at a great rate of speed. Speaking of Bluetooth: Also there are many great Bluetooth keyboards out for the Tab2. (Just make sure you purchase one for JUST THE TAB2 10.1).

- Wonderful Kindle Android App is pre-installed, and I downloaded several Kindle books with no problems. Kindle loads fast and this Tablet is a joy to read a book on either Kindle or any eBook or PDF booklet.

CONS: (Just one con I found, however, this con is NOT the fault of Samsung)
- New Adobe Flash is not supported, however, I found that archived flash gets the online videos to play. So I downloaded the older archived flash which gives me the ability to view many internet videos.

Bottom line: Would I buy this WiFi only model over again? Yes I certainly would and I already did (bought my second one). So if you are looking for a superb Samsung 7.0 inch tablet and you have great access to WiFi, this is the one to buy. Also, since I am a techie person, I will be happy to answer any questions you may have through the comment section.

The Galaxy has a very interesting feature. When you compose an email, you can speak the words and the Galaxy will input your words into the email.  I tried this several times. Even with my Bostonian accent it accurately input my words. The only other experience was with my cell phone. My words were interpreted as a bunch of gibberish.
One interesting thing which results from not having completely read the manual is that sometimes I am completely taken by surprise while experimenting with a new device. There is a feature that allows you to speak the search item in google. A google search page comes up with all the relative search items. I wanted to find out how my favorite baseball team was doing. I spoke the words "Red Sox" and a female voice came back to me and said "The Boston Red Sox are tied in the top of the eighth inning 3-3 with the Baltimore Orioles".
Another thing the Galaxy has that I have been using a lot already is the Bluetooth feature.  I have already paired the Galaxy with my cell phone and desktop. I have transferred some photos and documents.
This review is meant to be a "first impression" review. I will post an addendum in a few weeks and maybe a picture or two.

I can't believe there are so many complaints about the proprietary USB cable.  It was meant to be used for charging only.  To use a USB device, will need to purchase an OTG adapter cable instead.  OTG means USB On-The-Go, which is actually pretty cool.  It can read disk drives, or it can allow the tablet to act as a disc drive, when plugging the tablet into a computer.

I bought my OTG adapter cable from NewEgg.  It's cheap and everything I plugged into it worked great.

Remember to eject/unmount the OTG device via system Settings > Storage > Unmount OTG device before taking the cable off the tablet.

About the tablet itself, I will not give a full review, but just a few things people might've overlooked:

. The biggest advantage of using the Galaxy Tab vs other cheaper no-name brands is that apps are usually tested for it.  There are cheaper tablets out there, like the Asus Memo, but they have compatibility problems with many apps.

. Even though the new Google Nexus 7 will blow this tablet away in terms of hardware specs, I still bought the Galaxy Tab 2 because availability of microSD port and because of reliability issues of the Nexus.

. The IR blaster feature (TV remote control) works with my Sony Bravia TV and LG blu-ray player.

Fixing Bootloop- Here's what works to fix mine when I get into a power on loop. Unfortunately the only fix is to factory reset the device (why I don't suggest storing anything you don't have backed up elsewhere. Store things you need kept on an external microsd), I've scoured the net, but unfortunately found no other working fix (I've dealt with the bootloop twice now). Hold down power and volume up button until the screen goes black (may take some tries at different points of the power up loop). Once it goes black and doesn't restart on it's own press the power and volume up again until it turns on (it will restart the loop again if you try to let it go from here, but if you're like me you'll try anyways, just in case). Once it starts powering up again let go of both buttons then immediatly press the power button again, only. A droid dude should pop up. Let go of power. You may have to try a few times to get to this stage. Once there use volume down to highlight factory reset then hit power (remove your external sd first!!!!). This will tale you to a list with a bunch of nos and one yes. Use the volume to highlight yes then hit power. Once it says it's complete select to reboot. Installing Flash- Here's how you install flash(so you can watch videos online and play games on sites and etc). It's actually really easy. You just have to download flash from the adobe site, it's in the archives. [...] just scroll til you see flash for android 4.0 then click the first download link under that (you will need to click in settings that you can download third party stuff. It will give you the option to do this after you click on the uploaded apk file in the menu to the lower right that pops up when you click on the time). After you change setting just go into the files folder app (yellow folder) go to downloads and click the flash apk. Choose to install. You now have flash. Easy peasy. (Also here's a vid how to from adobe [...] Usb/Sd Access- If you need access to usb, a full sd card or etc then look up graybean card reader hub for galaxy tab (B0084NYYGQ This is the best product I've found for cost and quality (aka durability). Removing Ads- Another complaint I saw was about the hubs and suggests that come preloaded on the tablet. To get rid of these just remove the hubs from your screen. Long press and move to the trash/remove in upper right. No more ads Easy Peasy ;-) My review- I also have the original galaxy tab 7 and ended up replacing this tab 2 7 with a tab 2 10. This model is much cheaper then the original, and for good reasons. That said, it is wonderful for the cost and I have already suggested it to a few friends asking me about budget friendly tablets. The tablet is missing some of the features of the original, most notably the camera quality and zooming. I apreciated with the first being able to take nice-ish pics and video of our kids, then being able to show them off on the 7 inch screen. However, the imbedded 8gbs this tablet comes with is very nice for storage and media purposes. Especially for all the apps you cannot move to your removable sd card (on the original you could move apps over with a feature built into the devices app setting- that is lacking in this model. Probably because they gave you so much built in storage). I decided on a tab 2 10 with 16gb instead for the extra room (although I believe you can get 16gb in the 7inch also) so manly the larger size screen making it easier to view things like magazines, websites and streamed video. One of the things I liked most about the 7 inch though is it fits in your purse in place of a planned book, currently being a sahm I find less need for the tablet to be more compact. For the undrr $200 cost this is a great option.

I purchased this item refurbished from another retailer. I got the wireless unit. I've now owned it for about a month, and I'm very happy with it.  I bought this tablet primarily to use as navigation device for off-road traveling.  I'm using Back Country Navigator (BCN Pro), and Roll-Me-Over by DriveHard.  I drive an FJ cruiser, and it was easy for me to mount the tablet on my dash using the Fintie Slim Fit Folio Case [purchased on Amazon] and a little commercial-grade velcro.  The GPS works flawlessly.  It is my understanding that a lot of folks are having a hard time comprehending how you use this unit with the GPS and maps for navigation purposes.  It's really very simple.  Regardless of which navigation tools you choose, you MUST download the maps you'll need beforehand, i.e., BEFORE you travel.  To me it's pretty obvious that you'll only have access to the internet when wireless is available to you, so don't expect to be able to access maps you don't have when you're out on wilderness peak somewhere in the middle of nowhere...unless there happens to be an internet cafe at the summmit ;-)

I also ran a test on the USB charger in the car.  If you plug the USB cord into your car's USP port, it will charge, but at a very reduce rate compared to a regular AC charger.  If you are running the tablet, while it's plugged into the USB, the battery will discharge, but at a much slower rate than if you didn't have it plugged in at all.  It works kind of like a trickle charger. I managed to run my tablet using BCN for about 5 hours, and the battery only discharged from around 89% to about 67%.  When I turned the tablet off, the USB charger brought it back up to about 74% in just and hour or so.  I also have a Samsung detachable car charger [purchase on Amazon] that will charge at the full 2amp rate.  Samsung recommends that you not run the tablet when doing a full 2amp charge, or the battery may not charge correctly.

I also use the tablet for quicky email checks, and web browsing, etc.  It's nice to have it for those things too.  Now I don't have to arm wrestle my wife for the netbook at home, since I have my OWN device now.  Incidentally, I've not entered the smartphone world as yet, so this unit probably does a lot of things for me that smartphone might do for other folks.  However, I have to say that I like the larger screen. But, it's not so large as to not be easily portable.  That's why I wasn't very interested in Samsung's 10-inch unit.

I'll try to remember to update this review if anything new needs to be added.

I've owned this product for almost a year now, and the list of cons just keeps growing and growing. Here they are so far:

CONS

1. The cheap plastic housing makes a creaking noise when you hold it by the edges. It feels like it's about to fall apart. I was reluctant to return it for such a trivial complaint, so I ended up opening the case and rubbing some petroleum jelly on the plastic tabs. That reduced most of the noise, but you can see where I pried open the housing.

2. When I bought the device, Samsung strictly enforced the $249 price tag. That was good because I didn't have to worry about waking up the next day and finding it cheaper somewhere else. Then a couple of weeks after I bought it, Samsung lowered the price down to $199, and now it is even lower than that. Of course I expected them to lower the price at some point, but $50 is a huge difference.

3. The device is filled with bloatware that you can't uninstall. The 8 GB internal drive is reduced to around 4.5 GB. A freshly installed copy of the original Windows XP takes up only around 0.5 GB of space, so I marvel at how Android can be so big. I understand that you will never get the full advertised capacity, but this is just ridiculous.

4. When I bought the device it came with Ice Cream Sandwich. When Samsung upgraded to Jellybean, they wiped out all of my customized user icons on the homescreen and replaced them with icons to "stores" and "hubs" to try to get me to purchase their crap. That wasn't nice.

5. The glossy screen makes it very difficult to see. If I wanted to see my reflection, I'd use a mirror.

6. The Samsung keyboard sucks. They won't allow you to use the default Android keyboard. I had to purchase a 3rd party one.

SD CARD CONS

7. First, let me say that the whole reason I bought this product over the Google Nexus 7 was because it had an external SD card. Otherwise I would have got the Nexus because it has a quad-core CPU and a higher resolution screen for the same price. I thought I could save money by getting the smaller 8 GB device and using the memory cards that I already own. Now it seems like the SD card is almost useless on the Galaxy.

8. You can't load apps onto the external SD card. As I mentioned earlier, half of the internal storage is filled with bloatware, so this is really a limitation.

9. I like to watch MP4 music videos, but if you watch them off of the SD card (which is where you're supposed to store them), the videos stutter every now-and-then. They run fine off of the internal memory, but there's no space to put them there.

10. DON'T STORE ANYTHING IMPORTANT ON THE SD CARD. All of my files magically disappeard one day. It seems to have a lot of trouble loading large files onto the SD card. When I try to transfer audio, video, or image files, they get corrupted during transfer and the entire SD card needs to be reformatted. I've tried three different SD cards and they all behaved the same way. I am able to transfer files using a card reader without any problem, so I know it isn't the card that's faulty. I'm not sure yet if all Galaxys have this problem.

The Galaxy Tab 2 has two fatal flaws, as far as I see it.  The first is not surprising, but still annoying.  The second is a killer if you connect it to your computer.
The first flaw involves the volume/on-off buttons.  They are part way up the right side of the device.  Not too bad, if you are right-handed.  If you are left-handed, though, guess where your fingers naturally fall when you hold it?  Dead on the buttons!  Add that to the lack of a flash for the camera and spotty touch support, it is not a great device overall.
As a developer, though, the real fatal flaw rears it's ugly head.  Many times, when you insert the device into the USB port with the cord, Windows promptly reports, "Hardware ID not found" and refuses to connect with the device.  This is a software bug, and as a developer, I plug the unit into my PC 20 times a day!  The only real cure is rebooting the whole machine, and even then, it sometimes does not fix the issue.  I tried to get the new drivers, but mine are up to date, and some people recommend actually rolling the drivers back to fix the flaw!  Now add to this part II of the flaw, and you get a barely usable device.  When files are updated on the tablet, they do NOT update in Windows Explorer.  The only way to update Explorer is to unplug the device, which, guess what, causes the aforementioned bug when it gets plugged back in!  And if you unplug the device while Explorer is on a Tab's folder, Explorer force-closes!  Not fun at all.
So if you want to use this as a cheap developing tool, think again.

I had been happy with my iPod Touch for more than a year, but wanted a relatively inexpensive tablet I could use more for videos and other graphics-intensive games and apps where the larger screen would be an advantage. I got that and more with this tablet.

PROS:

- I love its customizable wallpapers (including animated wallpapers).

- With the push of one button, I can wirelessly sync it with my Xbox 360 to watch videos stored on my tablet on my TV.

- It plays far more video file formats than my iPod, which won't let you watch anything that's not .mp4 or .mov.

- When I connect to my computer via USB, I can drag-and-drop files onto it, unlike my iPod, which required iTunes. (You can download syncing software for the Samsung tablet, but I've found I hardly ever use it.)

- The screen works in portrait or landscape, unlike the iPod, whose home screen can only be used in portrait.

- Ability to open settings for screen brightness, Wifi, GPS, Bluetooth, etc. from anywhere on the device.

- I'm admittedly kind of a cheapskate, but I love that fact that I can get some free, complete ad-supported games ("Angry Birds," "Fruit Ninja") from the Google Play store that I'd have to pay 99 cents for in the iTunes store.

- I bought a 8GB version of this tablet, but I was able to find a very inexpensive 16GB micro-SD card that instantly tripled my capacity. So far, storage is something I've never had to be concerned about.

- Speech recognition is surprisingly excellent, though not 100% perfect.

- Battery life. I don't know how this compares to other tablets, but I use the device pretty constantly, and I've been totally happy with it. You can watch several hours of video on a single charge.

CONS:

- Unlike my iPod, it doesn't charge when connected to a computer unless it is off or asleep. To charge it while using it, you'll need AC power, which is a minor inconvenience (though an AC adapter is included). I ended up buying a cheap extension cord so I don't have to sit next to an outlet to use it.

- A lot of glare on the screen from outside light, but that problem was solved by an anti-glare screen protector with a matte finish. The matte finish sacrifices a tiny bit of sharpness in video, but it's minor, so I wouldn't even really call it a problem.

- I kinda thought a larger device would make a touch-screen keyboard easier to use, but typing with this can be kind of a pain.

STILL UNKNOWN:

- Music: It has an audio player, but having an iPod I've found I don't have much need for this function on my tablet. I did listen to a couple of podcasts and they worked fine.

- Photo/Video: I've owned this for a few months now and still haven't played with many of the photo or video options. I've taken a few pics that have turned out fine, but most of the time, my tablet is the least convenient camera device I have on hand.

CONCLUSION:

I wouldn't trade my iPod for the world, but I'm so glad I didn't shell out for an iPad when buying a tablet. I would have paid more than twice as much, and I don't think I would have gotten twice the quality, given the unique advantages of this operating system vs. the iOS. Highly recommended.

This is my third Android tablet. The first was from Vizio and it was horrible. Underpowered, unresponsive and not all that cheap (this was a couple of years ago). I returned it on my second day of ownership. My next attempt was with this very same tablet, but running the 4.0 'Ice Cream Sandwich' version of Android. This was much better than the Vizio tablet, but still suffered from uneven performance and a user experience that when compared to the iPad came up short. Again, the price was near $300 and in the end I just couldn't live with it and it too went back to the store.

So it was with this background that I saw the Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 on sale at Costco for $159.95. I noticed that it was now running Android 4.1 "Jelly Bean" and remembered reading that this release had done wonders for Android's user experience. "Project Butter" and all that. So knowing Costco's return policy was very lenient and it being a rainy day (some people deal with depression by eating ice cream; I buy electronics), I thought I would give it a try. I fully expected to bring it back the next day.

After using this tablet for 24 hours all I can say is: Wow! Jelly Bean makes this a whole new tablet. Everything flows, apps work like they should and even the default browser is decent (it has a new 'laboratory' setting where you get a full-screen experience and 'thumb gestures' that are really nice). Netflix streams perfectly, Pandora plays without interruption, the wifi connection is rock solid and the GPS locked onto *14* satellites from inside my house. The battery will go 8+ hours doing web browsing and video with the screen on 50%. Even the IR TV app impressed me where the one last year did not. For $160 bucks this thing rocks and I am keeping it.

Please bear in mind that this is no iPad Mini, but it's getting close and it has the IR and GPS features that the wifi version of that device lacks. SOUND: Very good stereo sound (strong volume and neat sound).

I had begun to be interested in the world of tablets, and I started to look for a small, budget conscious device, and I found the Galaxy Tab 2 7 Inch, and I am pretty astounded by the quality and value of this device, it does not mimic the cheapness found in similar tablets of this price range, with a highly responsive screen, full Android 4.0, and a good build. Also being a 7 inch device it is very easy to hold with one hand, and it is very light, it is definitely a good choice for those who are on the move often. The device is not perfect though, with a few hiccups.

Performance

The device responds quickly to commands, plays media flawlessly, and runs every app without incident, but after a week of using the device, there was an odd slow down of the home screen that occurred for about 5 minutes, I did not get the issue again since, that is the only issue I have had with the performance. I think it was the stock TouchWiz interface, I have since switched to GOLauncher, it's great.

Battery Life

The battery life is great so far, after being charged to 100% I got 2 days of use without charging, tasks on the device included a little web browsing, browsing and installing apps, and some video/picture taking.

Networking

The device is WiFi only; I have had no issues with it, reception is no different than the other WiFi devices in my household.

Interface

The device uses Samsung's TouchWiz interface; which to my guess is a modified 4.0 interface, it is a nice interface, without lag, but the lock screen seems a little boring, I will probably look into using the default 4.0 interface, or something else.

Screen

The screen is very good in my opinion, it displays content nicely, and it is very responsive. There have been a few instances where I have sworn I tapped the screen and nothing happened, it could be my error, or the device's.

Audio

The device features two speakers at the bottom of the device, which sound nice but are not the best I have ever heard. The microphone is located at the top of the device near the 3.5 mm headphone jack, from a little use of the Google voice command feature, I have found no issues.

Cameras

The device features a front and rear camera, the rear camera is 3 MP which takes decent photos, while the front camera is a VGA camera that is good for video chat, it is no SLR camera, but has good cameras.

Ports

The Tab 2 features a 3.5mm headphone jack at the top, Micro SD slot with door, proprietary Samsung USB port at the bottom. The most interesting is a built in IR Blaster located on the right side, which is supposed to be used with the included Peel Remote app ( I had to manually update the app before being able to use it) which worked very well with controlling my devices (LCD TV, Sony Surround system, Comcast DVR). My only true gripe is the lack of a Micro USB or micro HDMI port to be used with projecting content onto a TV screen, one must purchase Samsung's adapter to do so.

Buttons

The Tab 2 features only 2 buttons, which are located on the right side of the device, the first button is the usual lock/wake button, and a volume up/down button, I would of liked to see a Home button, but the 4.0 interface takes care of that.

Build Quality

The Tab 2 has a solid hard plastic build, the back of the device features a soft metal like shell that feels good when held.

Pre-installed Apps

This is one of my gripes with the Tab 2, the device comes pre-installed with a suite of bloatware, that cannot be installed as far as I have discovered, I prefer the default Android apps, with apps I choose to install. It does come with some useful apps such as Netflix and Kindle bookstore.

Overall, it is a fantastic device, with a few hiccups that may only bother a select group of users, being a first time owner, I cannot compare this tablets to others personally.
I only use it for my bible reading; and occasional internet browzing, and email reading, and some pictures, and for those reasons it performs fine for me.

I've only had my Galaxy Tab 2 for a couple days, and I can say without a doubt it's a fantastic little device and well worth the money. It came down to between this or the Nexus 7, and after playing around with my friend's Nexus 7 (wasn't all that impressed) I took the plunge with the Galaxy. Pros: 1. Very quick and responsive. I'm one of those OCD stylus guys, so I also purchased Samsung's special tip stylus with the Galaxy. It works very well. 2. The setup wasn't bad at all, and it only took me less than 20 minutes to have my Galaxy running across all of my Google applications. I had no problems with any of them. Gmail, Google Drive, Maps... they all work flawlessly. You don't need Chrome or vanilla Android to streamline the Google experience. 3. It has a MicroSD slot! Folks, this was the deal maker and breaker for me. The Nexus 7 (for some mysterious reason) does not have a disk expansion slot. The Galaxy Tab 2 may only come with 8GB native memory space, but throw in a 32GB MicroSD and you've suddenly got 40GB. Keep a few spares and you've got nearly limitless space for all of your media. 4. The best portable Bluetooth keyboard/case on the market, IVSO Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 Bluetooth Keyboard Portfolio Case - DETACHABLE Bluetooth Keyboard Stand Case / Cover for Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 Tablet (Black), is only available for the Galaxy line of tablets. It works great and allows me to write using Google Drive with much more portability than my laptop. The days of not being able to use a tablet as an effective word processor are over! 5. Has both front AND rear facing cameras making it great for Skype, Instagram and other social media applications. 6. The PRICE! The value can't be bested at this point in time. You're getting a quality device for next to nothing that easily rivals an iPad mini. Cons: 1. It doesn't come with a USB transfer cable, which I think they could have thrown in. But just download the WiFi Transfer App and you'll never need that cable again, anyway. 2. I'm not just going to sit here and make stuff up! So far, there are no other cons. So if you're on the fence, jump into Samsung's backyard. Google just hasn't quite figured out how to balance quality with value yet, even though they're on the right track with ASUS. But unless you want to wait six months for the next gen Nexus (which will still be more money), get yourself a Galaxy Tab 2. You won't be disappointed! UPDATE: Actually, it does come with a USB transfer cable (I just didn't realize it because the cable also serves as the wall charger adapter). But you still would never need it with that awesome Wi-Fi Transfer app. UPDATE #2: I've found one CON that, according to my research, is more of an OS/Google problem than a Samsung problem... though a problem nonetheless. Unless you "root" your tablet (you can search the web on how to do that), there is currently no way to transfer apps to the external SD card. Since game apps can often be very large (some up to 3 or 4GB), you might lose space on the native memory very quickly. With that said, ANYTHING else can be easily saved or transferred to the external SD card (e.g., music, images, movies, docs). Since I haven't downloaded any giant games, I haven't had an issue with this limitation. However, I realize that a lot of people play games more than anything else on their tablets, so this would definitely be something for them to consider. I really hope that Google resolves this issue with future Android updates for the Galaxy series.

Back in November 2011 I decided that 7" tablets were the sweet spot for me, roughly the same size as a paper back novel, and about the same weight, I was going to get a Dell Streak7 but Dell discontinued it, so I ended up buying three Samsung Tab 7.0 plus in early 2012, I was quite happy with them, until I dropped mine just about a year later and broke the glass - the 7.0 plus has been discontinued, so I replaced it with the Tab2 7.0, the subject of this review.

I'm a wee bit disappointed that it does not have 5GHz WiFi, but I can live without it, the same goes for the flash on the rear facing camera, and delighted to find that the Tab2 has much better battery life than my old 7.0 plus - I have no idea if this is OS or hardware related as the 7.0 plus is running Ice Cream Sandwich, and the Tab2 7.0 is running Jelly Bean - but with the 7.0 plus I could easily drain the battery in a couple of hours and had to remember to disable the WiFi when not using it, the Tab2 in contrast has been running with the WiFi on for over two days on the initial battery charge.

Well - after six months with the Tab2, I am out of storage space - my not so favorite app, Zinio, for reasons best known to them (and despite promises to do so) won't let me store magazines on the SD card and filled up my storage.

I dragged out the old Tab 7.0+ and found a genuine Samsung digitizer on ebay and fixed it - the colors on the old 7.0+ are much more vivid than the Tab2.

I was very impressed with the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 4G LTE (Verizon). Its size, weight and cost were all exactly what I required in a mini tablet computer. Unfortunately, the one function I absolutely needed, the ability to scan credit cards, did not work at all on this model.

I've been using this Samsung tablet for over a year now and have been slowly compiling experience and opinion about this device.  Only now have I really formed an opinion.  Since the Galaxy Tab 2 is getting a little older now, this review may be more helpful as a what to look for guide in newer models.

Let me start with the good.  This 7 inch tablet is compact enough to take almost anywhere.  In many ways, it is a miraculous device.  Such a device would really have been nearly inconceivable just a decade ago.  But do technological achievement and novelty translate into utility?

The tablet serves well as an e-reader.  As such, it does have its drawbacks.  I also own an e-ink Kindle and would say overall the Kindle is a superior e-reader.  Still, the tablet is convenient and portable.  I probably wouldn't want to do multi-hour reading sessions on it;  it's also not good for reading in sunlight, but it is serviceable as a reader.

It also serves well as an entertainment device.  My children see it as a gaming toy.  So do their cousins.  Anytime we go on a trip, the kids mob the tablet.  It's also good for streaming Netflix and other videos, although the screen is so small that you really only want to do this when no other device is available.  But this is the trade-off of portability.

It also works for keeping contacts, calendaring/scheduling, and taking short notes.

Now, the bad.  In many ways my experiences with this tablet have been frustrating and leaving me yelling out that this tablet is just a toy.  Allow me to enumerate several such experiences.

Google Navigation is basically useless on this tablet.  After I purchased it I thought I might be able to use it in place of my Garmin as a GPS navigation device in the car.  Wrong!  Without an active Wi-Fi connection, Google Navigation is nearly inoperable.  If you pre-load your destination route BEFORE you leave, it might get you there.  If you need to visit a new destination while you're out, you are up a creek.  Really, Google Navigation was designed to use on cell-phones with constant connection to cell towers, not for tablets with no cell service.  I see why they originally designed it this way, but for tablets it is an epic failure.

The main camera on this tablet is utterly lacking.  It takes low-grade pictures and lacks autofocus.  Lacking autofocus turns out to be a real Achilles heel as several apps I've attempted to use have it as a requirement.  As a result, I can't use this tablet to scan barcodes or QR codes!  Pathetic, but true.  Also, my mobile deposit app reliability suffers for the same reason.  When I first realized I could use my tablet to do mobile deposit I thought I had found a real utility for it.  Only to have my hopes crushed by no autofocus.

I've been learning to tune pianos, so I really was excited to find the tuning apps available.  After playing around with these apps, I realized that attaching an external microphone to the tablet would improve accuracy.  Surely this would be a possibility?  Uh, no, not really.  I have found some crazy guides on the Internet, but it is crude at best and too much effort to boot.  Not being able to easily attach an external mic was something of a shocking disappointment for me.

A few words about Android.  It's not as refined as I expected it might be.  It mostly gets the job done, but is really simplistic.  I'm not sure if it's an Android limitation or a limitation to my specific device or browser, but it can't really multitask.  For example, if I tune in to an Internet radio channel, then open a browser tab to surf the web, the audio dies.  Kinda lame.  Android is neat for what it does and that it exists at all, but the user experience is pretty average.  My tablet started out with Ice Cream Sandwich installed and then Samsung updated me to Jelly Bean, a step backwards in my estimation.  Jelly Bean made my tablet look more like a phone with tiny little buttons and icons even though my screen has more real estate than that.  In my opinion, ICS is better for tablets than JB.

Last, but not least, this tablet does not have a user replaceable battery.  So far it hasn't been a problem, but unless you are willing to undergo a somewhat risky replacement operation, you'll have to send it in to Samsung and will likely be without your tablet for at least a week.  For me this wouldn't really matter since it hasn't proven itself indispensable anyway.

In summary, I would say this tablet is more of a toy than a useful tool.  It's close to being more useful, but has not quite reached primetime.  If I were to sum it up in one word, the word would be: frustrating.

Samsung Galaxy Tab 2

Before buying the Tab 2, I read several Consumers Reports articles on tablets.  (Oct 2012 and Feb 2013)  I wanted a tablet so that I could read ebooks, surf the internet, read email, take an occasional picture, view pictures imported from other devices, and maybe do a little GPS navigation.  I did not want a monthly bill for a 3G/4G connection.  The Kindle Fire HD has a good price, superior speakers, but has no GPS or camera.  The Google Nexus is highly rated and inexpensive, but has only a front camera - good for Skype but not for taking pictures.  The iPad Mini is highly rated but expensive and lacks GPS.  I had some difficulty discerning the pros/cons of the Galaxy Tab 7.0 Plus and the Galaxy Tab 2.  The Galaxy Tab 7.0 Plus is actually a year older than the Tab 2 and runs an older version of Android (3.2), but costs quite a bit more.  The only significant advantage I found in it is that is more internal storage - either 16GB or 32GB.  However, you can buy a Tab 2 with 8GB and install a 32GB micro SD card at a lower cost than a Tab 7.0 Plus.  The front camera on the Tab 2 has less resolution - 640 x 480 - but that is plenty for Skype, I think.  CR also rated the Toshiba Excite and Toshiba Thrive.  The Excite is highly rated but very expensive.  The Thrive is a bit lower rated than the Google and Samsung models, yet costs more.  So there you have it - I chose the Tab 2 and got a good sale price.

I had a strange experience when I went to buy it.  The salesman tried real hard to get me to get an iPad - to the point of bullying me, I'd say.  He said he had a Samsung and got rid of it and got an iPad instead.  Maybe that was the truth, maybe not.  I pointed out that the iPad doesn't have GPS, and he said that GPS doesn't work well on a tablet anyway.  He said that the Samsung would not work with iTunes, which is true.  With the Galaxy, you can either sync music and photos with Windows Media Player or Kies, which is free software that Samsung provides at their web site.  I have used iTunes with other MP3 devices, and I tried both Windows Media Player and Kies.  They both work fine, but maybe not as well as iTunes.  Kies helps you install firmware and software updates on your Tab 2 or other Samsung device.  It is supposed to be able to import playlists from iTunes, but I did not succeed at that.  I created my own playlists in Kies.  Maybe the salesman figured that since I was twice as old as him, I couldn't figure out the Tab 2.  Or maybe he wanted a bigger commission.

The most pleasant surprise was that the Tab 2 prompted me to enter my Google username and password, and that immediately made my Gmail, Google Calendar, and Google+ accounts available and synchronized.

The most unpleasant surprise came when I tried to print an email from the Tab 2.  I was informed that I could only print on a Samsung printer.  Well I am not going to get  Samsung printer.  I read on another review that the EasyPrint app makes it possible to print to other printers - I'll try it.

I was annoyed that the Gallery app has an icon to make it easy to upload pictures to Google+, but not Facebook.

It has voice recognition, so when you want to enter text, there is a microphone icon.  Click it, and speak, and the words you speak go into the text box.  Works pretty well, and is fun.

Everything I read said it had Android 4.0, but mine has 4.1.  Apparently the change was made at the end of 2012.

The Tab 2 is slippery and hard to hold on to.  I keep mine in a cover all the time, which takes care of that.  I didn't find many covers that were custom sized for the Tab 2, so I got a universal sized one, which works fine, but is a bit larger than necessary, so it won't fit into any of my pockets.

It has blue tooth, but I haven't made use of it yet.  It would be good with a blue tooth keyboard.  My Chevy Equinox allows blue tooth phones to connect to the sound system, but not tablets.  It also has an infra-red light, and Peel software, to make it a remote control for your TV, DVR, etc, which I have not tried.

This was my first Android device.  There is no user manual on the device, or in the box, but a decent user manual can be downloaded from the Samsung web site.  It is reasonably easy to figure out how to do things on the Tab 2.  If you are new to Android, you have to try things and see what they do.

I'd give it five stars if they would add a capability to print to any wifi printer and an icon for uploading pictures to Facebook.

This is a high tech device that with a little shopping around you can get at a price below $200.00. If you like to star gaze, load Google Sky, hold your tablet up to the sky and enjoy how accurate the built in magnetometer inside will display the positions of the objects in the night sky. This also means when you load a compass application it will very accurate as well.
It also has built in GPS that is independent of internet service so you can always use your map program.
An application that I find very useful is one that comes preloaded and is unique to this Samsung unit.  It's called "Smart Remote" and once you set it up you'll have not only a real time TV guide at your fingertips but you'll also be able to control all your video devices from the comfort of you couch.
What is interesting and disappointing at the same time is it has front and rear facing cameras that work just fine and I used the camera a lot on vacation. However, if you plan to read bar codes or QR codes, know that it does not do that well at all. The camera just does not focus in on close objects at all.  So if you plan to do a lot of close up pictures or bar code reading, you will be very disappointed.
Other than the close up picture disappointment, this is a very nice unit and I would defiantly recommend it.
