I received this as a birthday gift on Thursday April 11th 2013, and it's amazing!

Pros:
. Very easy to setup (especially if you already have a Gmail account)

. Good battery life, on fairly heavy use it lasted me 14 hours but it would last your average user about a day and a half without needing a charge. The battery life really depends on the user though, it depends on things like, screen brightness, apps running in the back ground, GPS and other things being on when the don't need to be. Needless to say you won't have to worry about charging it in the middle of the day because the battery last all day long.

. It's very user friendly and doesn't take very much time to get use to at all, took me about 20 minuets of messing around with it to fully grasp how this device works.

. Very portable! I never really understood how much more portable tablets are compared to laptops until I got this.

. Overall picture quality is very crisp! I've only had this thing for two days and watched at least 20 Youtube videos, mostly music videos and a couple of Netflix shows, all in 720p HD, the display is very bright, I mean dangerously bright and vibrant!

. Super customizeable! There really isn't a limit as to what you can't do on this thing. I love how I can customize the lock screen with my favorite pictures, security features and even the option to write a message on the lock screen. I put my name in the message box just in case it ever gets lost or stolen so there wouldn't be any fuss as to who's device it is.

. Perfect size for me, if you don't want something as big as a 10 inch tablet but still want the screen to be big enough to fully enjoy great resolution quality of your videos and pictures than this is definitely the tablet for you, if you want a larger screen I'd recommend the 10 inch version of this tablet, which I have also used. It's awesome too!

. It has flash support!

. Expandable memory via Micro SD card up to 32GB, I absolutely love that feature! Unlike the I pad you don't have to pay an extra $100 just for an extra 32GB of space, which I find ridiculous. Just order a 32GB card from Sandisk for $20 bucks or a 16GB card for $5 and you're good to go.

. Front facing camera great for skype, oovoo and other webcam apps.

. Runs very smooth with no delays on the touch screen.

Minor cons

. Overall design could have been better in my opinion, it has a somewhat unattractive back cover, that is just kinda bland, but lets be honest here. The fist thing everyone does when they get a smart device is throw a case on it anyways, well I know I did anyways, so this really wasn't an issue for me.

. Like I said before the brightness can literally hurt your eyes if you have it cranked up high for long periods of time, not to mention excessive screen brightness drains your battery a lot faster than it normally would drain.

. Camera Quality isn't the best but it's not bad either, I think it could be a little better but considering the ridiculous bargain price of the tablet and the fact that there is actually even a camera on the thing unlike the Kindle Fire HD it's really not that bad of a flaw.

I personally believed that there was absolutely no way that you're going to get a quality tablet for under $200, man was I wrong. I was dead wrong! Overall I'm very satisfied with this tablet and to be honest, the price is a steal, it's really worth more than what it sells for, I'm so glad I asked for this over the Kindle Fire HD. I had second thoughts before I got it but now that it's here in my hands I have absolutely no regrets what so ever! And as someone who has used the ipad 2, ipad 3, HP touchpad, and the kindle fire HD, I can honestly say with an unbiased opinion that you will not regret buying one of these, or giving it to someone as a gift, they'd love it. I would highly recommend this to a friend, it's a quality device for a low price, doesn't get much better than that.

I'll update this review in the future if any thing else comes up that I think you should know about this tablet before purchasing it.

UPDATE#1

I almost returned this.  I got it for the IR remote, which turns out to be a waste of time.  The provided free remote is very limited.  The play store remote is very very very expensive.  I used the trial, and found out the database is limited.  Most of the devices I needed to control by IR are NOT in their database.  But I would not pay the fifty bucks for it anyway,,,,,,the better remote app should be under $20.  There seem to be only two remote apps for it, the provided one for free, and the squid one...which is too expensive, and as I said, limited in database/devices.

The IR feature problem, and the proprietary cable connector took off one star.  I would give it three stars but it is such a good value, I gave it four stars.

Setup was frustrating at first.

1) Be careful about getting the Samsung account.  I did not get the registration email.  Their system is not capable for correcting this.  I had to create another gmail account to use it.
2) Of course, you need a gmail account with payment method attached if you want to use the play store.
3) Don't bother using the amazon app store, as you need to install the app store app to use anything you bought on the amazon store.  Just use play store.
4) Tech support is outsourced out of USA and is totally useless, I found.  It should get one star less for the crummy ignorant and arrogant support, but that is the way of the world for an international company like Samsung.
5) Most apps I use run fine.  Dish, Squeezebox, Kindle reader, cool reader, and many more.
6) Video app built in is better than most.
7) DOes NOT seem to support flash, and I could not get it to load.
8) Works well with the Pogoplug home device.  This allows you to stream video and must, as well as see files on pogoplug device in your home network.  Pogoplug app seems to be ok.  TO stream video you must "optimize" video on the pogoplug (it does that itself, but is VERY slow).  Once the pogoplug optimizes the video, it will play on the Galaxy fine.  You can get pogoplug cloud storage too, cheap, and have all your stuff in the cloud if you can;'t get to your home network stuff.
9) Video and audio quality during playback are fine.
10) Touch screen is very sensitive, but good.
11) You can get spare cables from amazon.  Including a cable that converts to female usb connector.  I think you might be able to use usb flash drives with this.
12)Many cases or covers available.
13) Battery life is ok.  Depends maily on running apps that constantly stay on to access network stuff.  You need a task killer to effectively kill these when not really using them.
Overall for the price, an excellent value.  Worth the extra bucks over the cheaper nasty tablets.
Recommended, overall.

I have ipod touch and Acer tablet 10 inch.  I was looking for something portable yet big enough to read ebooks and do basic web/email and watch videos.  Considering the price and options to add android apps, I decided to get this tablet over Kindle.  It's an okay tablet but not great.  The screen gets dirty faster than the two mobile devices I have.  It's not as vivid as apple products for sure.  Micro SD card expansion is somewhat misleading as the android OS that comes with does not let the tablet to store apps to external SD card.  There's just little over 4 GB space available on internal memory and that's just not enough.  I have some basic apps downloaded and no game apps at all.  And I already filled up more than half of what's available.  So if you're planning to download many apps and videos and magazines, 8GB internal storage is not enough at all.  The expandable micro SC option looks great as if it'll add more storage but it does not work that way at all.  Apps will not be stored in the external SD card at all.  The default apps come with the tablet cannot be deleted and just take up space in the limited memory space.

Also it says it's compatible with Adobe Flash Player.  Adobe apparently has discontinued Flash Player support for newer android OS and this tablet does not come with Adobe Flash Player plug in and does not work.  So that's also misleading.

I hope android will provide its OS updates in near future with an option to store apps to external sd card.  So will adobe with its Flash Player.

I purchased the seven-inch Galaxy Tab 2, with 8 GB storage on board, and an SD memory card with an additional 32 GB.  Of the 8 GB on board, only about 4.5 GB were available, because of space needed by the OS and by preloaded applications.  I thought I would be well off, until I discovered that you cannot install anything to the memory card.  That is, you can't install applications there or move them there.  It's true that you can load your own videos or music there by using perhaps file transfer from your computer.  But the apps have to be able to recognize data there.  Direct downloads to the device will usually go into on board storage.  Only a few apps are set up to write their data where you wish.  For example, you can stream your Amazon MP3 music from the cloud; but if you ask the Amazon app to download any of your items, you have no choice as to where they will go.
As I understand it, this is a limitation of the Android operating system, and has been true for the last few versions.  And there is apparently no way around this.  So this is not the fault of Samsung, but it certainly reduces the appeal of the Galaxy Tab 2, which is otherwise an attractive and well-performing unit.

This is a well-crafted and well-engineered device, but I returned it for a refund because of the following:

The navigation function is useless because it is tied to Google Maps, which cannot be used offline (i.e. without an active Internet connection).  This is due to a bug, that Google has been aware of for more than a year, which prevents mapping data from being downloaded to the device for offline use.

Many of the applications, including the main user interface for the device, include a clause in the user agreement that permits access to ANY AND ALL ACCOUNTS AND FILES stored on the device, and may be used to gather information and to send emails to your contacts "...without your knowledge or consent."

Let me start off by saying, I am an Android fan. I own a Samsung Galaxy S II phone and am eagerly looking forward to buying the S IV once it is out. So, when I got the Galaxy Tab 2 (7 inch) in a deal on purchase of Samsung 46-inch Smart LED TV I was pretty excited about it. However, upon using it for a day or so, I had no choice but to return it for a refund.

The Wi-Fi receiver is extremely defective. It needs the signal to be at full strength to open web pages. If the signal drops even to 3/4th of full strength, it won't open the lightest of web pages (e.g. Google). It will simply show "loading" and will eventually time-out. I did some research of my own and found a number of hits for "Galaxy Tab 2 Weak Wi-Fi", one of the first links is actually an Amazon link: http://www.amazon.com/Did-they-ever-fix-WiFi/forum/Fx2OE7QX73W89HA/Tx2WVDVZLKXZDGM/1?asin=B007P4VOWC and the answer to that question is NO. Then you have the "death grip" issue - hold the tab on the bottom left corner (where the Wi-Fi antenna is located) and see the signal strength drop before your eyes. I even tried following some of the suggestions which point to adding the Wi-Fi network manually instead of auto-detect and that did not help either.

Finally, I had to call up Amazon tech support, who were very helpful but they basically ran through the same set of troubleshooting tips I mentioned above. They also pointed to the death grip issue and the manual network addition. They also mentioned that the Wi-Fi problem was a known issue with Galaxy Tab 2. As a result, I had no option but to request a refund.

The only reason I gave a 2-star rating is because I didn't "hate" the product. For someone who is willing to ignore the Wi-Fi issue, this is a fantastic product. For me, I can't always be standing next to my wireless router. In my opinion, it kind of beats the whole purpose of having a tablet and a wireless router, especially when my iPad 2 can do a much better job at receiving signal and rendering web pages at more than acceptable speeds. And it is 2 years old!

This review is on the Samsung Galaxy Tab2 tablet but as the Android OS is the only OS choice I must consider OS issues as a part of the overall review. Samsung has done an excellent job making this quality tablet for a good price. The quality of the materials and finish are excellent. It gives me a high degree of confidence that this will work for a long time and provide me real-world usefulness. Onscreen typing compared to smaller devices is good. Thumb typing is very easy to manage with this size and actually it's easier to be accurate.

The larger screen size is a huge improvement over smaller smartphone sizes screen for everything, especially photos and video. I think the 10" screen model would be just as useful if you need bigger but this 7 inch model is very mobile and still fits in a pocket. The screen resolution is very sharp and crisp but not useable in direct sunlight at all. Keep the brightness turned down to get the 4+ hours of battery time. The processor is quick to load and refresh for Internet browsing. Zooming and moving around standard websites is quite acceptable, quick and easy to do. The 32gb micro card accessory included provides lots of storage.  Using the "two finger" touch and squeeze motion makes zooming in and out very easy. The one finger flicking to move around pages includes acceleration with faster flicks and stops on a dime with a soft touch. Streaming video content such as an HD streaming movie is awesome and quite adequate. The speakers sound surprisingly good. Streaming via WiFi is as fast as my desktop anywhere you have a WiFi connection.

If you're thinking you can use it for office software, it can be done to a point but still no contest to a desktop or laptop. The facial recognition method to login needs lots of light to work well. It comes with the Polaris Office app that has wordprocessing, a spreadsheet, and presentation software. It does recognize Microsoft file extensions but not macros. It also has built in GPS. Downloadable Google maps of the USA stored locally on the devices storage makes turn by turn directions available without the WiFi connection.

I do think the onscreen keyboard needs to be more like a real keyboard. At least put the @ on the main layout. When typing a web or email address the keyboard wants to insert a space after every dot, so a backspace is necessary to remove extra spaces for it to work. As my very first tablet ever, and as a very first time Android OS user (not a smartphone user), I am quite pleased with the device overall. Getting proficient on the operating system is a big challenge because it comes with very minimal documentation and help systems.

Not sure if I just got a bad unit or what, but 3 days after I had it the tablet would no longer take a charge or turn on.  On the bright side the return process couldn't have been easier. Amazon sent me a prepaid shipping label (I printed it out) and a week later I had a full refund. Way to go Amazon!

This is my first tablet device. I wanted something affordable (but not from some unheard-of mystery manufacturer) and this seemed ideal. At the current Amazon price ($180) I think you'd be hard pressed to find anything better. For that kind of money I wouldn't lose too much sleep if something awful happened to it...I'd just buy a new one! It might not be as high-spec as a $500 device, but it does the job. Minor complaint is that the cord on the charger is a little short, which is a pain if the battery's dead and you need to use it while charging. My only other gripe is that a lot of TV streaming services work only in "landscape" format, with the tablet held horizontally, but the speakers are on the bottom edge, so stereo is impossible! The sound all comes out of the right hand side!! I'm sure this probably applies to most (perhaps even all) tablets, but it's a really dumb design mistake in my opinion. On a similar note, it would make sense to have the volume control reversed when using it horizontally...so that you press the left hand side to lower the volume, right hand side to raise it. Maybe someone at Samsung will read this review and take note! :-)
DON'T waste your money on anything else.  Get this tablet.  Great clarity, speed and easy to use.  Great value for the price.

*** The Positives:

When I powered this thing on... What a beautiful display!! It is lovely.  No wonder S^MSUNG is taking over the TV display market.

The Android operating system is the best.  I guess I am personally biased toward Android because the HTC Incredible got me hooked on the simplicity and openness of the OS.  From the main screen there are five panes you can access with a slider, if you are familiar with how the Androids operate.

*** The Negatives:

Right out of the box, I had a sinking feeling when I saw the other end of the USB charger/data cable had a S^AMSUNG connector on it instead of a micro-USB. I can see it now.  I go off on a trip and I have not packed that specific cable for the Tab. I can't get that cable at Target or Radio Shack!! I have to get it from... S^AMSUNG. It will not get to me from S^MSUNG before I have to go back home or go off to the next destination of my trip. If I had wanted stupid charger/connector hassles like that, then I would have gotten an Apple iPad with it's confusing array of which-generation-connector-goes-with-which-generation-iPad conundrum. OR I would have gotten a BlackBerry Playbook (*giggle*) where the Playbook insists on having the charger's data pins shorted to permit the power pins to charge the Playbook's battery! I kept that sinking feeling about the Tab pushed down in my heart, because I was trying SO HARD to rationalize being able to keep this neat device with it's beautiful display.

Next con: When the Display Brightness is set on "Auto" the display is constantly set to be too dim for whatever the lighting conditions are. Manually adjusting it is easy enough, but why can't I set it to *automatically* adjust to how bright I want it to be? Also, when the Display Brightness is set to "Auto", whatever the Tab does to set the backlighting down to it's too dim setting, well that just makes the backlighting flicker. It's annoying!

The con that broke the camel's back: The micro-SD card would not stay in the micro-SD card slot!  Was it the plastic-snappy-hinge-door that was supposed to keep the micro-SD card in place? It didn't. If I put some finger pressure on the closed plastic-snappy-hinge-door while my 32GB niblet was in there, a display at the top of the (beautiful) screen would say "Preparing SD card". But the instant I took my finger away from the plastic-snappy-hinge-door, the status at the top of the (still) beautiful screen would tell me that the "SD card was unexpectedly removed!"  When I called the 1-800-SAMSUNG support line to resolve this problem the troubleshooter did determine that I had not installed the card correctly. I had not pushed the micro-SD card in far enough. HOWEVER, to push the micro-SD card in far enough, I would "have to use a gemclip or a safety pin to carefully push" the outer edge of the micro-SD card into the Tab deep past the plastic of the slot until it went "click". I successfully tried this and the micro-SD card worked in the micro-SD slot. An optimist might say, "Well! Now that you have that there micro-jobber clicked into yer hoo-hah-hole just right, ya might never have to mess with it ever again! :-D " To which I say ripping movies for long trips, transfering other bits of data, video and pictures to and from the Tab is going to be a constant battle with micro-SD micro-card micro-slot micro-surgery with the S^MSUNG-recommended "gemclip or a safety pin". (For younger readers: The "gemclip" is an archaic metalic wire device old-timers used to use to hold paper documents together before the "floppy disc" came along. The advent of the "floppy disc" in the late 1970's and early 1980's effectively banned the easily magnetized "gemclip" from the office because those "gemclips'" magnetic force would erase devastating amounts of kilobytes from the said floppy discs.) (Also for the younger readers: The "safety pin" is another metallic wire device used in the 1950's and 1960's to cinch the waist of a cloth diaper onto a baby's butt.)  I guess I was just hoping to be able to change micro-SD cards with my standard-issue hands, the way I do with my phone, camera, handheld scanner and every other device I use that requires memory! Every time I go on a trip, I will not think to pack a gemclip, nor shall I pack a safety pin! I don't even have these things from 3 to 6 decades ago IN MY HOUSE! AND I'M A BIT OF A PACKRAT!!!! So... I micro-extracted my micro-card, went to my Amazon account and clicked "return".

Bottom line: Beautiful display, but there are a lot of gaffes in the Galaxy Tab's design which were going to be so annoying in the years of ownership to come.  If you are seriously considering this Tab, make sure my three cons, which were evident on the first day out of the box, are not a concern for you.

The screen has a slim bezel but not so slim there's nothing to hold onto.  The screen does attract fingerprints on the black bezel but there's a white model floating around if that really bothers you.  It runs a recent version of Android 4.1.x which gives it the performance updates of "Jellybean" Android.  This model is also the GT-P3113 version.  This model has the integrated IR repeater in the side of the unit. It also comes preloaded with remote control software.  Its a neat idea and as a remote its much more useful than what $200 bucks will normally buy you in the custom remote scene.

I did purchase the 8GB model.  It only has about half of that usable after the OS is loaded.  The advantage of the Samsung over other models (Asus Nexus 7) is it will allow for a 32gb micro SD card to be plugged in the side.  You can store all sorts of movies on 32gb and then swap them out as much as possible.

The screen isn't "retina display" crisp, but it also doesn't cost what an iPad costs and the iPad Mini doesn't have retina display anyways.  I only mention that because inevitably someone will look to compare the two.  If you're already bought into the Android ecosystem with an Android phone this a great addition.  If you have a Samsung TV or really any TV that has published IR codes you can impress your friends a family with your new cool Samsung Tablet remote control.  If you want a versatile e-reader with the huge Android ecosystem back-end, this device makes much more sense than a Kindle Fire HD or Nook HD.

Samsung is a force to be reckoned with in the android market. I have purchased a Nexus 7 which has a much smoother user experience, and a beautiful design, but it does not beat the Samsung Tab 2 7 and here is why:

1. The Samsung device allows for removable sd cards. This takes away all of the storage issues that tablets have. I have a bunch of digital videos and music that I can watch or listen to just by swapping out micro SD cards. Granted Samsung should have given the device 16GB of internal stroage instead of 8GB, but the micro SD cards make this a non issue.

2. Unlike the other 7" android tablets like the Nexus and the Kindle this has a camera on the back which allows you to take decent videos and pictures. The picture quality is pretty good, but not great (I consider my iPhone 4 great in this area). It makes the tablet a very handy device for when you are traveling and want to take pictures and videos. I use it to shoot videos for my children when I am in Europe on business trips. This feature piggy backs on reason 1 listed above becasue you can save your video and pictures directly to the micro SD card.

3. It has excellent video playback, gaming and web surfing.

4. You can use it as a remote control for your TV and Cable Box. I can not tell you how liberating it is not to have to look for a remote control.

The only thing that the device is missing is an mini hdmi out, and the reading experience could be a bit better. If you are buying a 7" tablet to primarily read e-books then go with the Kindle Fire HD 7", but if you want a full fledged device with full access to the android ecosystem then go with the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7". The Nexus 7 has a cleaner design, and much better user experience (swiping is effortless) but they hobbled the device by copying the iPhone model of not allowing for external storage, yeah... yeah.... yeah I know about USB OTG, but it too clunky to have something sticking out the bottom of such a small tablet.

The bottom line is that this is the best value in 7" tablets!

Display - 3.5/5 - This is probably its biggest weakness.  It's more than adequate, but it won't amaze you.  Both the Nexus and Fire HD have it beat here.  It won't blow you away but it does what it needs to.

I love this tablet! I purchased two right after the new year and they have been going strong since. Maybe that seems crazy, but I've heard some horror stories about off-brand tablets becoming crap within a few weeks. This tablet has a lot of internal memory and runs android. The battery keeps its charge well, and I haven't had any issues with playback of movies or music, and it plays apps perfectly. I have probably downloaded approximately 20 apps and the system hasn't slowed at all. The WiFi works well, when I take it away from home and come back, it is almost instantaneously picking up the signal. It almost never loses the connection, even when my ps3 or my laptop do.

If you are looking to buy a tablet and you aren't sure which one to buy; decide what you want it to do first. Are you working or playing? Are you familiar with android or mac? Android is super easy to use, and the app store is very extensive, with tons of free apps. You need to decide how much you want to spend, long term. Apple products may be top-of-the-line, but they are priced accordingly, and so are their warranties, if you want one. Even after your initial purchase, you will still have to buy a case, possibly you might need a memory card, or a replacement power cord, and you might not want to pay $50-100. If you decide you want to go with android, now you have a variety of choices. Your first consideration should be WHICH version of android you want. This Samsung runs 4.1.1, but I've seen lots of off-brand that only have 2.1, and that OS came out a few years ago. The higher the number, the newer the OS and the better your tablet will work, and run apps especially. I don't recommend the 2.1, I used to have it on my phone and you can't save apps to external storage. At the very least, look for 2.3. There's also the kindle to consider, they run a certain android OS that has been modified for Amazon, and has exclusive rights on new adobe flash software. This is a definite perk for the kindle, but it was still out of my price range. Plus, while it can be so upsetting to miss out on the random flash ads (haha), the Samsung still plays videos from the internet just fine, as well as several different kinds of video files downloaded from a computer to the external card.

After looking at the OS, you need to decide how much internal memory you want. The literal total for the Samsung is 4.49 gb. Of which I still have 2.90 gb free. Now, I am using 1 whole gb for apps, but I mostly play games and they can be large, and when you have this much memory, you don't have to constantly move them to your external card. I could potentially get a lot of that space back if I wanted to.  Having enough internal memory is VERY IMPORTANT;  you will want to throw your tablet in the street and crush it with your car if you don't have enough. It will constantly tell you that the storage is low, and you won't be able to even update your current apps. I would say, depending on your usage plans, you will want at least, AT LEAST,  2 gb, but even that's on the low side. If you are going to read, play games, and be on the internet a lot, you will want more.

Next, decide how big you want this sucker to be. I love this 7 inch tablet, and I wouldn't want a larger one. Yet again it depends on what you want it for. I like that I can just throw this in my purse or school bag. The 10 inch ones are too big for my tastes.

After these major considerations, here's the other thing about tablet buying that you may want to think about. My girlfriend received an off brand tablet for Christmas, and we looked, and looked, and looked for a good case for it. Nada. There are so many different tablets out now, a saturated market, while the accessories are about as easy to find as water in the desert; if you don't have a Kindle, an iPad, or a Nook. This may sound crazy, but in the end, what made me get this tablet was the fact that I could get a good, solid case made specifically for it, at a reasonable price. I was not going to spend several hundred (I bought 2, remember) dollars on tablets, only to break mine within a week. I'm a huge klutz, so I have to think ahead. This is a great tablet, I highly recommend it!

Unfortunately anyone considering this device should Google-search the term "Issue 36993:  wifi no longer working in ics 4.0.4 " or simply "galaxy wifi authentication failed".  Essentially at this time you may find yourself without any option to connect to the internet. In other words, a pretty useless paper weight.

The various forums have several threads on the topic where users, including IT professionals, who own android devices are reporting the problem and not finding a solution or work around. Typical posts from the above read:
* "just signed a 2 year contract. Had I known about this issue I never would have committed my two years to this device. Now Im stuck."
* "I am too extremely frustrated that for $700 i have a piece of plastic doing a half job... simply unaccceptable.  Google needs to push some kind of update ASAP and start treating the android project seriously..."
* "Huge problem!!!! Bought 2 galaxy 3's and a galaxy tab 10.1 2 all with no ability to connect WiFi!! This is unacceptable!!!"

A bug in Android, introduced in v4.0.4 and persisiting through the latest Android v4.1.2, prevents android devices from connecting to many, mainstream, wifi routers. If your home/office router is one of those, tough luck.  Users have these routers working fine with all non-android devices (ie iOS, Windows...). Also, many Galaxy devices (including mine) worked fine up to the v4.0.4 upgrade.

Personally I had been an advocate of the Samsung Google product family.  However the lack of networking functionality, and lack of communication by these companies in the several months of this issue persisting should be unacceptable and potential consumers here should be aware and beware.

I started looking for a replacement for my 2 year old B&N NOOK Color a couple of weeks ago. One local store had the Nexus 7 and this Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0. Another store had the Acer Iconia A110. My choice was between these 3. I will begin with the one that I first rejected.

Nexus 7 - The Nexus 7 was perhaps the best compromise of the 3, but the large number of reviews on many shopping sites that described problems and poor support from Asus and Google made me eventually eliminate it. I liked the better screen resolution and the speed with the quad core processor, but no microSD slot and the reported problems and failures kicked it out as a choice. I didn't want to take a chance of getting a bad one and I didn't want to have to open it up to fix loose screws and such.

Acer Iconia A110 - This one could have easily been my final pick, but the screen knocked it off. Just a relatively small amount of offset from straight on and the screen dimmed. It not only dimmed, but the colors also changed, which I read is common with TN screens. My 2 year old NOOK has a better screen in my opinion. It had the same quad core processor as the Nexus 7 and the same lower screen resolution as the Tab 2 7.0, so it was in the middle as far as those attributes. It also has a microSD slot.

Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 - The Tab 2 falls short of the Nexus 7 in the processor and screen resolution. However, the Quadrant score is not that much slower than the Nexus 7. In one review site comparison, the Nexus 7 had a quadrant score of 3501, while the Tab 2 had a score of 2840. After loading all of my apps, I ran Quadrant twice and the lowest score that I got on my new Tab 2 was 3131. Not enough of a difference to matter. I found rooted NOOK Color reviews and they got Quadrant scores of around 950, so the Tab 2 is a big improvement over that.

The Tab 2 has the following advantages over the others:
- The screen is better than the Acer and even slightly better than the Nexus, even though the Nexus has a better resolution.
- It has the memory expansion that the Nexus doesn't.
- It has the best speakers by a small amount.
- I managed to get it for slightly less cost than the other 2, but that didn't factor in my choice.

Even though I don't plan on using the Bluetooth capability, I will have to pair one of my headphones to see if it works.

Some people like the simpleness of stock Android, but I actually prefer the added features of Samsung's Touch Wiz. I'd prefer not having the added Samsung apps, but I will just have to ignore them. I don't want to root the tablet, as I will probably just brick it.

Update 2 days later: I mated my old Motorola S305 stereo headphones fine and they worked with no problems. I discovered that I had a long unused microSD - 256MB. I plugged it in and tried to load some photos using AirDroid and AirDroid would not find the external card. A Google search found that this is a problem with AirDroid with Jelly Bean, so not a tablet problem. I installed the wifi file transfer app and was easily able to transfer files to the external card. It's not quite as nice as AirDroid, but it works fine. I'm still waiting for the microSDHC and the OTG cable.

Update 5 days later: I received the microSDHC and OTG cable. No problem with either. I used to OTG cable to mount a USB flash drive and a mouse. Both worked with no problem.

Update 7 days later: I almost forgot about the GPS function. I just turned GPS on for the first time and loaded the GPS Status app. I'm impressed. It quickly (about 1 minute) found and locked onto 16 satellites while in the house. By comparison, my HTC Incredible 2 phone found no satellites in the same time and finally locked on to only 9 before fluttering between 7 and 9. I don't think that I have ever seen either my old Droid or my current Incredible 2 ever get near locking onto 16 satellites, even outdoors.

I bought this for a recent vacation to Cancun. I wanted to be able to read and watch movies on the plane, read at the beach, check email occasionally and check my favorite websites. And I wanted to be able to do all of this without lugging around the books, magazines and a laptop for the whole week. I used to have an android phone so it was all very easy to figure out how to use. I chose the Galaxy Tab from all of the android tablets out there for 3 reasons, 1-Samsung makes a good product and 2- the external microSD storage and 3- for use with my SmartTV.
The built in memory is only 8GB so I threw in a 16GB microSD and (foolishly) thought I basically have 24GB of memory. Here comes big drawback number 1... the external memory can only be used for pictures and videos taken with the built-in camera. There is an app that will allow some apps to be saved to the SD but I was hoping I'd be able to download movies to the SD. I'm going to assume its my fault for not researching that further before purchase. Maybe there is a way to do it and I haven't figured it out yet but I kinda doubt it. I was able to download 4 movies to the device but when I went to install a game I purchased I found I was out of memory.
Big drawback number 2- with the Galaxy Tab you have the Samsung App Store, the Google Play store and the Amazon App store to find your entertainments... the problem is the 3 of these combined are woefully inferior to the selection available from Apple Apps & iTunes (especially for movies & magazines).

(I've also put this review under the Kindle Fire HD)  I'm not one to typically write reviews but since I spent a long time researching the right tablet for our family I thought I'd give my opinion.  First, the main use for our tablet was for the kids to play apps (fun and educational) and watch movies/shows.  I wanted to be able to download movies/shows so they could watch them on the plane or if we didn't have wifi access  I also plan to use it for books for them and me.  I have other Apple products but didn't want to spend the money on something that the kids would primarily be using.  With that said I narrowed my purchase down to the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 and the Kindle Fire HD.  I actually bought both and tried both for a few days.  I read many reviews and most said to go with the Galaxy.  BUT, in the end I liked the Kindle Fire HD much better and here were my reasons:
1.  I thought the screen quality was better on the Kindle Fire HD (it is amazing!!!).
2.  The screen size was a little wider.
3.  The interface was much more user friendly with the Kindle.
4.  I'm a big Amazon Shopper and it just made more sense to go with the Kindle plus I plan to keep the Prime Membership up after the trial.  Like that you can borrow a book a month, get free streaming of tons of shows and movies, free 2 day shipping), lots of free books.
5.  Supposedly there are many less Amazon apps than on Google Play but this has not been an issue with us at all.  All the apps we want are available on the Amazon store.
6.  The big seller for me was the 16 gb internal memory versus 8 gb for the Galaxy.  Also, in reality the Galaxy only has 4 gb internal memory because half it taken up already by the operating system and other stuff that is loaded that you can't delete.  I do understand that there is the option to get an external SD card and in fact I have one but, FIRST, you can't store any apps on it only photos and movies, SECOND, it is a royal pain to transfer stuff to the extSD Card (you have to plug the tablet into the computer, transfer the files onto the computer and then put them back onto the tablet into the extSD card section.  Weird!)
7.  So, even though the Kindle Fire HD with 16 gb is really only about 13 gb I like the fact that it has almost 3 times more internal memory
8.  The Kindle felt of high quality build.
9.  I have family members with the Kindle so we can share some books (not as many as we hoped but still a neat feature).
10.  Battery Life better with the Kindle Fire HD.
11.  Sound better too with Kindle.

So, these are my 2 cents for what it's worth.  I liked the Samsung Galaxy but I loved the Kindle Fire HD for what we wanted to use a tablet for.  Happy shopping.  I don't think you will be disappointed with either one!

Overall, this is a great tablet, and I'd recommend it to anyone who wants a quality Android tablet.

Recently there was an article in the "New York Times" cautioning buyers of tablets to try them in the store "hands on" before making a decision. When purchasing my Galaxy Tab 2 I didn't. I also was not paying much attention to its features (or lack thereof). Here is what I have learned after three month's use. This is my first tablet and for the most part I think it is terrific. Because I have an aversion to Apple's business model and because I have found that the many Samsung products I own are of excellent quality, the Tab 2 was my obvious choice. In addition I have three year's experience with the Android OS and expected the learning curve to be substantially shorter. It was. The 7" screen is the perfect size. I can't imagine how I would navigate the 10". What I wish I had been paying attention to are: 1) This tablet was engineered for right handed people. This makes perfect sense since most of the world is right handed. Unfortunately I am not. 2) There is noSamsung Galaxy Tab 2 (7-Inch, Wi-Fi) flash which means that for all practical purposes snaps are limited to those taken in bright light. Goodness knows there is plenty of room on the back of the unit for a flash. 3) The buttons on the right side are a design disaster. The top one turns the screen or the tablet on and off. Right below it is a rocker switch to control the volume. Their feel to the touch is exactly the same. Good luck on being able to tell instantaneously which switch your finger is touching. The obvious answer would have been to put the On/Off switch on the top of the tablet. 4) The socket for connecting the tablet to the world or the charger is on the bottom. If you plan on lying in bed with the tablet in the vertical position resting on your belly it can't be done without seriously bending the cable. There seems to be plenty of room on the left side of the tablet. I purchased the Samsung 2 7" Wifi Tablet in November. I am reasonably happy with my $199 purchase. Because there are now so many choices at the lower end of the price range it means that it is going to be more difficult to give them a hands on try. That being the case, make very sure you can return your purchase if you try it out and are disappointed. Good luck - but caveat emptor.

My first tablet was Acer A500 10 inch tablet.  It still runs well but I'm starting to find the weight was starting to bother my wrist after extended use.  I have checked several 7 inch tablet models (Apple, Nexus 7, IBM etc.,) and decided to take chance on Samsung 7 inch tablet.  Because several early reviewers have posted issue with battery/charge problems, I have hedged my bet by ordering from Costco due to its very generous return policy of 90 days.

As tablet goes, set-ups are pretty straight forward, I activated Google and Samsung accounts and the tablet was set to go.  As others have already noted, this tablet comes with paltry 8GB of internal memories with half of it already taken over by bloatware.  It can however, take 32GB micro-SD card so that helps to store your video, e-books any download you will inevitably do.

Some reviewers have complained of having issues with wi-fi connectivity depending on how you hold the tablet.  I have had no problems here.  Signal reception was excellent both at free wi-fi spot at Kaiser Hospital and my home wi-fi network.

Anyone who have owned android smartphone and tablets should have no problems playing around with this toy.  The screen is veritable fingerprint magnet so I have ordered screen protectors which I will apply as soon as it arrives.

If you try to read in bright sunlight....well, good luck.  But indoor, it is pleasure to use.  It may not have the best screen but I found it more than adequate when compared to my old Acer 10 inch.

Battey life is not the best.  If you do not have power-saving features on and you have wi-fi enabled, you can almost see the battery drain noticeably.

In closing, I picked Samsung 7 inch Galaxy Tablet 2 for its low price, ability to accept external memory card, decent screen and light weight.  I am not a power gamer so not having the latest CPU is not an issue for me.

If I have issue with battery/charge down the road, then I will do an update.

UPDATE:  03/05/13

I've noticed that on some website, Samsung installed browser may give you problem with accessing.  If so, install another browser like Opera portable and access problem will go away.

When two of my children's offbrand tablets malfunctioned within the warranty period and that other manufacturer wouldnt even answer the phone, we bought two more of these samsung units to replace the offbrand units.  The children love them.

We use them for e-readers, using kindle app, fbreader and adobe reader.  We use them for offline gps with gps copilot. We use them for educational purposes with multiple language and drawing apps.  I use mine for work both as a toolset and administrative assistant.

The biggest drawbacks we have found so far, other than having to use power save mode all the time and gps causing fast power drain without external power, come from android 4.1.1 and are generic to all units running this release, but are only minor issues. IIRC, samsung has already released 4.1.2 in several countries but continues to hold north america to older software.  Android no longer allows for the moving of apps to the expansion card via settings and app developers have yet to "pick up the slack."  On apps that can be manually modified to do so, config files have to be found and corrected and relevant folders have to be manually moved.  This isn't something the average user wants to be bothered with. Jelly bean 4.1.1 seems to want to reboot on rare occasions that appear to be with moving large quantities of files, and it is difficult to remove bloatware, requiring a 3rd party app that can perform "rooted" tasks or can bypass that need. One samsung specific quirk that I don't like is the proprietary usb connection on the device.  If the usb cable messes up, it will be a pain to replace it.  This also limits connectability flexibility when trying to connect to devices with a micro usb slot.

Pros:
Dual cure processor, 1gb ram, 32gb expansion
Lightning fast gps tracking, bluetooth, wifi
E-reader compact size
Functional flexibiliy
Economical price

Cons:
Must be run in power save mode AND airplanemode for optimal battery performance
Even with external power, the gps function will slowly drain power.
Android 4.1.1 specific glitches and bloatware.
Proprietary usb slot on device
Storage limits for the technically illiterate.

Summary:
Great unit with just a few drawbacks that can be worked around.  Biggest drawbacks are usb slot/cable, battery consumption when using gps or communications features and issues specific to android 4.1.1 that will hopefully be fixed with the eventual update.  But if you tend to download a lot of apps and don't want to be bothered with manually configuring them to use the expansion sd card, then you may want a different unit with 64gb of internal storage instead.  However, if this unit withstands the test of time then I will be extremely pleased.

Here in brief is the Kindle HD vs Samsung Tab2 Comparison.
I bought this Samsung after a lot of thinking about maybe getting a new Kindle HD where the Samsung seemed to be a little better and after few days of use here is my thoughts:

Comparisons between Samsung Tab and Kindle Fire HD:

1- Kindle has a better and friendlier User Interface than the Samsung, specially for Novices and Kids. Easier Navigation and switching between apps.
2- Kindle has a more sensitive and receptive touchscreen, it seems that I have to push the screen several times sometimes for the Samsung to respond.
3- Samsung have a better App Store(Google) compared to the Amazon.
4- Samsung can have a SD drive added.
5- Samsung has back and Front Camera, Kindle just front.
6- Samsung has less memory(8GB, 4.5 usable), Kindle starts with 16GB.
7- Kindle processor is 1.2G while the Samsung is only 1GHz.
8- Samsung seems to get a little sluggish at times specially when opening several apps in a row where never had that issue with the kindle, maybe because the kindle will not allow apps to continue running in background after closing them.
9- Seems that the battery life is a little better with the Kindle.
10- Kindle does not come with a charger(Ridiculous!) and alot of complaints of ads while using Kindle.
11- Amazon customer service is superb, I don't think anyone beats them.
12- Samsung has GPS, not the kindle.
13- Kindle has hDMI output, not the Samsung.
14- Samsung measured usable Ram is around 700MB and not 1GB.
15- Same Price.
16- Amazon Video Library and access is great, Parental control is great. Don't think Samsung has a Parental control and still haven't used their video library and to see if u can download bought movies to watch later?!
17- Samsung options and settings are more versatile and editable for the experienced than the Kindle.
18- Battery life is worse for the Samsung compared to kindle, 6 hours on continuous use.
19- Samsung Tab Glass is NOT Gorrila Glass, Broke after a drop, Kindle took alot more beating and no scratch.

So far, Seems the Kindle might have been a better option but not sure, I'll keep the Samsung for now and update this review as things change.

I bought this tablet for my 14 year old son for Christmas.  I purchased it mostly because it resembled my galaxy smartphone and figured it would be easy to set up for him and use.  So far, it has been great.  I have had no complaints from him about it so far....he spends most of his afternoon and weekends using it for movies, games and google searching.  Now that he is back in school, I am sure it will help him with homework as well.  I couldn't be happier.

To be fair,  this is my first tablet purchase so my review is not relative to any other tablet options.  However,  I do consider myself a tech junkie and did a good bit of research before my purchase.

My motivation for buying a tablet was to make my job easier.  I'm an outside sales representative and meet with many clients in their homes or businesses.  I needed a tablet that had a rear facing camera,  expandable storage, and blue tooth capabilities.

I thought I had found the perfect tablet,  and had until I tried to print.  When I'm meeting with clients,  I need to print contracts,  product literature, financial information, etc.  Normally,  I do this from my laptop to my blue tooth portable printer.

However,  carrying a laptop can be cumbersome and time consuming to set up.  The Galaxy Tab 2 was the perfect solution,  except that you can only print to a Samsung printer!  Yes, there are apps that allows you to print to other printers,  but only via wifi.  Blue tooth printing, however, is limited to Samsung only.

I realize my application is very specific, and not likely to be an issue to many others.  So,  to be fair, it seems to accomplish other tasks admirably.  My daughter plays games on it.  I've watched a few YouTube videos and music sounds great through the speakers.

So, all in all, a good tablet but the printing limitations are a deal-breaker for me.

***  Edited Review - a follow-up comment to my review suggested an app that may work for Bluetooth printing.  IT WORKED!!  I'm beyond relieved that this tablet will do the job.  I'm changing my review to 5 stars.  At this price point, and with the ability to run my business through this tablet, there's nothing more I could ask for.

Pros:
In comparison with the iPad, I find it quite useful if not more so.  For one thing I was able to get it to print to my Epson R2000 since it was on my network. With about 8 hours daily use it would be good to plug it in for the night for an overnight charge.  One of the biggest pros to me is the remote app that you can use to program all your devices in your home (bye bye Harmony!)

Cons:
The only thing I can think of is the fact that the antenna is not that strong.  I was in a hotel and easily picked up the wireless with my laptop. With this unit it seemed a bit more difficult.  This seems to be a problem with many tablet devices. But while in my home it does just fine.

Conclusion:
Pound for pound this unit will hold it own with the iPad ver 2. But with the cost in the equation, this wins out big. Especially with the remote app.  Now I just have to figure out away to get it from my daughter. ;)

I've owned or worked with 4 different 7" Android OS tablets.  When choosing a tablet it's all about what you will use it for. I like the Acer Iconia A110 the most because it has the most "utility". It's sort of the jack of all trades of these devices. It may not do anything the best but it can do the most. I hope that makes sense. I hope my review will help you choose your tablet.  Here's the comparisons

Acer Iconia A110 - $199
Pros - GPS, HDMI Out, Micro SD card slot, Google Play
Cons - Screen Resolution 1024 x 600, Speed is just a tad bit slower than the others,the device is physically thicker and more bulky than the others.
Notes: This would be a 5 star product if it had a better screen. Only 8GB internal storage without adding a micro SD card. I am able to stream amazon flash based videos by downloading a different browser than the stock chrome. This device runs Android OS 4.1 (Jelly Bean)

Kindle Fire HD - $199
Pros - Performance Speed, HDMI Out, Amazon Instant Video, Screen Resolution 1280 x 800
Cons - No GPS, No Micro SD Card Slot, No Android Market/Google Play (Amazon Market only by default), Have to purchase wall charger separately, Layout isn't the standard Android OS GUI. Amazon has created their own UI.
Notes: Excellent product but the lack of GPS and micro sd card slot is disappointing. The amazon based apps (kindle books & video etc..) have a wonderful UI in comparison to the other 3 devices. 16GB internal storage for the same price as the others is better value. This device is very "sleek" This device runs Android OS 4.0 (Ice Cream Sandwich) under the Amazon Kindle GUI.

Google Nexus 7 - $199
Pros - Performance Speed, GPS, Screen Resolution 1280 x 800, Google Play
Cons - No Micro SD card Slot No HDMI Out
Notes: Great product would easily be the best unit if they added HDMI out and a micro sd card slot. This device has 16GBs of storage like the Kindle Fire HD. This devices runs Android 4.1 (Jelly Bean) by default.

Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 - $199
Pros - Performance Speed, GPS, Micro SD Card Slot, Google Play
Cons - Screen Resolution 1024 x 600, No HDMI Out (they make a hdmi out adapter for the other galaxy tab/note models but not for the 7").
Notes: Only 8GBs of internal storage like the Acer Iconia A110. This device runs Android OS 4.0 (Ice Cream Sandwich) by default.  For me not having HDMI out is the killer.

I own an original Galaxy Tab 7" wifi and the new Galaxy Tab 2 7" wifi, and honestly, I have to say the old one is better in almost every respect.

Pros:
*The GTab 2 is lighter, faster, thinner, and has slightly louder speakers.
*Runs Android 4.0 and the screen is very pretty.
*Has all the features you'd expect... with one glaring exception (See below).
*Since it has a newer version of Android, it works with Bluetooth keyboards and HID devices.

Cons:
*The camera is horrible compared to the old one. It doesn't auto-focus, has no flash, has worse resolution, and you can't use it to scan barcodes (which I did a lot with my old GTab). I loved using the flash LED as a flashlight, too... works so much better than using the whole screen. I wish they would have left the camera alone, I would have paid the money for it.
*The WiFi antenna is situated so that if you hold it upright with your left hand, WiFi reception is almost nothing. Hold it with the other hand (on the other side), it works perfectly. Why is it like this? The old GTab never did this.
*When connected to a non-Windows computer, it won't let you connect as USB storage. Very frustrating, I can't just plug it in and copy files to it like my old one.
*The auto-dim screen feature seems to always make it darker than it needs to be. I'm always finding myself turning auto-dim off because I just can't read the screen. Old one wasn't like this.

My opinion:
If I had known the camera was so bad on this, I wouldn't have bought it, even at the low price I got it for. I used the camera  for close-up photos, some low-light shots, and scanning barcodes... none of which the GTab 2 can do. At first I like this little tablet. I do like the size and the processor seems to be quick enough. The original Android build and Samsung software was nice. Half the available storage is taken up and hidden by the Samsung software, but i put in an SD card and since I only bought this to do Android development with the storage was fine. The size is really nice and has made me think that I'd really like the Note II. It's smaller than my iPad and is easy the take off to meetings (unfortunately the poor WiFi renders it useless). The screen looks nice - though not nearly as good as my iPad.

However, the WiFi radio on this device is so weak as to be unacceptable. I wrote a Java RTSP library to stream video from IP cameras. When I took this tablet into the office I found that the range limitation was so short I simply could not demonstrate the application unless standing virtually right next to the WiFi router. All other devices had no issues with coverage - iPhones, laptops, iPads, etc.

The camera is also of such poor quality that some barcode scanning prototyping I was working on never has worked. In fact while Scanlife can generally scan EZScan codes, other scan software simply won't focus sufficiently to read the "UPC" codes on products. Even "normal" pictures never seem to be in sharp focus.

Finally, the touchscreen does not seem to be responsive. I'v found that I have to be very careful with my aim when pressing the menu buttons at the bottom of the screen and it often takes 3 or 4 tries to actually click the button.

Overall I'm disappointed with this device. From what I have read this WiFi only version is very cheapened down - people that have the version with 3g say their WiFi works just fine.

Like the Nexus 7, this seems to have me a bit undecided on whether this or the Nexus 7 makes the best 7 inch tablet for Android. This falls behind the Nexus in specs, but makes up for it in other features like TouchWiz, the IR remote, and expandable memory. The one major drawback for me is that this particular model is limted to the 8gb memory capacity (with the exception of the student addition which I can't find anywhere anymore, but even that's limited at 16 gb). Something like this, I feel, should be at a minimum of 16 gb with an option for 32 gb. If it was a 32gb one, I'd choose this one in a heartbeat over the Nexus 7, but because it's lacking that memory, it's a toss up between this and the Nexus 7.

To give a little bit more background information:

I started off with a Galaxy Note 10.1 tablet and loved it so much that I wanted another Samsung tablet that was smaller in size for portability. I figured that besides specs, the only way the Tab 2 would fall behind its big brother the Note 10.1 would be that it lacks the S-Pen. So I bought it (sadly, I paid like $200 or $250 and a month or so later, I saw the price for this model drop to about $149). When I got the device, I saw that it performed much slower than the Note 10.1, which was expected. However, it was still a sweet device with the ability to use front and rear cameras, edit documents, enjoy the Android app store (Google Play), and so forth.

But with my usage (pictures, movies, video games, apps), it filled up too fast. Of the 8gb, I think you only get to use 5 or 4 and a half, so you're pretty much restricted to space. If you're using it just for things like email, streaming video (YouTube, Netflix, Hulu, etc.), and for surfing the web with the occasional app or game download, then this should be perfect. But if you're going to use it for all those functions in addition to things like downloading games (esp. the high memory games), apps, and so forth, then you might want to look elsewhere for a device with more memory.

While you can use the micro SD card with this device, it does not allow you to transfer apps to it as older Android phones and tablets would let you. But you can still transfer documents, PDF files, songs and stored videos to the card to lighten the load on the device. That helps out tremendously, especially if you have enough songs to take up a gig of storage, videos to take up the same amount of space, and a bunch of documents like textbooks for school. But you still have to limit your app selection to just a couple of games (if they're big ones), and apps.

Ultimately, I found it a very useful device, but the storage limitations had me look elsewhere for a 7 inch device (I settled on the Nexus 7, 32 gb and with better specs but lacking Samsung's lovely TouchWiz that makes using the device such a pleasant experience). As for the Tab 2, I didn't return it. I felt it was still a great device. So now I downloaded an app designed for parents to customize the user experience on it that way my son can play his games and watch his videos and read his books on it when we're traveling or at the doctor's office, etc. It still sees a lot of use, just not by me.

I would definitely recommend this tablet, but would also advise people to be cautious of memory usage. Many people don't need that much memory and can be fine with a couple of games or a few heavy apps and use it without any problems. It definitely beats most of the competition with the exception of its main rival, the Nexus 7. It wins out over the Kindle Fire HD easily (which I also own), and the Nook Tablet (which I sold due to the lack of apps available for it). Keep in mind, this review is coming from someone who likes to download apps for all sorts of things (games, checkbook, word processors, photo editing, etc.) so this is why it gets a more negative review than others might give it. For the price, however, I'd easily say this is one of the best choices out there and still recommend it for those looking for a great tablet at an affordable price (almost unbeatable price depending on where/when you buy it).

There are two kinds of people in the world... ones that have used smartphones and tablets.. and the ones that haven't. The ones that haven't number enough to fit on the head of a pin. I am one of those people. But FINALLY, I'm making the jump into handheld mobile computing, and this Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 is working out splendidly. So, a few remarks for anyone else just now jumping off the head of that pin into the 21st century... 1) This tablet is awesome. Thumbs up. Absolutely recommend. For the price it is a great value. No reason this should not be a good a choice for newcomers. I figured for $200 if I dump it in a year for something else it would still be a good deal. But I'm sticking with this unit until the technology rolls over (probably about a year ;>). 2) It runs the latest version of the Android operating system. The system is not 'locked' as on other hardware sold with Android such as the Kindle. This means maximum compatibility with the apps you wish to install. And believe me, once you have gotten used to the basic functioning of the tablet, it's ALL about the apps. 3) Tablet/mobile computing is a life changing experience. Mobile computing is nearly as revolutionary as the Internet itself. I would dare say that mobile computing is more useful in your personal day-to-day life than traditional desktop computing. Desktop computing started in the 'Dark Ages' (DOS, early graphical user interfaces), and proceeded to the "Middle Ages' (evolved operating systems, voice recognition, data sharing, etc), but has basically stalled. Portable computing is the evolutionary leap into the 'Renaissance'. Computers are now beginning to behave the way people who know nothing about computers expect computers to behave (more Star Trek like). 4) The 7" form factor is a great size. Not too big. Not too small. I no longer use my iPod Touch to listen to music (except when exercising). I installed the 'TuneSync' app which copied all my iTunes music and playlists to the tablet. And because the tablet is right-sized I tend to take it everywhere. A good portion of the work that used to accomplish on my laptop is performed on the tablet. 5) Accessories purchased: Leather case. Also acts as a backstop to prop the tablet up on a flat surface for hands feww viewing (Poetic Slimbook Leather Case for Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 Black. A memory card to expand storage SanDisk 32 GB Mobile microSDHC Flash Memory Card SDSDQ-032G-AFFP. Both of these have been invaluable. Next purchase will likely be a Bluetooth keyboard. 6) There IS a learning curve. This is a different world from desktop computing. Different interface. Different terms and acronyms. Different mind-set. Although you can somewhat intuitively learn the touch based interface and run apps and even download and install new apps, the process of syncing your desktop data with the tablet (music, images, videos, documents) is a WORK IN PROGRESS. The free Samsung application for its tablets that supposedly helps with this is a bit of a joke (Kies). You are sort of left to develop the wheel on your own, so try and hook up with a kid or someone who has figured out how to set up sync media for your tablet, specifically to the external add-on memory card (where there's more room to put everything). That will save you some headaches. --------------------------------- UPDATE February 22, 2013: Best way to Root Once you get your tablet all set up --which can take many many hours of copying songs, photos, videos, etc., plus downloading and configuring apps, plus futzing with various settings, plus arranging all your icons, plus operating system updates-- you want a way to back up EVERYTHING in case you lose your tablet, or whatever. Unfortunately it seems the native Android operating system running on this tablet does not provide a way to back up EVERYTHING. I tried several apps from the app store, the native Google cloud backup, and the Samsung Kies backup... and none of them backed up EVERYTHING. Each of these apps back up a FEW things. For example, none of them backed up my email account settings. I learned that the only way to get a true, full backup is to "root" your tablet. Rooting simply means gaining full control over the Android OS. Rooting can void your warranty, but not having to spend another couple of days redoing everything (assuming I could even remember everything I did) made it worth rooting my tablet. If you choose to the root route here is the best link I found for doing so after quite a bit of research: Wait... ok, the Amazonian Police have removed the links. Just go to the galaxy-tab2 website (add the c-o-m). That's the ticket. Once you have the tablet rooted you want to do that EVERYTHING backup I keep mentioning. Install a free app called "ROM Manger" from ClockworkMOD, which will back up ALL of the main memory card of the tablet (but not the removable external card). For the procedure google 'nandroid backup galaxy tab 2' and look for the link entitled 'How to Perform a Nandroid Backup and Restore it to your Android'. Another useful [free] backup app good for doing SELECTIVE backups and restores (it's wisest to use both) is 'Titanium Backup'. --------------------------------- UPDATE February 28, 2013: A few good apps Most of the Samsung supplied apps can be replaced with [usually free] more robust counterparts from the google play store. I did the following: The built-in Gallery app for displaying photos and video doesn't allow much flexibility over the sort order of your photos, so I replaced it with Photo Gallery from Fish Bowl Software. The native Google Play Music app is pretty good, but Rocket Music Player from JRT Studio has a few extras like a sleep timer, an indicator of how many songs are in a playlist, and the ability to specify the media folder. I also installed MixZing because it is one of the few players that can display song lyrics imbedded in the music file (as with iTunes). I use iTunes, and a good app for syncing your library to the tablet is TuneSync from Fireleap software ($5.99 for unlimited version). It copies over songs, playlists, and any "meta data" in the song files such as album art and lyrics. A good non-cloud alternative to the stumbly Samsung supplied Kies app for syncing other data from a computer is Cheetah Sync. The free version will sync one folder on the PC to the tablet. For $2.99 you get unlimited folder sync. A stay away from The Cloud as much as possible so this is a rare find. Other nifty apps are Google Sky Map for viewing and identifying stars. 3D Digital Weather Clock displays weather, date, time, moon phase, and battery charge. Nav Free provides turn-by-turn voice prompted navigation without the need for a wifi connection. Handrite Free allows you to take notes by writing on the tablet with a stylus or your finger. The built in Memo app does a good job for typed notes. ListNote let's you speak your memos and converts them to text. Google Translate for speaking sentences you type in a different language. And many many many more...

I was in the market for a tablet for my son. I was considering the Kindle Fire, but then saw the Samsung Tab 2. This is a much more versatile tablet. Looking at the specs, the two are very competitive. However, on closer inspection, the Tab 2 came out the winner. And here's why:

- The Samsung Tab 2 has upgradable storage. I can add up to a 32 GB micro SD card to the Samsung. The Kindle is not upgradable.

- The Samsung Tab 2 has both a front and rear facing camera. If all you want to do is Skype, then the front-facing camera is fine, but if you want to take pictures using the Kindle, good luck.

- The Samsung uses Android Ice Cream Sandwich, and I prefer it to the Kindle's UI. The Kindle seems to use Android apps, but these must be purchased through Amazon's front end. I guess I prefer the versatility of the Samsung App store and Google Play.

- The Samsung uses a "standard" tablet UI environment. This is a minor point, but I like the thought of my son getting used to a more conventional UI, as it will prepare him to use a real tablet in a real world. He's growing up in a world where tablets are commonplace tools. If he learns how to navigate and organize his day using a standard tool, he will be better prepared in tomorrow's world. Again... a small point, but an important one.

Cons:
The Sammy DOES have a proprietary charger as opposed to USB (This is where the Kindle wins). For this reason, I cannot give the Sammy a full 5 stars.
The Sammy also lacks the app time-out feature of the Kindle, which lets parents set time limits on some apps. This is easily accomplished using apps on Google Play, however.

This has happened several times. Upon keeping it plugged in 100% of the time and attempting to boot it up, the tab froze on the battery screen and I sent to Samsung for service. As it turns out, the tab needed a new motherboard (which seems pretty significant for a brand new item--maybe it was a fluke, who knows). I'm going to try to make this concise and hit the major points, so it will help all you tablet-seekers make an informed decision before you finish your x-mas shopping.

About me: 30s, non-technie, don't care one way or the other about gadgets. I do have an iPod touch, which I love, but the screen is simply too small for me to do a lot of things I wanted to do with the tablet.

What I use the Galaxy Tab for: E-mails while traveling, Netflix, e-books/audio books, apps.

Since I've never had a tablet before, some of these things may be typical of all tablets or unique to the Samsung. In any event, here are my pros and cons:

Pros:
+Vibrant screen, easy to watch movies, read, and use apps
+Touch is, for the most part very responsive (see my comment below)
+Easy to navigate the unit despite never using an Android device before
+Battery life is impressive, even after watching movies or reading for several hours
+Easy to get accessories for (case/stand/usb keyboard)
+Optional 32G SD card, which you pop right in and forget about
+Price: with the exception of all of the additions you will need (case, memory card, extra charger, etc.) it cost the same as my iPod touch with much more functionality/features
+Weight: perfect for travel, lightweight yet sturdy (I even take it to the gym and use it on the elliptical machine)
+GPS!

Cons:
-The WiFi signal seems inconsistent. Not that it's bad, but hovers around average, even if I'm near my router
-Links on the internet are sometimes not responsive to touch. Not sure if that is the browser or the websites themselves
-Netflix can be laggy, especially when it buffers
-This is a major one for me...the volume rocker and the power button are nearly on top of each other. I'm not very tactile so almost every time I go to adjust the volume I inadvertently turn the screen off. Really annoying but I'm sure I'll get the hang of it
-Android apps require a ton of permissions. As in, they basically tell you how they are going to invade your privacy. Maybe iOS apps do this too and they just don't tell you. I also don't like that a lot of apps require full-time access to the internet

In sum: for the difference in price I would definitely choose this tablet over a knock-off in the $100 range. it is a user-friendly, fully-functional, and handy accessory for travel or anyone "on the go". The only thing I would consider upgrading is possibly to a bigger screen, but then you sacrifice weight and portability factors.

Happy holidays!

Now, I know a lot of this is my own damn fault for thinking back to when it was newly advertised and not checking into what people's experiences have been so far; a lot of my problems also result from Amazon themselves, and from third parties.  I just don't want people to make the mistake I did - I'm not whining about it, not asking for my money back, just letting people know what they are NOT going to be able to do with this device.

First, the good parts is that it's a nice tablet and, with the price drop, a pretty nice deal.  There are a lot of reviews covering the good points - I find the screen crisp and responsive (although I haven't yet put a protector on it); wifi speed is great - can stream netflix and looks pretty good.  As a device to replace a lot of what I was using my phone for (besides "phone" things), this tablet is really quite nice - it's a pleasure web surfing and using email compared to a phone screen, and it's got decent processing speed and plays games quite nicely.  Decent display for reading, although I personally still prefer e-ink for reading.

But I'm disappointed in what I'm not able to do with it; the Galaxy Tab 2 10.1 can do video output - this can't.  I was hoping to hook it up to the TV in my exercise room to watch while working out, but no dice... not even SD.

On top of that, I recently signed up for Amazon Prime... but you cannot stream video from Amazon to this device - it was part of the reason I signed up for prime.  This is not a flaw of the device, but of Amazon - an artificial barrier, seeing as how you can play streaming content on "blessed" android devices.

As a side note, in trying to bypass using an app for Amazon streaming by accessing it on the web, we find out that Adobe no longer makes a compatible flash player for the latest versions of Android.  If you download a browser, like Dolphin or Firefox, that has built in flash, Amazon still claims the device is not compatible.

Again - it's not flaws of the device, really, but it limits what you can do with it, and I just wanted to throw it out there that other Galaxy's - the Tab 2 10.1, the old 7.0, the 7.0 plus - all have features and abilities this tablet does not have.  Yes, they cost more, but examine whether it's worth it for you before buying this one.  As I write this, the Galaxy 2 10.1 is actually a really great price given the much larger size - and for some reason it can output video while this one can't (you'd think it'd be essentially the same exact thing except for screen size, but no).

I don't know how this next one compares to other tablets - but on my phone I can move downloaded apps to the SD card.  At 8MB, being one of the lower memory tablets available, I got mine along with a microSD card to save on device space, but it doesn't allow me to move apps to the SD card.

So it's a decent tablet, but given some of the other great deals available right now you should think of other options.  If you're willing to go even higher, I bought the wife and kids 7.0 pluses last year and they are pretty happy with them (still no Amazon instant video, though); they are far superior, but of course also far more costly.  If you think video output or Amazon instant video might be interesting, I implore you to examine other tablets and do the research on them.

When I finally decided to buy a tablet, I literally spent days researching everything that was out there.  For the price and features, the absolutely best deal is the Kindle Fire HD 7", which I bought and love.  Unfortunately, the Kindle does not have Adobe Flash Player and it cannot be installed on the Kindle.  Since one of the primary reasons I wanted a tablet was to access websites that require Adobe Flash Player, I found the need to purchase another tablet.  From my previous research, the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 had been my second choice, again for the price and features it offered.  The Galaxy Tab is exactly what I needed and performs flawlessly!  I love this tablet and recommend it for anyone who wants a small tablet that can do just about anything you want it to.  The price is excellent and the compact size makes it extremely versatile.  I can take it anywhere as it fits very nicely in my purse, even with the case on it.

Additionally, for those who need a tablet with Adobe Flash Player, this is the only tablet on the market that comes pre-loaded with AFP.  As of 08/15/12, Adobe is no longer producing AFP for Android systems and it is not available to download.  So, if you do not have it pre-loaded you will not be able to get it.  This may or may not be of consequence to you, but if it is then please take advantage of the days I spent researching all of this information.  For more information, please follow this link:  [...] OR do a search for Adobe Flash Player for Android and choose the "Android's Flash Player is dead - live with it|ZDNet published on August 15, 2012 by David Meyer.

The Galaxy Tab is the only tablet in the $200 to $250 price range that has AFP.  I did not research the higher-end tablets since I had decided this was the maximum I was willing to spend.  I also did not research the lower-end tablets, under $150, as the majority of them have older operating systems like 2.2 or 2.3 and are only 4GB.  Technology continues to change too fast to spend any more money, in my opinion, as it will be obsolete in a very short period of time.

In closing, the Samsung Galaxy Tab is an awesome little piece of technology that I am sure you will thoroughly enjoy owning.

I was recently gifted this tablet as a replacement for another tablet my cat felt the need to destroy. Initial impression was good - Nothing was broken or missing, no dead pixels, no screen flickering or nonexistent battery life.
