The screen is adequate - Not the best, but not even approaching bad. The tablet feels very solid, like a piece of equipment rather than a toy. Touchscreen is responsive, smooth, and hasn't lagged at all. 'Tis a fingerprint magnet, but that ought to be obvious.

The cameras are nothing to get excited about, but are neat to have. The speakers are probably one of my favorite parts of this tablet - While they aren't front-facing, neither are they on the back of the thing - They're located on the bottom edge, and louder than I expected.

Wifi is functional, with range on par with that of my phone (Samsung Infuse). Bluetooth works fine, with no complaints.

Battery life is pretty decent, and it charges quickly. The Micro SD slot works fine, and the cover fits perfectly. Haven't used the IR, so I can't comment on that.

Overall, I love this thing. While it certainly isn't the most powerful or shiny tablet out there, it is far, far more than enough for $199. My single complaint - and not about the tablet itself - is the charging cord. I don't mind it being Samsung's proprietary cable, but the thing is friggin' short. I can work around it, but it's still mildly annoying.

The Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 is the first Android device I have ever owned.  I wouldn't say that I'm vehemently Apple-oriented, because my phone is still a Blackberry, but I am rather attached to my iPod touch.  I was pretty sure nothing could replace it.  I've owned both an iPad and a Kindle Fire, and as loyal as I am to Amazon, I gave my Kindle Fire to my son.  I really didn't like the user interface of the Fire, or not being able to run HBOGo, and I hated not being able to run Flash on my iPad.

So, I went shopping around.  When the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 came up for sale, a colleague and I went in halves for one.  We both wanted to try it, and decided that this would be the best way.  When it came, I had a bit of a ride on the learning curve, but after that, I found that I loved the platform.  Using, downloading, and installing apps/widgets is easy, uninstalling is also easy - the process is not difficult to find.  Email was a breeze to set up, and I now have shortcuts for 3 different email accounts.  Facebook and Twitter work flawlessly, and all the apps I bought when I had a Kindle Fire are available to me here.

I was a bit concerned about my iTunes music.  I have a lot of classical music, and I wanted it available to me.  Google Play made that incredibly easy.  I still use my Amazon Cloud Player, which works great, and I downloaded and installed Dropbox so I can now share files much more easily between devices than I could before.

I know that some people are descrying the fact that you can't save apps to the SD card.  Not an issue for me, as I am not a terribly heavy app user.  I have my favorite few, and that works for me.  I will probably get an SD card for pictures and music, so I don't think I will have to worry about device space being an issue.

The 7 inch size is perfect.  I hated the iPad - it was too big, but the Galaxy Tab's size is great.  Battery life has also been good.

I'm really pleased with my purchase, and my Tab 2 has replaced my iPod touch.  For everything.  Thanks, Samsung (and Amazon!)

I love Samsung products, so I got this tablet over the weekend from a local store. From first impression it was lovely. I did a couple of Android updates and it was good to go for me. Will use it mainly while I'm on the go to enjoy the Android experience.

I generally like this tab. Has the latest Android OS, responds fast, offers multiple options. It seems, though, that most satisfied users compare this tab to a Kindle. I don't own a Kindle. But I do own an Acer Iconia which, performance-wise, supersedes the Galaxy Tab 7.0 even a year after it was released.
The reason I took the first star off is that ostensibly this Tab comes with 8GB - it's advertised as such, and says so on the box. However, what it does not say is that it most of its internal memory is taken up by the system and by numerous preloaded application that you can't get rid of. What you have out of the box is barely 4 GB of memory available for your use. If you think that's enough, think again.
ALL of the apps that you plan to download to your new pretty Galaxy are programed to go to your internal memory, and there is no option in the settings that allow you to move the app to your SD card. Samsung opted to label the internal memory as "SDcard" and the external memory as "extSDcard." So not only do your apps go straight to your internal precious memory (of which you only have 4gb to begin with), all the data that's generated by that app also goes to the internal memory. The only thing that's possible to use out of external SD is media - videos and pictures.  Games, offline maps, word processing apps - all go to internal memory. I contacted Samsung on this before I bought the devise as I saw couple of users mentioning it here on Amazon. After 30 min of conversation with sales person and a TECH (!) department I was assured that I can move the apps to the external memory card. That's the reason for taking off a second star - incompetent customer service. I should have read reviews on Samsung website - all this was discussed by users there.
Don't know if I'll keep it, aside from the above reasons the Tab is fine, especially at this price point.

I am what you would call a power user. I was looking for a 7 inch tablet after using and returning an ASUS Transformer due to its size and lack of video codecs. I needed a small tablet to read books, surf the web, play games, take class notes, and watch videos. After being disappointed at the Amazon locked Kindle Fire, not wanting to pay a high premium for an iPad, and the Nexus 7 lacking an expandable storage option, I found the Tab 2 7.0 a worthy tablet that hits all the points important to me.

- Affordable. After being released at a good price of $250 this tablet has hit the magical $199 price point shipped on Amazon. An amazing price for what you get.

- Launched with Android 4.0.4 but now has Android 4.1 Jelly Bean! This update has made the tablet quicker and much more responsive due to Project Butter. The layout has changed and is now more consistent between different devices. Google Apps are updated with better performance. Google Now shows cards based on your location and your Google searches. A much need update has breathed new life into this tablet. Update is available automatically on start up or via Settings, Software, Software Update.

- Battery Life and Performance. I easily get 6.5 hours of "on screen time" for heavy use and have gone a couple of days without needing a charge. Over 8 hours for video (will vary due to brightness). An excellent duration. YMMV. With a TI OMAP 4430 Dual Core Processor, Performance is good. It is an older processor to keep the price low but is more than capable of running this tablet. No issues. Power Saver Mode provides longer battery without any noticeable decrease in performance. Brightness is allowed to be much darker than normal. Good for night reading.

- Expandable Storage. With 8GB of internal storage and about half user-accessible, expandable storage is important for those with a big library of music and videos. I can store all my shows and movies on any size microSD. The tablet also plays MKVs, Xvid, and other important video formats with srt embedded or external subs support in the default Video Player and MX Player. Tested 720p. I am currently using a 16GB microSD Class 10 card.

- Features. WiFi, Bluetooth, GPS, Front and Rear Cameras(Google Hangout is great), Good Dual Core Processor (TI OMAP 4430), 1 GB RAM, 4.5GB user accessible internal memory for apps, microSD Slot, and an IR Blaster (Peel App controls my TV and DVR flawlessly(Samsung HDTV + RCN Motorola DVR)).

- The Tablet. Great build. Good screen at 7" and 1024 by 600 resolution. Easy to hold. Lightweight.

The cons that are easily overlooked
- Proprietary charge cable (prefer microUSB)
- Camera quality is not very good (I would never use a tablet as a camera... Good for QR Codes and video chat though!)

Like I said this tablet hits all the points important to me. Couldn't ask for a more balanced tablet in terms of hardware, software, price, and features. At $199 as of Jan 16, 2012, I highly recommend this tablet.

This is my 2nd "touch' device after my iPod Touch 4gen and it has certainly been a learning experience. A few negatives future buyers might like to know:

What $199 does get you vs. some other $199 devices:
A functioning GPS (no GPS antennae in the $299 iPod Touch 5 or $199 Kindle Fire HD); a wall plug ($20 extra for KF HD); a rear camera and microSD slot (not on either KF HD or Google Nexus)

iOS 5.0 vs Android 4.0.4:

There are several apps missing I would like as everyone has noted elsewhere, and the "same' apps don't all work the same. Pros
- Great form factor. Easy to carry and hold in one hand for extended periods of time.
- Excellent resolution for reading newspapers/books, listening to podcasts or watching downloaded movies.
- Battery charge is great - gives me about 6 hours of reading time.

Neutral
- Samsung's Kies application is a good first attempt to access your tablet from a browser on your PC - similar to how you control IPad through ITunes. One big limitation is it does not let you manage your apps (add, delete, move screens, etc).
- Pairs nicely with other samsung products - Blue Ray player, TV - but works mostly as a remote.

Cons
- You can spend money and buy an SD-Card but you can't really use it with this tablet. There is no way to move apps from internal memory to SD-Card, download videos directly on your tab to the external SD-Card. What's the point of the Lobotomized SD-Card then? Nice design decision, Samsung. Kudos to the product manager.

Recommendations to Samsung
- Allow the external SD-Card to be used as an extension of internal storage.
- Allow watching whatever is on your screen on the tablet on TV or Blue Ray player. Extend the interaction between the products. Will be great if that's done as an app/firmware update on Samsung devices - wishful thinking?

Both are great and I highly recommend this edition if you can find it.

I agonized comparing this to the Fire HD and Nexus 7.  Recognizing each has pluses and minuses, I finally made the plunge with the Galaxy Tab and am glad I did.  It is everything I wanted in a tablet

To put my review in perspective, I didn't want a tablet for playing games, viewing movies, listening to music, or mainly shopping.  I wanted a lightweight piece of hardware that would allow me to access the internet, as well as maintain my calendar, contacts, to-do lists, and other general "workhorse" tasks.  The Galaxy Tab does all of this amazingly and as I've found, far more.

The Good:
1. It has the best calendar program I've ever used (including Palm, Apple, Google).
2. The display, though less than its competition, is clear and adequate for my purposes.
3. Battery life has been great, and I've been putting it through its paces.  As other reviewers note, you have to be mindful of what's running.  The Tab allows killing programs easily, turning WiFi and Bluetooth on and off quickly, and generally tweaking to your heart's content.
4. Navigation is fantastic and fully customizable.
5. Touch is for the most part, responsive (see below for so-so.)
6. It has voice dictation that is highly accurate and makes composing emails, searches, etc. very easy.  It's not perfect but then again, neither is Dragon.
7. WiFi performance has been excellent.  I'm not sure why some reviewers have had problems but I haven't.  At home, on the train, and at work, this has picked up, identified, and connected quickly, and maintained the connection even with weak signals.
8. The customizable universal remote is FANTASTIC.  I am having so much fun with it.  It's not perfect but it's good enough.
9. I was worried about performance given that the processor is lower speed than its competition and only dual core.  Also, this is the older version of the Android OS.  My fears were unfounded.  This has performed quickly and responsively with everything I've thrown at it, including real multi-tasking.
10. The USB dongle included in this edition is also great.  I've moved files and so far, avoided having to get a micro-SD card.
11. Though I keep thinking I should have gone for the 16 GB version, so far, I haven't eaten away that much of the storage.  And I see the micro-SD as a solution should I need more.
12. I've accessed my entire Kindle library and the entire Android market with ease.  The Tab holds its own to the competition.
13. Internet usage is smooth, fast, and I haven't experienced any clipping.
14. It reads and allows editing of MS Office products admirably, as well as reading pdf's.

The So-So:
1. Touch response is usually fast but sometimes lags.  I've found that sometimes it's because my other hand is overlying the screen somewhat, but there are occasions where I have to keep tapping.
2. The feel of the screen is dampened by a plastic overlay, so this lacks the smoothness of moving your fingers over true glass.
3. The overlay is a true fingerprint magnet.
4. The camera isn't that great (haven't used it for Skype yet) but this isn't what I want in a tablet anyway.
5. No manual on the device.  I personally don't tend to read them and enjoy finding my way around hardware and software but others might be daunted.  The manual is available on Samsung's website (and other reviewers have given links in this forum) but it would have been nice if they had included it.

The Bad:
1. As others have noted, placement of some icons, and particularly with the keyboard, are awkward.  I've taken too many screenshots with the camera than I care to admit.
2. Syncing software with their calendar and Outlook proper (not Exchange) would be great but is absent.  There are low cost options in the Android market but then you lose Galaxy's wonderful calendar (I think - I haven't bought any syncing software yet.)

With this market, the Galaxy Tab is fast becoming "old" but I think it is a very viable choice.  My review may be too late to the party, but I'm so in love with it, I thought it proper to put it in writing.

UPDATE 10-18-2012
Still loving it.  Maybe even more.  My two "Bad" comments above have been addressed. Taking inadvertent pics with the camera from the bottom screen has been fixed as you can program that area to do other things.  And Samsung's own "Kies" software syncs its wonderful calendar with Outlook!

The only hiccup I've experienced is that it sometimes chokes a little on large pdf's (such as the electronic manual to this).  But other pdf's don't faze it at all.

Oh, and for me, the battery life is great.  But I practice conservation: shutting down apps I'm not using, turning off wifi when in sleep mode, etc..

I was primarily looking for an e-reader but got talked into this tablet by the salesperson due to all of it's capabilities.  I've regretted this decision daily.

This tablet was released in a time when the market was hungry for a cheap-yet-decent tablet experience. You were either stuck buying a crappy Vizio (or other value brand) tablet, the locked-down Kindle Fire, or spending huge wads of cash on a 10-inch device that was clumsy and bulky to hold. Samsung apparently saw the market niche and jumped on it.

This is not a premium tablet. Instead it's targeted at people who want a "good enough" tablet experience while keeping a reasonable price point. There's some tasks the tablet is "good enough" for, and other tasks that some people might find lacking.

I primarily use this thing to read books and watch YouTube and Netflix in bed. The 7-inch screen is totally suitable when your face is close to it (much less eye-strain than trying to watch extended video playback on the 4-inch screen of a smartphone). I've spent many blissfully relaxed hours watching stuff on this tablet, with the added ego boost of knowing it's much more electrically efficient than watching the same content on my desktop computer.

Less frequently I use the tablet for listening to music (media players are a joy to use on the bigger-than-a-smartphone screen, with the album art showing up huge and pretty), web browsing (Google News and articles on various sites), online chat (through IRC an client), and all the other uses you'd expect to get out of an Android device. Email, social networks, image browsing, screwing around with the camera for the lulz, etc etc etc.

There are a two minor flaws I've noticed. The stock web browser seems a bit laggy and buggy at times and the music player occasionally suffers brief hiccups in playback, though this may have been fixed in a software update, as I haven't heard this problem recently. On that note, Samsung has been supporting this product really well. For the 3-4 months since I've gotten it, I think the device has received.... five software updates? It's always nice to see a manufacturer standing behind a product post-sale.

So, the verdict. It's not a premium device, but it is excellent for the price, and good enough for my tablet needs. Even as it's made depreciated by newer 7-inch tablets, I plan on using it and loving it for a long time yet.

While I understand loud noise can certainly damage your hearing, I doubt if many people are in danger of doing this with their mid sized tablets.

Vs. the Original Fire

I bought this with the first week of its release, and I preordered the fire, what I'm saying is, I have extensive experience with both... And because of that I don't understand the comparisons people are drawing. The Fire was never meant to be a full range experience, it's meant to be an ereader that handles color pictures. The fact amazon decided to add in web surfing or netflix support was them just testing the water. They didn't expect the tablet to sell like it did, and they didn't intend for people to use them the way they are.

This on the other hand is a legitimate tablet, in a seven inch formfactor. You can read the specs, I'm not going to type them out again. But the web browsing is quick, I've only had one issue with firefox on it, and I simply reinstalled, not another issue since, using iSyncr I loaded it with all my playlists and top rated songs (wirelessly), the newest iteration of iSyncr even records your playcounts. The offline GPS function of google maps has not worked once on here, but tethered it works fine. I have synced with multiple bluetooth devices, and it handles swapping  between them MUCH better than my Galaxy SII. The only real problem I have with it, is that samsung backed it up with complete trash for peripherals. Do not buy the samsung car stands or any of that stuff, there are plenty of bundles and alternatives by third parties (which I have reviewed) that work very, very well in comparison.

Vs. the Nexus

I'm an ASUS fanboy, I love their components, but the omission of the mSD slot in the feature list for the GNexus is what made me grab this one and cancel my GNexus preorder. However, I recently spent the entire day with the two side by side, and I can tell you empirically that any differences are subjective interpretations. The screens are not so different that your eyes will melt, the speeds of function are not so different that you'll rue the day you paid for a samsung product, and when you start showing off all the content you have stored locally, the opposition gets sad... especially when you bring up how much youtube content is blocked to mobile browsing.

In my opinion, the SGT7 is a clear victor here. I didn't walk away wish I'd bought a nexus, in fact I drove away with my SGT7 in the windshield clamp jamming to music off it and a giant smile on my face.

The bottom line from my perspective is this:

If you want a seven incher, that will handle all your basic media consumption and net needs, plus a few other things, this is it.

It's also worth noting that Polaris office (which comes preinstalled) is the best MS office alternative offered for ANY tablet device.

I was excited about it for the first few weeks, but I've run into a number of limitations that have me questioning this purchase:

What's the point of a 32GB SD card? Photos? Unfortunately, that doesn't really work either. They both run variations of Ubuntu (Linux) but this device will not mount no matter what I try (and I've tried lots of options offered by the internet). I've downloaded drivers for the MTS mounting system, switched USB debugging on and off, and tried connecting it as a camera. No dice. Can't connect. Can't transfer files. I bought this device for the smaller form factor and to avoid the Apple walled garden, but it seems just as bad (if not worse) on the Samsung side of the fence. Booo. I was recently in the market for a small tablet and had to make a choice between the Galaxy Tab 2.0 7-inch and the new Google/Asus Nexus 7.  I chose the Galaxy for 2 main reasons:
 - Expandable memory
 - Rear-facing camera (with video)

My use for a tablet is primarily for checking e-mail and Web browsing throughout the house (much more portable and quicker to use than a laptop).

For me, having a camera is useful for those times when the tablet is closer/quicker than hunting down the digital camera, or for quickly taking a picture and posting it online.  There are also some apps that make use of the onboard camera, and having a rear-facing camera allows you to point the camera and see (on the screen) what it's looking at.

The expandible memory is a nice-to-have but hasn't been an issue so far.  If I start putting lots of music or videos on it, being able to add a 32GB memory card is going to be helpful.

The one big benefit that the Nexus has is that it comes with Android 4.1 (Jelly Bean) out of the box.  I'm hopeful that my Galaxy Tab will eventually get 4.1 (it came with 4.0, Ice Cream Sandwich), but it's no guarantee.  But even with 4.0, the interface looks great and is speedy and responsive.

As for the Galaxy Tab itself, it's been an outstanding device.  It comes with great apps, easily integrates with the Google Play store, and easily syncs up with both my Yahoo and Google accounts.  Web browsing is great, and the few games I've installed have worked perfectly.  A video chat I tried with Google Hangouts worked seamlessly.  I even recently tried the audio input (you talk, it types what you say) and was surprised at how well it worked.

Unfortunately, it won't let you print to anything but a Samsung printer - so I have to go back to my main computer in order to print an e-mail or a map.

Overall, a great tablet that I would recommend.

Caveat 1: This is my first "Smart" device. My phone makes phone calls, that is all. Caveat 2: This is my first exposure to Android.

When I discovered that Samsung was making a mid-sized pad with WiFi and GPS, for under $250, I was delighted. This seemed to be able to fulfill so many of my desires, including two big needs-- A mid sized pad for use with Skeye, an amazing and completely unique astronomy app, and a highly configurable GPS that was big enough to use in the car yet could still fit in the pocket of my hiking shorts. (Note that a WiFi IPad cannot do GPS or Skeye, and besides it is too big and expensive.)

These two functions work great (for the most part--see below about screen) and alone make the device worth the price, but of course it does much more that is useful. I really liked that it could accommodate an external memory card to enhance the limited on-board memory, although this turned out to be mostly bogus, as apps cannot be put on the external SD card, due to terrible limitations in the Android operating system.

For the first week it worked perfectly. By the second week the software was extensively corrupted. By the third week I had to "wipe" the memory and start over. This was very disturbing. But as far as I can tell, this is the weakness of Android, not a hardware issue. Fortunately, as "wiping" appears to be routinely required on Android devices, it is well supported and implemented. Many of the weaknesses of this device (corruptibility, many very buggy apps, poor memory management, crippled external SD card) are due to Android and it's wild-west ecosystem, not Samsung.

But there are hardware issues too. The cameras are really poor, and no autofocus to boot. Makes many potentially useful applications useless.  The main camera is said to be 3.2 mp, but has the resolution of a 1 mp camera at best.  This is an area where Samsung really cut corners. My son has a fancy ASUS pad and the camera is 10x better, at least.  The Sammy can't read barcodes, or work as a document scanner or as a text translator, because it doesn't focus that close. Sharpness is terrible at any distance. The main camera is not a real camera, think of it as a web-cam for Skyping (backwards) or spying on your babysitter, that is all it is useful for.

The screen is good, but it lacks the brightness to easily use it as an in-car GPS in the daytime--too bad.  The position of the face-facing camera is not the best, at least when used in landscape mode--it is designed to be used in the portrait position only. In terms of processor speed and internet download speed, it is about where you would think for $250--good, but not up there with the big boys. Internet download speed is 3/4 of my sons high priced ASUS pad (I got 15 mbps, the ASUS was 20 on the same wifi and network), overall speed is about 40% but raw processor speed is ~25%. For me, this is fast enough, but probably some people will think otherwise.

Battery life is good but not great--when semi-frequently used as a GPS during the day, with the screen at maximum brightness, it barely lasted the day. For most uses battery capacity is adequate, however. Sound is not bad for such a device, better than I had expected, but it can't really produce sounds under about 400 hz (no big surprise). WiFi reception is good, but not quite as good as higher end products I have tested--certainly adequate most of the time. GPS works very well indeed, every bit as good as the higher end products I have benchmarked it against. It lacks a gyro, and therefore the functionality that a gyro provides (whatever that might be!).

The wall charger that came with the Sammy appears to be a standard USB type, so I thought I could recharge the Sammy by plugging just the cord into the Belkin USB voltage charger I have in the car for use with my IPod, but it did not appear to work. I need to try again to verify this issue, but if this is a voltage mismatch issue, it is very inconvenient and a very odd decision by Samsung. Maybe the Belkin device doesn't produce enough current? Even with a strong magnifying glass, I cannot read the microscopic text describing the voltage/amperage output on the side of the Samsung charger!

If a much better device comes out for under $350, I would consider upgrading to get a real camera and brighter screen and a real external SD card slot. Right now, no such product exists on the market in this size/price.  On paper, there is no advantage with the Google Nexus 7, only downside. Maybe the hyped Apple Minipad, but I doubt it will meet my basic needs as described in the beginning of this review. So overall, I do like this device and will keep it (3 months return policy at COSTCO), but with a bit more refinement of hardware and software, this could be the Dream Device I have been anticipating for almost 20 years. It falls somewhat short of that at this stage, however.

Now, nearly three weeks after I sent my device in to Samsung for repair, I find out that my device will not be repaired.  My device will be exchanged; apparently there would be a long delay waiting for parts to repair my device.  I've spoken with a few very nice ladies at Samsung this evening.  They're all pleasant, all very apologetic, and can't really give me a definitive answer on when I'll receive a replacement device.  The third young lady I spoke with this evening was very pleasant, very professional, and did seem interested in trying to find answers for me...unfortunately it seems that another department has to call me to discuss the exchange of my device. I was told that it should take another 11-12 days for the process to be completed.  I'm just having a hard time understanding how, 3-4 days after you've determined that you cannot repair a customer's device and you're going to exchange it, how can it take nearly two more weeks to resolve this?  I could understand a situation like this if I had an older unit, out of warranty, and they were doing me a favor.  How can you drag out the repair or replacement of a new unit and call that customer service?  How can you drag a customer through so much bureaucracy and expect that they'll be a happy customer and want to continue to purchase your products?

I bought this for my wife for a gift and she has really enjoyed it.  She had mentioned wanting to get an ereader recently, but I thought this might be a better option.  We were already familiar with Android from our HTC phones, so there was only a small learning curve with the quirks of Android 4.0 and Samsung's UI.  After setting up Nook and the rest of our apps, she was off and running.  One of the nice features that I hadn't really considered that she is enjoying quite a bit is the DNLA capability to stream music from our PC to the tablet.

The device performs great, and my wife almost always turns to her tablet over her phone now.  Very responsive, and the battery lasts for a long time.

Now I want a tablet too...

Overview:

I am very happy with the Tab and use it daily for many things.  The highest praise I can give is that my wife is jealous of it.  But you have to go into it with reasonable expectations - if you compare it to an iPad you are likely to be disappointed.  I had no previous experience with an iPad, other than testing it an an Apple store, or any smartphone, so the capabilities were a revelation to me.  I chose it primarily because of the price and size - the iPad seemed too big and heavy for use as a book and magazine reader, and I did not want a phone with a monthly payment.  The Tab is comfortable to use standing on the Metro, on airplanes or lying down on the couch.  Others have complained that it is laggy, but I don't find this a big problem.  Like others I have found that it can be difficult to press the right button, especially in apps where the buttons are closely spaced, but somehow over time this has ceased to be an issue for me.  Typing with two thumbs is easy and responsive, especially in portrait mode.  Caveat: the market for small tablets is changing rapidly, with Google's Nexus, new flavors of Kindle Fire, and a rumored mini-iPad in the offing, so the competitiveness of this device is up in the air - it will have to evolve to stay viable.

Specifics:

1. Reading books:  I chose this over the Kindle Fire and BN Nook because I did not want to be tied to one vendor and wanted a more open Android experience.  I do not regret this.  I also considered some e-ink readers, but have not found any problems with eyestrain reading the LCD screen and can read in sunlight to a degree if I crank up the brightness.

2. Reading magazines and pdfs: I chose the Tab over an e-ink reader in part because I wanted to read media other than books.  This works well despite the small screen size.  While not optimal for 8.5x11 or A4 size pages, expanding 2-fold by tapping or pinch-and-zoom is available in most magazine and pdf apps and is good enough.  I mainly use Zinio for magazines and repli-go pdf reader for pdfs, which in addition make it easy to jump around in long documents.

3. Camera: Specs are not impressive, but I have found it quite useful for close-up photos like portrait shots.  The convenience of having it on a device I often carry with me anyway and direct upload to Dropbox or Picasa make it preferable to a stand-alone camera.

4. Web browsing and email:  A great convenience to have on-the-go or when you want to look up something in a book.  For serious usage, I still prefer my laptop.

5. Calendar: Sync with my Google calendar is very handy.  Again, for serious usage, a laptop is better.

6. Storage: I don't store movies or much music so even the 8 GB on board (4.59 GB usable) is adequate, but I bought a 32 GB micro SD card for extra space (and a bargain at $20 plus shipping).  Most apps can't use it, so it is not a complete solution, but it is a convenient place to stash photos and documents that are not tied to a dedicated app.

7. Battery life: As advertised if you limit Wi-fi use, Bluetooth, and GPS to when you need them.  It also helps to keep the screen brightness down as this is the main power hog.

I received my Galaxy 2 7" tablet right before Memorial Day. I liked the device itself when I purchased it. It had a micro SD slot and had received pretty good reviews. The price was great as well. The device worked as expected for the first 36 days after purchase. It then started having issues. It started with random reboots. I was not worried as first as I throw a lot at my tablets. A few weeks later the screen would no longer come on. I tried all the tips and the device would not respond at all. I plugged it in and unplugged it and held the power key for about 60 seconds. The device would boot but as soon as the screen would turn off it would die again.

I called Samsung and was told I needed to ship it back. They asked for a detailed description and I provided it and they sent a UPS label for me to ship the device back. About 2 weeks later I got an email that my device was fixed. The explanation of the problem was simply "Dead (Intermittent)" and the repair was "S/W Upgrade (External Factor)". A few days later my tablet arrived and I was shocked to see it was just stuck into a bigger box with no additional packing. When I removed the device there was an obvious scratch and it looked like the back had been pried off as there were small gouges. I fire the device up and the first time the screen went off, same exact issue! I plugged it in, waited a few minutes, unplugged and held the power button for 60 seconds and it came back on.

I again called Samsung and was told I needed to ship it back a second time. I asked why as it did not seem like they did anything except wipe it and re install the software. I told them this was unacceptable that I had to give up my tablet yet again since no one fixed it the first time. I also questioned the cosmetic damage and was told "we are very careful with all customer devices". I said so what if it comes back and is still not fixed? I was told they may consider an exchange. WOW, thanks.

If you get a good device you will probably be happy with it. If you have issues, good luck actually getting it fixed. I'm very disappointed in Samsung and the way they are handling this. At least offer me a replacement since they apparently can't fix mine. Not happy it was damaged either.

UPDATE: I sent an email to the president of Samsung North America and got a call from someone in his office. She reviewed my case and said she would ship me a new Galaxy 2 7" tablet as soon as my old one arrived at repair. She assured me this would be a new, sealed device. Today she notified me that it shipped from CA today. I'm very happy that they went the extra mile for me. I will report back once I receive the replacement and ensure it is working properly. Nice job Samsung!

UPDATE: I have been using the new replacement unit for about a month now. No issues with the new unit so far. As I recall, unit one went dead at 36 days so let's see if this one will works in a week.

I currently own a 1st gen IPAD (64gb WIFI & 3G nonactivated and purchased on sale through AT&T when IPAD 2 came out) and only use it during traveling.  It's function for me falls between an expensive toy, e-reader, and movie player.  I wanted to Skype and a lighter tablet so I hesitantly purchased the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2.0 7 inch at Costco for $239.  I cannot say how this tablet compares to newer generations of IPAD but compared with my 1st gen, it offers more versatility and of course it is the compact solution for traveling and doesn't add as much weight as the IPAD.  So now I can carry it in my purse everywhere I go with no bulk added!  Now I have Kindle keyboard so as far as reading goes, I prefer using the tablet for reading PDF files and have yet to try comic books which Kindle keyboard is not compatible with.  However, for regular e-books I still prefer my Kindle keyboard because of the battery life and the E ink technology that is much easier on my eyes.  The Samsung's touchscreen is slightly less responsive than the IPAD but after using it for a few days I've figured out that you can tweek the responsiveness on the settings.  As far as application use, you can open and manage multiple apps and widgets simultaneously which at first being a nuisance to an apple groupie like me,  I am slowing adapting to use the tablet for efficient tasking.  For instance, I usually need to scan tons of receipts so I downloaded a scan app like Genius scan then scan my documents and save to evernote.  I can open the calculator without closing the evernote app and calculate different receipts.  This is a huge time saver over the IPAD and Iphone which only allows one app to be opened at one time. My favorite widget so far is the sticky notes which can be posted in different sizes on the home screen (something IPAD can't do). However, to prevent the multiple apps from slowing down the Galaxy, it's important to check the task manager and close apps that are running in the background. As for internet connection, I haven't had any problems like other reviewers have posted.  Also, the microSD slot is a huge bonus over the IPAD which allows for expanded memory for photos and music, etc.  A 32 GB micrsoSD card on Amazon is around $19 so a huge money saver over any of the IPADs.  I am planning to purchase the Samsung accessory kit for USB and SD slot for greater expansion in the future (that's around $20 on amazon).  A couple things I didn't like are the poor camera resolution and the smudging and glare of the screen.  The IR remote app is a great concept that worked on my TV but has very limited functions. It doesn't allow for searching by channels and doesn't provide a tv guide.  When I entered into the menu of the tv, the keypad doesn't work for scrolling or exiting the menu.  Overall, I am making great use of the expanded capabilities. There is so much customization that I have spent hours exploring.

Even with only one application open, the tablet will eventually slow down until there is a 2 or 3 second delay between each letter I type and when it appears on the screen. Also, the glossy screen is a pain if you are trying to watch anything when there is ANY glare. The screen is so glossy that it works like a mirror, more so than the iPhone or iPad screen I believe. If buttons are close together on the screen, forget about trying to click one properly. I wanted to replace my first-gen iPad with a 7" tablet. My choice came down to this device and the Nexus 7. Samsung won for one simple reason: the micro SD slot. If you have any desire to carry video around to watch where you can't stream, you need storage space.

The Gtab is lighter than the iPad -- though hardly lightweight, especially when compared to a Nook Touch -- which makes a difference for extended reading of e-books, or reading while lying down. Being a smaller device, it's also easier to travel with; it doesn't take up as much room in a carry-on and it fits in a coat pocket (or even a cargo pocket in my shorts!). The micro SD card slot means I can carry more videos to watch on a plane, though the battery life for video isn't as long as I'd like. Battery life while streaming Netflix via WiFi is even less; it's good for 2 - 2.5 hours and then it's time to recharge.

I don't understand complaints I've read about the screen and its resolution. The screen is bright (turn off the auto brightness adjustment and do it manually), colors look reasonably good, and playback is smooth. Any artifacts I've seen in videos come from the videos themselves, not the screen. It's a 7-inch tablet; how many more pixels do you need?

Small speakers don't sound particularly great, but these are at least good enough to let someone else listen with me on occasion. Sound through good headphones is quite good.

The Gtab is good for reading, too; the size makes it easier to handle than the iPad. I've had some issues with certain e-books, but they're from the e-book or the reader app, not from the tablet.

I'm not happy about the lack of an adapter for video out so I could watch purchased movies/TV shows on my HDTV (although reading elsewhere indicates that you can't port DRMed material on any of the Tab devices to a TV through Samsung's HDMI adapter (which is not compatible with this device)). For that matter, not happy with the custom connector in the first place. A mini- or micro-USB connector would have made life easier all the way 'round. There also appears to be no docking station of any kind that's compatible with this particular device. (Seriously, Samsung? You have other tablets with the same type of connector, but you changed the pin-outs or something on THIS device so that it can't be used with any of the accessories that work with them?)

I'm glad that the Gtab came with Android 4 installed, so I didn't need to wait for an upgrade (the Gtab recently upgraded itself to version 4.0.4). However, I'm not happy that there is so much bloatware preinstalled, and no way to remove it without rooting the tablet. I also dislike the fact that there is no way to move apps -- or data that they download/install -- to the external SD card without rooting the tablet. Some apps can't even see the external card (which, I realize, could be the fault of the app rather than the tablet).

Given that Samsung has locked down so many things to internal storage, it would have been nice to have a 16gb device available. I'd have paid an extra $50 for that. Instead, I'll get around to rooting the tablet one of these days so I can ditch stuff I don't use and move data (downloaded videos and books) to external storage. For now, though, the combination of price, usability, and form factor means that I'm fairly happy with the Gtab.

Note: If you're switching to the Gtab from an iPad, and want to continue using iTunes for organize your music, get the iSyncr WiFi app. You may have to create special playlists -- iSyncr doesn't support picking & choosing songs/videos, it just grabs the whole playlist -- but this is the best iTunes tool available on Android right now.

I did a few weeks' worth of searching and comparing before I bought The Tab 2 7.0, and this tablet offers more bang for the buck than any other tablet in its size and price point. With the right apps, this tab really shines. I find the rear camera useful for bar code and QR scanning without issue using the free Barcode Scanner app (the one with a bar code icon with a red triangle in the center), and also use the Paper Camera, DSLR and Pixlr-o-matic apps which get the most out of the camera's abilities. While the rear cam is only a 3 megapixel, it's still useful. If I want to take better photos, I have dedicated cameras but this does quite well in a pinch, and will also shoot 720p video for those times when you're caught without a camera or camcorder. The front camera is useful for using Skype or other comm apps. The speakers sound remarkably well for being so tiny, but they are both at the end of the tablet while holding it landscape mode. Not a problem. Still, for listening while watching movies or Wifi FM radio (TuneIn radio app), I'll use either my Sennheiser CX400 or Audeo Phonak ear buds. I installed PowerAmp and am impressed with the sound quality while listening to downloaded music and FM; separation and imaging capabilities, even while plugged into my run of the mill Creative T20 speakers at work was startling. It was like having much better speakers! Video while watching streaming Netflix or converted mp4s is excellent and for a 7" screen, I didn't find the resolution lacking and the colors were saturated but not unrealistic, using the built-in Netflix app, the native video player app or MX Player Pro. I did not notice any light bleed and the blacks were black, not dark gray. It was easy getting caught up in a 2-hour movie while watching it on this Tab. Wifi connection is instant, both at home and on public networks and have not dropped any connections, remaining strong even while straying 50-60 feet from my home router. I think most issues with wi-fi is having "same channel" interference from other routers in the neighborhood, so I installed the free app Wifi Analyzer (if it's not here, check the goggle Play store), which will let you know what channels the other routers are using as well as signal strength, so you can plan accordingly which channel to use with your own router. GPS works fine; I was able to get 8-meter accuracy while using Goggle Maps. Goggle Sky is also fun to use. I also use GPS Test Plus from the Play store. eWeather HD by Elecont is an awesome weather app, also with HD radar and even earthquake features, and uses either GPS or you can punch in a ZIP code. I installed a SanDisk 32GB MicroSDHC card, and as for transferring data to or from the laptop, you can use either the supplied USB cable that comes with the charger, but I prefer using WiFi File Explorer Pro (also at the Play store) which provides an easy Web interface from a desktop or laptop, but it's only secure when using it at home (provided you're using an encrypted wireless connection, right?) which makes for easy transfers and avoids the hassle of having to use the restrictive length of a USB cable; ES File Explorer also works fine. As for moving apps to the external SD, it's not happening (yet) which can be an issue, since the ShadowGun game app alone is over 450mb once the data is downloaded for the game (and by the way, ShadowGun plays fine on the dual core TI OMAP processors on the Tab 2). There are also astronomical apps which can go from 500mb - 1GB with the downloaded data (SkySafari Plus and SkySafari Pro) so there is somewhat cause for alarm, as out of the 8GB of memory this tablet has, there's only around 4GB free when it comes new out of the box. I've checked the forums, and there is much concern regarding not being able to move apps from internal memory to the external SD (MicroSDHC) card. Some think it's a Samsung issue, while other think it's because Goggle (the developers of Android) wants people to use the cloud for storage needs. With Android releases through version 3 it wasn't an issue saving apps to the external memory card, but beginning with version 4 (Ice Cream Sandwich) the code changed as far as permissions went, so I'll quote Moderator Blast (thanks!) from the Galaxy Tab forum: "Turns out Google had for some reason since Honeycomb 3.2 decided to split the write permissions for the internal memory (the path of which is confusingly named /mnt/sdcard) and external SD card memory (the path being /mnt/sdcard/extStorages/SdCard) into WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE and WRITE_MEDIA_STORAGE respectively. Apps to SD The SD card is mounted r/w, but the owning group is media_rw which is linked to the WRITE_MEDIA_STORAGE permission. Unfortunately, this permission was not required for access to the external sdcard prior to 3.2 so most file management utilities do not request it when they run... meaning they only have read access to the card. Before Honeycomb 3.2, apps only had to request for the permission WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE and they would have write access to both the internal and external so-called "sdcard" sets of memory. Now, apps have to request for WRITE_MEDIA_STORAGE if they want to write to the external SD card, but many of them have not yet been updated to do so yet. This affects file managers / explorer / compression utility type apps most often because users would tend to use them to copy / move / zip files within the file system. As for Ice Cream Sandwich, latest reports are that, yes, they are going to continue with this separate permission model. Hopefully in the future, more apps would have been amended to include the necessary permission/security settings." So as you can see, most developers are just not aware of this change while writing apps for the current versions of Android, but hopefully they will catch on soon. For now, the only way to circumvent some of the bloat is to root the tablet, but I see some users experiencing issues after doing this, and rooting the tab will void the warranty (not to mention the possibility of "bricking" it, or rendering it useless), and since Samsung hasn't made their stock firmware available as a back up solution, rooting for me is out of the question. The Tab 2 makes a fine e-book reader. The included Kindle app works well, and the text is very sharp, clean and easy to read - to the point where I've already read 5 books since having the tablet in less than a month. It's just a pleasure to read with. You can also turn off GPS, Wifi, Sync and screen rotation to save on the battery. The new 4.04 release for Ice Cream Sandwich released by Samsung this past week in an update also adds some power saving features and a few other enhancements (it shipped with 4.03 in June when I received it). As for Web browsing, I use Dolphin HD which is fast, allows me to keep multiple tabs open while not slowing down the browsing, and allows me to browse Websites in native Desktop mode (with the Dolphin Desktop add-on); otherwise some sites will sense that you're using a mobile device and causes frustration while having to view in a different style than what you're normally used to. But browsing the Web is fast and enjoyable; pinch-to-zoom is quick and effortless with no lag. YouTube also works and plays fine. Typing on a device this size can cause frustration or outright expletives (I've experienced both), and after much research for alternate keyboard apps, I downloaded the Thumbs Plus keyboard app (the Play store) and never looked back. It costs a few dollars, but rest assured it's very much worth it. It's a real joy to use, and a no-brainer with any Android tablet. Oh, and grab a matte finish (non-glare) screen protector; you'll find them if you look and it's really worth the time finding one, as it turns the screen from it's default mirror finish into a screen that's a pleasure to work with and doesn't affect brightness or clarity. I like it so much that when I ordered the Tab I also ordered the Skinomi screen protector, which has a gloss finish. The Skinomi is still sitting in the box unused. If I can think of anything else to add, I'll update this review. Until then, I'm very happy with my purchase of the Galaxy Tab 2 7.0. EDIT 7/25/2012 - I've read some reviews where the length of the charging cable is short (and it is). What I've done is attach a ten foot USB extension cable between the end of Samsung's charging cable and the USB port on the actual AC charger and it works fine for charging (although I haven't tried copying or moving data) AmazonBasics USB 2.0 A-Male to A-Female Extension Cable (9.8 Feet/3.0 Meters). I find this to be a much less expensive solution rather than buying a Khomo 6' cable.

When the Tab 2 7.0 came out it looked wonderful. Feature packed with Android 4, cameras, SD card slot (important but missing on many tablets), GPS, Google Maps, etc. and the tablet itself has lived up to its promise but Samsung unfortunately has not. I have become well acquanted with their customer service and the people are great but seem to have spotty training. It is like the "little girl with the curl".

When it became evident that their Bluetooth instance had trouble pairing with a number of common devices (on access would give constant pairing requests), at first they denied the problem & said it was the adapter, then they were working on it. Finally two months after it was reported, ICS 4.0.4 came out and it was fixed.

Except no-one told the service desk just as no-one told them that Allshare had been moved from a seperate app to part of settings. This is bad because from day one HDMI support had been promised except it needed an unobtainable adapter. Then it was said one of their adapters would work except it doesn't. Samsung's latest move is to redact the reference to HDMI from their specifications and user guide (is in revs up to 3, not in rev 7. Page 22). Lawyers have a word for this.

So if it does what you need out of the box or with an available adapter then you are fine but if something you expected to work (like the Sat-Nav seems to need WiFi/3G access to calculate driving directions but the GPS itself seems powerful) is "different" or is in the specs but does not seem to be there (like being able to connect to an external display), good luck.

In any case, be kind to the service desk people, they are trying to do the right thing.

It was my birthday and my family asked me what I wanted. I decided a new toy would be nice. My needs are minimal as I'm at my desktop much of each day, but occasionally like to read from my Kindle, surf for deals on Amazon, watch a Netflix movie, listen to music and email. I have accomplished these things with my Android phone, but slowly using 3G and a 4" screen. For a tablet I wanted a 7" screen, camera w/ video capabilities, responsive operating system, expansion capabilities with a microSD card, and a built in GPS, not dependent upon wifi or 3G. I found all of that in the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2. Not the fastest OS (Google Nexus 7 will have the 4.1 Jellybean) or the fastest processor or the very best screen resolution, but 'very good' which translated into a good compromise between features and price for me. Not an iPad... but not meant to be one either. What I like about the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2... 1. GPS navigation worked well and was fast to locate satellites, making it a good choice for the person who likes having a GPS, but rarely uses one except to locate somewhere to eat lunch in the city. (Like me!) 2. Has more features than the Kindle Fire, Full Color 7" Multi-touch Display, Wi-Fi - which I also own - and with the free Kindle app still allows me to take my books with me. The viewing experience is the same as both have similar screens in clarity and size. 3. The 3.0MP rear facing camera takes good pictures and video. Not the best I've seen, but certainly as good or better than my LG Optimus Prepaid Android Phone (Virgin Mobile). 4. The weight is substantial - you know you're holding it - and the build quality is excellent! Buttons (rockers) feel solid and are easy to find. 5. Touchscreen swipes are smooth and transitions move quickly. 6. Wi-fi is easily found and connected. 7. Screen is bright and clear. Adjustments to brightness easily made in 'Settings'. 8. Watching Netflix and Amazon On Demand movies was lag-free and enjoyable. I was a worried about it not being as clear as I would like, but due to the 7" screen size, there was no problem at all. I've seen the iPad display and while it's not that tight, it's very good. 9. Good battery life. If you put it on 'Airplane mode' in settings, you'll get even more life out of your juice! 10. Came with lots of apps installed: Netflix, Gmail, Google, and more, as well as useful widgets for weather and calendar. 11. Charging went quickly and easily with the adapter that allows for USB or AC charging. 12. Web browsing was quick n' easy, as was emailing with this tablet. 13. This tablet has Bluetooth! I have a bluetooth headset that I pair with it: LG Tone - HBS-700 Wireless Bluetooth Stereo Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/Orange which also works with my LG Optimus phone. I can use it to do Google Talk calls - long distance for free via Gmail's interface. The tablet has a built in microphone on the front and you can use regular headphones for Google Talk, or you can use the one on your Bluetooth. What I wish was a bit better... 1. I would love it if Samsung was to offer an OS update to 4.1 Jellybean to make this thing fly! 4.0 Android Ice Cream OS is quick and when I received this tablet I immediately went to 'About' and clicked 'Update' - receiving the 4.04 update for Ice Cream. The update requires a reboot of your system and you may lose data, so good to do it right out of the box. Made a nice improvement in the tablet's speed after the update! 2. Again, the Nexus 7 will have a faster processor, faster OS and better display 1280x800 pixels, but the 1.2 forward facing camera n' no expansion slot were big issues for me. The Samsung doesn't have those 'fast' components and yes, I wish it did, but then I remember the price point. 3. Not much documentation came with it. Undoubtedly it's either on the device or online, but sometimes you just want to read a good book or have it handy for reference. 4. Internal memory gets eaten up quickly by apps, but multitasking isn't this tablet's strong suit - or my expectation. 5. No HDMI or USB ports, but it does have Bluetooth and can act as a remote control with included app via infrared. 6. GPS - yes, I put it in the 'like' area too, but truthfully it's more of a slow toy on this tablet than a GPS replacement. I am pleased with 2 accessories I bought for this tablet: MoKo(TM) 360 Degree Rotating Detachable Cover Case for Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 7-inch Tablet, Black (with Vertical and Horizontal Multi-angle Stand) which fits this tablet perfectly - allowing for access to all the ports and protecting it while also allowing horizontal or vertical viewing, and [Ultimate Clear] Ringbo Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 New Release Tablet 7" Screen Protector Cover Film with Warranty which while tricky to apply, also fits perfectly. I also bought a SanDisk 32GB microSDHC Memory Card (Bulk Package) for it, which inserted easily and was recognized as 28GB of useable space by the tablet. *FYI... it's not uncommon for any storage to be recognized as less than the stated size after installation. Charging the device out of the box and then updating it immediately made using it the best it could be upon first use. I will be installing an app to do basic clean-up of the memory cache and an antivirus. There are several free options for both. Being my first tablet, the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 doesn't have big shoes to fill in my life like if I was an iPad user. I don't think anyone with an iPad would find this tablet interesting at all! For those who want portability, with more functionality than the Kindle Fire and a tablet with good speed and expansion, as well as a camera and video taking capabilities - this is a very good choice at an affordable price. RE: Apps If you want to install the Amazon Appstore on your Samsung Galaxy Tab 2... you have to go to www.amazon.com/appstoreapp and download the app. Your tablet may say 'no' and block it. If so, go into 'Settings', 'Security' and under 'Device Administration' make sure the box for 'Unknown Sources' is check marked. The tablet will caution you that this makes your private info vulnerable, but in reality all it does is open up other another Appstore (other than Samsung's which is installed on the device) for you. Once you do this you should be able to download and install the Amazon Appstore and use it. That works well for me as I have several apps already that I use on my Android phone and Kindle Fire, which can also be used on this tablet. I'd suggest adding some of these apps I found useful and/or fun picked up at the Amazon Appstore. Most, if not all, are free. Remember that every day Amazon offers a new app for free. They are paid apps that for 1 day only, Amazon offers for free download. Sometimes, they are apps valued at $10 the day before, so it's definitely worth checking frequently! Star Chart -check out constellations. 23. iHeartRadio - like Pandora (also available), create custom radio stations. 24. Antivirus Free or Avast! - keep safe while surfing. 25. For the speediness of it, size and features, it's really a great buy! UPDATE: 12/2/12 Disappointing... the Galaxy is dead. Started not holding a charge, then wouldn't turn on, and finally wouldn't charge at all. My use with this tablet has been about once a week for about an hour. Not exactly hard on it, so I'm a bit bummed. I did run an update prior to this happening so I'm not sure if it's a bad update or the hardware. Either way, dead in the water and will be contacting Samsung for warranty repair or replacement. UPDATE: 4/21/13 The 'end' to my Tab story is that I took it back to Costco (where it was purchased as a gift with a 2 year warranty) and they told me they'd replace it, but had none in stock and to come back a week later. I did that (after a call confirmed they had them in stock) and drove 30 miles only to find they were out of stock. I asked how long it would take to repair it, and that was 'unknown' via the Costco repair system. I asked for, and received a refund on the purchase price (went back on the person's credit card who purchased the gift...). I liked the Tab, but since have purchased a Apple iPad MC705LL/A (16GB, Wi-Fi, Black) 3rd Generation which I love. I purchased directly through Apple refurbs, and it came with a 1 year warranty - for under $400. Yes, it's more expensive, but it's also better. If you're looking for a budget Android tablet, this is still a good choice though, and if Costco had them in stock when I had returned to exchange, I'd probably still have it.

I am truly overwhelmed by this tablet. I purchased this to replace my aging Palm Pilot. I primarily use this tablet to organize all of my work files and it is turnng out to be a great tool.

I transferred all of my notes from my Palm consisting of nearly 500 procedures. The transfer was tedious and required beaming them to a laptop with an IR beam. I then dragged and dropped the individual procedures from the laptop to the tablet. The tablet has Polaris Office which easily converted the imported text files and stored them in the Memo tool.

I imported my contacts in a similar fashion. All but a handful were successfully added to the tablet without having to re-enter them by hand. I also  dragged and dropped my photos and MP3's from the Palm to the tablet via the SD memory chip.

I had numerous HanDBase databases on the Palm that I transferred by saving them to the Palm's SD memory chip. Then I transferred the databases from the memory chip to the tablet. Fortunately HanDBase has an Android version of their database program and I was able to start using my databases in minutes. HanDBase is so much easier to use on the tablet.

Lastly, I opted to enter my calendar appointments by hand to the S Planner.

In all, the process of transferring my information from the Palm to the tablet was painless. I now have all of my information on a much better tool and the wifi capabilities is icing on the cake. By the way, I have found the wifi to perform better than expected. I have wireless devices that do not work on the third floor of my house but this tablet works flawlessly. The GPS and mapping features are awesome. I have several GPS devices that range in price and I am really amazed at the precision and effectiveness of the built-in GPS. The battery life is very good if you don't over do it with the wifi or GPS. I usually get 7 days of battery life if I don't use the power hungry wifi/GPS. If I sparingly use the wifi/GPS then I can expect 2-3 days of usage. I have owned this tablet for 3 weeks now and I am still finding better ways to utilize it and it has been a great companion at work.

I really do enjoy my Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 - The tablet was at a great price, it is fast and is well built - however, there are some quirks and some Samsung-isms that detract from what is overall a very nice 7" tablet.  I'll try to be brief but thorough, scroll to the bottom for the cliff-notes.

::Hardware::
Processor: Dual 1.0ghz - Pretty standard for 2012, zippy for most things but not record
  breaking
Ram: 1gb - Again, pretty standard for ICS in a middle price point device; fine for 99% of tasks
Screen: 1024x600 WSVGA - Gorgeous. Samsung makes pretty screens and good hardware.
microSD: Accepts microSDHC (Up to 32gb of external storage) They use a dumb mnt name though ...
microUSB: NONE (Samsung!  What were you thinking!)
miniHDMI: NONE (Samsung!! Seriously!!)
30 Pin Proprietary Port:  Yup. Instead of industry standard ports Samsung saddles this device
  with a 30 Pin port (*cough Apple rip-off cough*) You will be stuck with Samsung brand cables
  and accessories.  I don't know why companies think that proprietary ports are a good idea ...
  whatever.
Camera: 8mp Rear / 3mp Front.  They are decent but only really useful for Skype and video chat.
  Taking pictures on a Tablet is awkward and there is no flash.
IR Blaster:  You can control your TV (I had wondered where this feature went 7 years ago when
  it disappeared from devices.  I'm glad it's back, it is by no means life changing but it is
  fun.)
Speakers: Better than I had expected, but unfortunately they are located on the bottom so when
  you play games or watch movies in landscape the stereo experience is lost.  Also, if you have
  big hands and hold it from the right your hand covers the speakers muffling the sound.  Oh
  well.
Audio out:  Headphones work.  The jack is a little tight so you worry about breaking it the
  first time ... but it works fine.
Bluetooth:  Works great.  Keyboards, mice, gamepads, etc.  Go nuts.
Battery Life:  Much better than I had expected.  It generally lasts a whole day even with heavy
  use.  It lasts longer if I am just checking the web and email occasionally.  It won't last
  much longer than 3 days on light to moderate use.
Connectivity:  I bought the WiFi only model and it connects well to a Wireless B/G/N router.
Bezel / Case:  The device is well built and does not feel flimsy.  It has a little weight to
  it, but the appearance is very slick and attractive.  Occasionally, because I have big
  thumbs, I accidentally touch the screen when holding the device one handed.  I suppose
  someone with smaller thumbs would not have this problem.  (Thumb-ectomy?)

::Software::
OS: Ice Cream Sandwich is awesome.  Google made some great improvements with this release of
  Android and it is much more polished than Honeycomb .... unfortunately Samsung has included
  some "Customization" and several of the Android menus are truncated and some options are
  missing.  (Mostly things like Themes.)  I guess this is leftovers from the "Touch Wiz" era.
  This is too bad really, because on a stock build the device would probably run a little
  faster and have some more UI options.  Samsung ... STOP IT!
Pre-Loaded Apps:  This is the part of the review that makes me sad.  Samsung really does make
  gorgeous hardware, but their software is kinda crap.  They have pre-installed the Samsung
  Media Hub, custom gallery and calendar apps, and a slew of other Samsung branded "Features".
  Most of them work o.k. but you can't get rid of them and they don't really add anything to
  the Android experience.  I wish manufacturers would stop trying to provide "extra content".
  As usual the Samsung Experience apps are protected and cannot be removed without rooting.
  You can however hide them in the app drawer so you don't have to look at them and most of
  them do not automatically load into memory unless you tell them to.  More or less I find they
  just take up space.  The Galaxy also comes with the standard Google apps pre-loaded.  The new
  Ice Cream Sandwitch email app works so much better than the Gingerbread/Honeycomb one and
  Gmail's App is much improved as well.  Also, Google Chrome is available for Ice Cream
  Sandwich. It works well and syncs all of your bookmarks from your desktop browser if you let
  it.

::Summary::
Great price, nice hardware.  Runs most apps flawlessly.  (High end emulators will have to accept some frame skipping to get past the standard processor.)  If you like spending extra money on proprietary cables, there are a slew of accessories from the Galaxy Tab 1 7.0 that will work fine with this.

Hardware - 5/5  (*For this price point)
Software - 3/5  (*Ugh!  Samsung warez!)

Galaxy 2 7.0 vs. Kindle Fire = Buy this tablet!  It crushes the Fire in processing and overall user experience.
Galaxy 2 7.0 vs. Nexus 7 = Hmm ... depends on how important microSD is to you.  Probably get the Nexus 7.

Short review:

Nice screen, halfway decent camera and camcorder (no autofocus, though), and a good size to hold in your hand.

However....

The Wifi antennae is VERY weak on this device.  I use an AT&T Uverse Wifi modem in my house - a very standard unit and one used by a good number of people in my particular area.  It's been out a while as well, so is not an odd standard or unknown third-party device.  I noticed quickly that I was dropping Skype video calls on my Samsung Tab, then I noticed Netflix movies were buffering, and Youtube videos would do the same, all with me being only two rooms away from my router.  Through coworkers, friends, and a neighbor, I have had people come over to my house and test their devices on my Wifi, so we've had a range of Android phones, a couple of iPhones, and one iPad in here trying it out.  Everyone averaged around 12-18 Mbps download speeds on their devices, when in my living room, two rooms away from the router.  My Samsung Tab barely got one bar of signal, and averaged around .5 to 1.5 Mbps download speeds (if that).  Same room, same location in room, etc.

There are no updates to the device software.  Samsung support ranges from "we're aware of it" to "send it in for repair".  I'll be taking it back to where I purchased it as my "repair" - sorry, I'm tired of companies using the public to test their devices before they have.  That's my experience, yours may vary.

UPDATE (April 2013):

Decided to try this again as by now the kinks should have been worked out on newer production stock, so went back to the Big Box store and got one that runs Android 4.1 (instead of the previous unit's 4.0), showing it's an updated model.  This time, the WiFi worked *slightly* better with *slightly* better range than the previous unit, this time averaging about 6-8 MPS on average (in a 22 MPS area, however).  I noticed that for whatever reason, this unit had more "bloatware" apps installed than my last unit, that cannot be removed, and upon investigation many of them keep trying to kick on constantly even after you disable them (?).  Not a deal breaker, but irritating.  The "up to 11 hour" battery life is also stretched of course, too - with consistent normal use I'd say it's more like 7 1/2 hours depending on what you're doing.

This is app-specific but worth noting too - I tried a very popular scanner app that allows you to create PDF documents of papers you have, and upon installing I was told by it it was not compatible with this device because the Tab 7" only has a 3 megapixel camera on the back, and you really need at least 5 megapixels to be table to clearly scan documents.  I know this is specific, but something worth noting, as people do like to get smaller tablets for work uses as well.

Overall I upped my rating one star from 2 to 3 but there are still enough quirks and irritations to make me tell someone to look further (maybe a Nexus) unless they are getting one specifically just for very casual uses like Netflix, etc.

I purchased this 7inch tablet for use as a student in medical clinical settings and of course during leisure time as well. I purchased this based on my satisfaction of other Samsung products and my liking of their original 10.1 tablet. I won't make this too lengthy and will get right to the point, starting with a list of pro's and con's.

Pros
-Expandable memory (up to 32gb)
-Icecream sandwich OS (Soon to be outdated, see below)
-IR Port
-Front and rear camera
-Good WiFi reception

Cons
-My biggest issue with this tablet was the screen and I noticed this on all units I have been able to take a look at. The color calibration on this is EXTREMELY below Samsung standards. This was the worst screen I have ever witnessed on a Samsung product. When compared to the Kindle Fire and other tablets in this tier,the biggest thing I noted was the galaxy tab's whites are more of a cream and have a dirty look. It's possible this may be corrected in an update in the future but as for now, how did this ever make it to the consumer market?!?!

-Icecream Sandwich will soon be outdated by Jellybean. I have had 4 other Samsung Android devices and they are notoriously slow getting Android updates out. Feel free to look this up if you don't believe me, it's a fact.

-Also because it is Samsung, you do not get the full Android experience but instead you will get it mixed with their Touchwiz software. I have found this to have a very negative impact on the performance of this tablet and more often than not, just gets in the way.

-The iconic Icecream Sandwich face unlock feature that was so advertised with the OS release? You won't find that it on this tablet because Samsung doesn't support it.

-The IR port does not have a paired Samsung application to run it. Instead you will be directed to install the Peel Reel app to make use of it. It is one of extremely few apps that can make it work. Peel Reel is somewhat buggy and requires an internet connection to use (you can see it's reviews in the Google Play Store, will improve over time I am sure). I found that it works well on Sony and Dynex televisions, but for some reason it just couldn't master an LG flat screen. Something for Peel Reel to work on, but why no Samsung App to support this?!?!

-I put the cameras in PRO because they are included unlike some other tablets, but their quality limits their usefulness. You will be able to video chat, but be prepared to look pixelated.

-I mentioned performance before, but I wanted to throw in about requiring restarts too. I thought we had moved away from the tech limitation of having to restart a device to clear tasks, RAM, etc. but apparently not. When you turn on the tab you may be able to play a graphic intense game or an equivalent on this tab, but later in your session, you will see some lag times on it without a restart. Samsung includes it's own task manager but it does not clear up the lag with extended use.

-The touch sensitivity needs to be stronger and their is no option to increase this, expect a few double taps along the way.

an excellent product, own brand, it works very fast and efficient, as it came as it was purchased, that is NEW, I am very satisfied with my purchase

This is my first foray into the world of tablets, so I don't really have anything to compare this to, but I'm having a lot of fun with this little tablet. I really, really wanted a tablet and the Galaxy's price was right. I think it's probably a good starter tablet. Oh, and I can't forget my Kindle app. If I want to spend an hour or more reading, I prefer my actual Kindle, but the Kindle app is great for a quick bit of reading here and there and it synchs with my Kindle so I can pick up where I left off on either device. At first, typing on the touch screen drove me crazy, but now I'm pretty good at it. However, I would never use it for a lot of typing, just short emails. (I'm typing this on my laptop, not the Galaxy.) I still have trouble with the tiny "x" on the browser when I want to close a screen. I have to try several times before I hit it just right, toggling back and forth between the screen I want to keep and the screen I want to close. Arrrrgh! But, nevertheless, I'm having a lot of fun with this little gadget and I'm glad I bought it.

I love it so much i want to marry it. This is everything and more from a tablet.  This is the tech lovers version of the fire.  I have been reading on it since I got it and its just great. I have a Samsung Galaxy S2 phone and love it, so I decided to try one of their tablets. Since I have an android phone, getting around the tablet was a breeze. I have owned this tablet for several weeks and am very impressed. It is quick and the screen is very bright and clear. Battery life is excellent. The features work as advertised and it is a high quality unit. That said I ordered the Nexus 7 - in spite of the lack of SD slot. These are the reasons. I personally hate the 30 pin adapter that is needed to charge the unit. Maybe we will get HDMI from it - if Samsung ever released an adapter that will work with it. But at this point it is simply a more complicated and fragile charging/USB port and if I lose it I am SOL. Nexus 7 wisely uses standard micro USB. Next - the screen resolution on the Samsung means that you often have to move web pages sideways to activate buttons as so many sites are designed 1280 pixels wide. The Nexus 7 has 1280 resolution. It is aggravating to have to move your pages around to locate buttons. As far as storage I will buy one of those new wireless portable hard drives. Bottom line is the Samsung is GREAT, but for my needs the Nexus looks better.

First the product review:

After going through a round of 10.1 inch tablets, I felt that 7" is better to hold and does essentially most of the things you need a tablet for. So I bought this tab. After 3 days of usage, I would say it fits my needs well. I don't care much about HD or full HD or WXVGA, I would reach out for my laptop anyway for most of the tasks, as I find it more productive. The battery is decent, comparable to most of the tablets on the market. Charging time is a little longer than say Asus tablets, but I do it at night mostly. Another thing I noticed is that the charging cable is short like all other Samsung tablets, which is slightly frustrating.

Now comparing it with the nexus. The Nexus has all the hardware better than this, but there are a couple of reasons I am considering keeping this device. 1 - No sdcard support on Nexus. I will be using my device mostly for music storage, and 16 GB is quite limiting for me. I can manage by juggling my files around, but that would be frequent enough to annoy me, I think. Plus, if I use streaming services like Spotify or Rdio, I will have serious loss of space. 2 - It's Asus. All those who have tried their tablets know about the pathetic browser issue. Given the fact that even Prime has it, I doubt they would have resolved it in this one. That's something to look out for!

Thus far the only drawback I've found with this tablet is that it does not have a usb port. Hence, I am unable to connect a flash drive to save information. Had I realized there was no usb port,  I would not have purchased it.

If you read ebooks and mobility is important, i recommend this. For example, using a 10 inch in a crowdy bus while standing would be very hard. 7 inches is a good size for single handed use. It's also lighter.

If mobility is not important, you might want to check out devices with bigger screen.
