This is the second brand new Galaxy Tab 2 (7" model)that has not worked properly in one week. Amazon delivery and CS has been excellent but the performance of the unit and Samsung's CS sub-standard. I had great hopes based on Samsung's good name and the Tab's great features for the price. Being that this is a Wi-Fi model, I am rating it poorly because of it's inability to connect me to the internet.
I have linked multiple devices, laptops and smart-phones using various OS to my Wi-Fi Network w/out ANY glitches, BUT the Galaxy Tab couldn't yield a real/true connection. I am versed in setting up Networks and Wi-Fi connections, and Samsung's CS asked me twice to send the unit back calling it faulty. Two brand new units ? Let's get real! Unfortunately I can't stop to come to the conclusion that something in the hardware or software is not being able to fully connect with Wi-Fi's properly. I am using an N router and tried many ways to resolve the issue. From the beginning the Tab would identify the signal with the correct SSID and reported a strong signal and was unable to obtain the IP address and was not able to connect. I followed their suggestions by a) manually entering my network b) resetting the tab and c) entering the network spec's w/ a Static mode. All along the security password was recognized and secured. When using the static option I was finally able to achieve a connected status ( a short lived yeah!). While under "connected" status I was NOT able to truly connect to the internet or a google account, either the one I have been using, or even creating a new one. I spent 2.5 hours combined between phone CS and Chat CS to end up with their advise to return the unit and get a replacement.
I have wasted enough time and will not get a Samsung Galaxy Tab. I honestly wish it would have worked, but if it is going to be this hazzle on a perfectly good network/WiFi set-up I don't want to waste more time and/or have this degree of difficulty when trying to link to other networks. Under the CS guidance we even switched my N Router to the b & g modes and it failed as well.
I am again on the research mode to see which 7" Tab to get??  I don't like to bash a manufacturer and am hoping that this is a glitch that Samsung will correct. It has been a very wasteful experience; my time and Amazon's money absorbing the shipping costs! One of Samsung's CS said to me that my case was not unique, that he has seen other reports of inability of the Tab to connect with some WiFi's.

First of all, I have to really wonder about the many reviewers who bought this device, then returned, and gave it bad reviews because it doesn't save apps to the SD card. Since about 1 in every 5 of the 274 reviews (and counting) clearly complain that it doesn't save apps to the SD card - do you people who still continue to buy it, return, and complain because of that NOT bother to READ any of the reviews first before buying it???

Anyway, I've had this device for over 6 weeks now, and it does everything I wanted in a tablet - and within the max price I was willing to pay.  I previously bought a $150 tab and ended up returning it because it was under powered (IMO, you really need dual core CPU to properly run ICS 4), and my research indicated that the really cheap devices couldn't even play netflix movies properly.

I added a few 'accessories' that further enhanced the quality and usage
- a Poetic case for ~$18 that fits like a glove and is very functional (multiple viewing angles for movies, enhanced grip and no fingerprints, good protection)
- a good screen protector (originally designed for the 1st samsung galaxy tab 7) that gives a smoother feel when swiping on the screen
- turned on the "hotspot" feature on my android phone (extra monthly fee from verizon), so now I have 4G with this tablet anywhere there is 4G service...sweeeeeet!

Pros:
- netflix runs great on it
- good ebook reading experience
- screen quality is very good for doing the above
- camera - only because it's better than not having one at all (it's not great, but not as bad as some have written).
- 7" rules for portability and comfortable reading.  It's kind of funny watching folks trying to comfortably hold up their clunky (compared to 7") ipads for reading during the daily commute.
- internet surfing is excellent, either with home wifi or connected to my 4G phone via hotspot.

Cons:
- Peel remote app doesn't work at all with my Sony 40" tv.  I sent a support request to the company, a couple of times, and received no response.
- guess what? YOU CAN'T SAVE APPS TO THE SD CARD FOLKS!!

Since neither of the above Cons impact what I need a tablet for (still have plenty of internal memory to install more apps, if I need to), I gave it 5 stars, for overall quality and functionality.

Let me first say that I am no stranger to the tablet market. I started with the iPad 2 but then moved over to the 7" tablet form factor because I found that size to ultimately be more suited to my needs.

I'm a big fan of Samsung products anyway (already have one of their phones) and so I started to dabble with their 7" tablets, starting with the gTab 7.0 plus. I liked it, but I wasn't wild about it, so I ended up selling it.

Next I tried the gTab 7.7 from Verizon and, while it had an awesome screen and it blazed on 4g, I found that many apps didn't account for the additional screen size and so fonts were disproportionately small a lot of the time...not to mention that the 2 year commitment and initial price (despite being subsidized through the carrier) gave me more than one restless night's sleep, so ultimately  - given that for the monthly and up front cost, it wasn't rolling my socks up and down - it went back.

Enter the gTab 2 7" tablet. This one has proven to be the Goldilocks tablet for me...just right.

First of all, it runs ICS which (IMHO) makes a huge difference in the user experience on a tablet over Gingerbread. Perhaps just because I am used to ICS from my Nexus phone, but I found this tablet iteration to be the most pleasant to use out of all of them.

Obviously the gTab 2 7" can't out-spec the 7.7, but having had a 7.0 Plus, I can honestly say the differences are negligible. Is the Plus faster? Yes, a bit...but it was (at the time) also $399 to the tab 2's $249.

I carry this Tab with me daily in my purse. It is solid enough to feel good in the hand, but still light enough not to make having it in my bag or holding it up for long periods of reading a burden. The screen may only be 170 ppi, and only 1024 x 600 resolution, but to be honest, it looks great just the same. I stream Netflix on it as well as play movies from an SD card and in my opinion it is a very good video watching experience.

The cameras are only meh, but I have Skyped on it and it does fine. There were no complaints on either end as to quality.

For the most part, I use my Tab as a consumption device; I watch movies, browse news aggregating apps like Pulse, read books (and for $249 I can have both my Kindle books and my Nook books with me on one device...sweet!), stream music, spend time on social media and waste my life playing Draw Something.  I do appreciate the larger screen for managing my calendar and I have had occasion to do actual work on the thing too (though not often), which has been a good experience as well. In other words, I am not what you would call a power user - I am just your average consumer looking for a good product at a decent price point.

Personally, I just love it. I think the price is right for what it is, and I really like that (as opposed to the Kindle Fire and Nook Tablet - both of which are good devices, don't get me wrong) I can have an honest to goodness Android experience with the Google Play Store, etc.

Did Samsung need to put out yet another Galaxy Tab model? Probably not...but I have to say, owning this one, that I'm glad they did.

This little tablet is great!! Even Touchwiz on ICS is solid. Has a arrow that pops up Widgets that overlay apps like a Calculator, Notepad, Memo, Task list. So when I'm using Mint I can use the calculator and be in Mint at the same time. That to me was very impressive. It's true multitasking. I feel like everything is 1-2 clicks away. I bought the Memory adapter that gives me an extra 32GB of storage when I need/want it and have up to 72GB of storage. It's loaded with all my music and movies. The Peel app let's me use it as a remote control for my TV. I haven't gone anywhere without it, since it fits so easily in my backpocket.

This tablet has made me an Android Fanboy for sure. It does everything an iPad doesn't: 7", Widgets, In Browser flash, Touchwiz, Built in Remote receiver, Torrent downloader, expandable storage...etc.

the seller was also great. I paid for overnight around noon and got it the next day in great condition. Definitely happy with my purchase.

Purchased this tablet from my mother for her birthday and ended up getting my wife one for Mother's Day. The ease of use paired with the expandable memory and ICS make this a fun tablet to use. Also I feel you get the most bang for your buck. The camera is not the greatest but we rarely use the on board camera for anything other than quick video chats. The other thing that I like about this tablet is there is not a lot of fluff app preloaded. The only drawback is the lack of aftermarket products available for the Tab 2 7.0. we have resorted to using a Kindle portfolio until a decent case is put on the market.

First, the downsides of the tablet:
-It only has 8 GB of RAM, and half of that is taken by the bloatware Samsung has installed on the tablet, and cannot be removed.
-The cameras are horrible. The front-facing camera is VGA resolution and guaranteed to make you look bad in video chat, and the rear facing camera is 3 megapixels and fixed focus, so things like bar code scanners won't work with it. There is no flash or assistive light. Basically, if you ever think you want to use the camera for anything, buy something else.
-There is no indicator LED on the tablet, for notifications or charging status or anything else.
-Finding cases for it is tough.
-Some applications don't work too well, as they assume a bigger screen.
-Doesn't support larger MicroSD cards, only HC.
-The connector is proprietary, so you can't use standard USB variants to charge it.
-No HD out, even through the docking connector.
-No 5 GHz WiFi.
-Bluetooth compatibility issues with SPP class 0 devices.

Here are the upsides:
+In build quality, comparing it to the only other 7" tablet on the market (the Acer Iconia) for the same price you get a thinner and lighter tablet that feels vastly better. The Samsung is really well built, the materials are nice to the touch, and it's comfortable to hold.
+It's fairly responsive (unless you load it up with apps).
+The screen is nice, and the touch interface works well.
+I've been satisfied with the battery life.
+It's very good value for the money.

BLOAT WARE / Software?

I'm an Android fan from way back, and picking this up from Amazon for a Father's Day self-gift was easy. Amazon had it to me in two days and I charged it for a couple of hours before turning it on and setting it up. Sure, I was stepping up to the Ice Cream Sandwich operating system from Gingerbread on my Droid phone, but that shouldn't be much of a switch, right?

Wrong! I've been pounding on keyboards and phones for a long time, but my first 15 minutes on the Galaxy Tab 2 was not as simple as I thought it would be. I couldn't quite figure out the icons for moving around and my Gmail account did not get setup correctly. I contacted Samsung's online Support chat function and they were nearly worthless. They told me to click on options that didn't exist, so I had the Tab back in the box, ready to ship back to Amazon.

Well, I gave the Tab another chance, wiped the deck clean (I reset the device to its original out-of-the-box state) and started over. The second time was the charm. My Gmail account was setup just fine (I use Google's Authentication function on my Google accounts, so that may have affected my first attempt) and the Tab has shined brightly ever since. The device is a quality build, a perfect size and integrates with my Google applications very nicely. Netflix runs my movie selections flawlessly and the battery seems to last a long time between charges. For $249, it is a steal. I toyed with the original Amazon Kindle Fire when it came out, but it is very limited in comparison with the Tab 2. If you want a really good reader and Amazon store browser, the Kindle Fire is a great tablet for those things. If you want to pay 25% more, but end up with a tablet that can do a lot more online and with Google Play Store applications, the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 is your next tablet computer.

Positives:
High quality build - it feels like a well designed tablet in your hand
Great size - if you want a screen bigger than your phone, but small enough to read a book upon, the seven inch tablet form factor is great. The iPad is waaaaaay too big and clunky for causal reading.
Fast - screen switching from landscape to portrait is 'right there'. Moving among screens is smooth and quick.
Display - gorgeous. Vibrant colors, natural and realistic.
Open - you can sideload apps (get them from non-google and non-Amazon sources) and the machine is not just an Amazon tool.
Expandable - you can add a microSD card to this to expand your storage, add movies, music, etc.
Keyboard - nice size and quite accurate. (If you've typed on a smartphone, you know how challenging it can be to keystroke accurately.)

Negatives:
Sound - there seems to be just one speaker, at the bottom. It is easy, while watching Netflix, to cover it with your hand. The sound is ok, but won't win any awards for faithful reproduction of low notes.
Samsung support - they don't make it easy and their techs don't seem to know this new product very well yet. Phone support would be helpful, but Samsung uses a very slow paced chat service where you type in your questions and the tech takes FOREVER to respond. (But don't take long, yourself, to respond to them, or they'll terminate the chat!)

My wife wanted my Kindle Fire so instead of purchasing another I wanted something with a little more. Something with expendable memory, Bluetooth, gps, mic, and camera and this tablet hits on all cylinders.  I have a 32.gb micro .sd card in mine loaded with movies, pictures, and music along with documents.  Plenty of internal memory for apps and games. The display is excellent, making for excellent video watching, and sound quality is excellent for music as well as movies.  There is very little I can't do that I could do with the Kindle namely watching Prime videos and shopping on Amazon is a much better experience with the Kindle Fire.  However with this device you overall get much much more for only $50 more than the Kindle.
When using this device the drop down menu is actually a pop up menu on the bottom right of the screen for easy and quick access to a quick settings menu including Wifi, screen brightness, sync, GPS, silent mode, screen rotation,Bluetooth , notifications, and ariplane mode. This menu also has a set button for access to the full settings menu and immediate access to the screen brightness control as well as ongoing audio and notification. At the bottom of the screen there is also a button for instant access to mini apps including email, calculator, alarm,music player, planner, world clock,and task manager. These mini apps pull up small windows in the center of the screen that allow quick access to these features without leaving the screen you are working on. There is also an instant screenshot button and a button that pulls up apps that you have previously been working on giving you the ability to quickly return to them.
The camera takes excellent photos and videos and the forward facing camera is not all that great but does allow for selfportriats and face time. I personally make VERY little use of the camera but thought it was worth commenting on.
The GPS works great, just as it would on a good smart phone although it will not give you driving instructions without wifi.
The built in mic allows for use if voice dictation when emailing, writing Amazon reviews etc. I admittedly have very little experience with using this feature.
The Bluetooth feature was probably my biggest complaint about the Kindle Fire but this device does make use of it making listening to music untethered a pleasant experience as well as transferring data between bluetooth devices seamless and quick.
Web browsing is excellent on this tab, very quick and fit to screen is excellent as although pinch to zoom can sometimes be a little laggy.
This device comes with Polaris Office as it's native document program instead of Quick office. I have lots of evperience with DataViz, Quick office, and Office Suite as I read and edit documents on my mobile devices daily and Polaris blows all the other doc readers out of the water with it's (my opinion only) ease of use, and is visually very pleasing. I still use Office Suite some as I am more familiar with it by I expect that will come to an end as I become more familiar with Polaris.
The IR blaster was a surprising touch as I can program my tablet to control my TV and other IR devices in multiple rooms. Though there are glitches with the native Samsung app that makes use of the IR abilities it is still very nice.
Battery life is one thing I don't complain about vs other reviews.  I get a full days use from a single charge, even if I use it a lot, however I keep the screen brightness down and unused features off like GPS, notifications, wifi if not on the net etc.  I do the vast majority of my internet surfing from this device as well as TuneIn radio, mp3, Amazon mp3, Rahpsody, and YouTube and get a good 8 hours or more out of the device. I do believe screen brightness and of course streaming video or audio are the major factors when it comes to battery usage.

Now, in the spirit of full disclosure I strongly prefer a 7 inch tablet vs a larger tablet. The ONLY thing I like a 10 inch tablet better for is web browsing , though a 7 inch is no slouch in this department. A 7 inch tablet IMO is better for virtually everything else, games, email, video/audio, portability, and especially as an Ereader. The Kindle app for Android allows me to carry all my books very similar to the Kindle Fire.
I keep my Galaxy Tab 2 in a Poetic hard cover/stand with camera cutout and the device literally fits in my back pocket making this device truly portable vs, a 10 inch tablet. I use this as my Bible, web surfing device, hand held video game device, mp3 player, video streaming device, (youtube, Netflix, hulu, Crackle, etc) email, doc reader and editor, voice and video caller (when connected to wifi) PDA, and ereader. In the short time I have had this device it has become a "must take with me everywhere I go device".

I have the New iPad (aka the iPad 3) and my mom has the Kindle Fire so I have used that as well.  I would have to say that overall the Galaxy Tab 2 has worked great.  I received it about three days ago and I really like it.  I like my iPad but I always thought it was a little too big.  I liked the size of the Fire but I felt that the operating system on it was too limited.  I decided the Galaxy Tab 2 7" looked right for the price.  It's $50 more expensive than the Fire and $450 cheaper than my 64GB iPad 3.  The screen is not as clear or bright as the iPad 3 and the video quality isn't as good as the Kindle Fire but I would say that it is not too bad.  Don't expect excellent video quality because it's not but you can't expect all the bells and whistles of a high end tablet for only $250.  I like the android ice cream sandwich OS.  It looks nice on this device and it's a lot different than Amazon's version of android OS on the Kindle Fire.  The interface is fairly smooth and intuitive.  I haven't really had much delay when tapping on icons or sliding the screen.  It's not quite as smooth and sensitive as the iPad but let's face it, if you are interested in buying the Galaxy Tab 2 7" it is probably for the price and you have ruled out the iPad for that reason or because maybe you have one already.  I think the camera isn't too bad considering the Kindle Fire doesn't even have one.  It is front and back.  There is 8GB of internal memory with an expandable slot for up to 32GB micro SD card.  That is a plus over the Fire.  I find it easy to put music and movies onto the micro SD card, then put the card in the Galaxy Tab and it very quickly loads all of it onto the device to play.  Easier than using the iTunes software if you ask me.  The speakers on the Galaxy Tab are not as clear and crisp or even as loud as the iPad 3 but it gets loud enough for my taste.  The sound is better and louder with headphones.  With headphones it sounds pretty good.  The Galaxy Tab 2 is more portable than the iPad because if you don't carry a bag of some sort to put it in you can still fit it in your front pocket.  You won't be able to put much else in that pocket and it sticks out but you certainly can't do that with the iPad.  As far as android play store, I am new to it.  I'm used to iTunes but there are many of the same apps available on the play store.  There is a Kindle app so you can still read your ebooks.  As far as I can tell there is no way to play Amazon VOD for Prime members or otherwise.  You also can't really sync your iTunes purchases to the Galaxy Tab 2 either.  There are work arounds that allow you to put iTunes movies and music on the Tab but if that is something that interests you, you can always look that up.  Surfing the web is easy and you can use firefox or opera if you want.  I have read some reviews that say surfing the web on this tablet is slow but I have no found that to be the case.  Web pages don't load quite as fast as the iPad but they load pretty quickly.  I also read reviews about how the wifi connection isn't as strong on this device as it is on other tablets.  That appears to be the case but it really hasn't resulted in slow internet speeds for me; and my internet provider doesn't provide me with very good upload and download speeds.  Overall for the price I would say this is a good tablet.  You can get a few cellphones like the Samsung Galaxy Note or the upcoming SIII for $200-$250 that are like this tablet but with better specs.  However, that is the price you pay if you have an upgrade available otherwise without an upgrade you will pay retail of $500-$550.  I think that even the Galaxy Note's 5.3" screen is a bit too small for a tablet though.  The 7" screen is just right for an extra-portable tablet.  I would recommend the Galaxy Tab 2 7".  You can wait until July when supposedly a 7" Google Asus tablet will be released for $200.  It is supposed to have better specs.  Just FYI.

With this tablet, I can load all kinds of reader apps like Kindle, Barnes & Noble, Sony, Aldiko, etc.  Why limit myself to just Kindle?  Plus I can run most Android apps from the Android Market.  With Kindle, you are limited to just what you can get from the Kindle store.  I can't fault Amazon too much on this, since their main objective was to get the cheapest e-Reader on the market as fast as they can so they can sell more books.

Now, on to the one major flaw.  This tablet only has 8GB of internal memory of which only 4.48GB is useable for applications from what I can tell.  I have since filled up this memory with Kindle books and applications.  Android 4.0.3 (Ice Cream Sandwich) doesn't support moving apps to the external SD card like the previous versions.  The 32GB external SD card I have installed in this tablet is absolutely worthless.  From searching the web high and low, it appears that this is not a bug but a design feature.  Apparently, Google just wants the external card to be used for storing media files and nothing else.  They figure a tablet should have plenty of internal storage and not have the same issues as phones.  I hope Google will change their mind on this quick.  My Samsung Galaxy Epic II phone doesn't have this storage problem, but it's running Android 2.3.6 (Gingerbread).  It now holds far more apps and e-books than my tablet does LOL.

I bought this to replace my Kindle Fire which I was hacking and updating almost every week so I could have an inexpensive and small tablet with plain Android 4.0. Having the front and rear cameras is nice when you want to have a video chat or take a quick pic of something to Google Goggle. Bluetooth works really well for tethering and uses a lot less power than WiFi tethering on both the devices involved. The TV remote app is a good idea but does not work with all devices and cannot be used like a plain old universal remote (you are locked in to using it as a guide). As usual Touchwiz and all the other Samsung crapware ruins the device and slows it down. It also has a proprietary iPod like connector instead of the a standard micro USB connector like the majority of other devices in the world. Samsung if you insist on including a useless dock connector at least add a micro USB connector as well. I will probably end up selling this tablet and getting a Google Nexus 7" tablet if/when they release one so I don't have crappy software customization and get updates in a reasonable amount of time.

I will never buy a samsung product again! My mp3 didn't even last 1 year before it stopped working, now my Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 won't even turn on or charge & I purchased it less than 3 weeks ago! Yes- I tried the hold the power button, with finger on tab volume up & down....nothing but black screen! They told me it needs to be serviced.... SMH! Returning it today not exchanging! -_-

Overall this is a good tablet for $250.  The processor is fast enough, 1GB of ram is just right.  Everything seems responsive.  I got one issue and it is very important to me.  I use the barcode apps a lot and I am having problem using barcode app with this rear facing (3.0 Megapixel) camera.  The barcode is always out of focus when I try to scan the it.  I think the camera is fixed focus one (I was excepted it to be auto focus).  Maybe there is a setting that will turn on auto focus...like the camera from my phone.  It actually has a setting to turn on auto focus.  But I am not able to find in for Galaxy Tab 2.  Maybe I just got a defective one.  If anyone know how to turn auto focus on, please reply and let me know.

It's amazing how little marketing this awesome tablet is receiving. I've shown this device to a couple of my coworkers, fellow software and hardware engineers, and they all seemed highly interested and made aware that this tablet even existed.

My brother owned a Kindle Fire and I got a chance to play around with it. I liked the size, form factor and price. However, the dealbreaker was the lack of a SD/micro SD card slot. As an avid photographer, it would be nice to pull out my cards and view them from a larger screen. Fortunately, I ran into an article stating that Samsung was going to release a 7" tablet that would retail $250 that would include the micro SD slot, in addition, front and rear cameras, GPS, and IR blaster (Note: IR is nice to have, but currently the app that comes with it is flakey - sw issue/ not hw). Compared to the Fire aside from all those extra components, is that it's also much lighter, thinner and easier to hold.

From reading some of the reviews, I've noticed that there are complaints regarding the 8GB built in memory and the inability to transfer apps to the SD card. I currently have about 60 apps installed on the tablet with 3.88GB to spare - no rooting done to remove bloatware, mind you. Media (photos/video/docs) generally uses most of the memory, which if that is the culprit, can be alleviated by transferring via dropbox/app of choice/cable or the micro SD card (also you can change settings to have pics save to card) ;)

The gyroscope, or the screen rotation rather, is a bit laggy and it does take about 2 seconds to kick in portrait/landscape mode. Video streaming is smooth and internet browsing works fine with a wifi-dsl connection. Brightness can be easily adjusted by tapping the right hand corner in whatever screen you are in - no need to exit app and dig through the menu.

The front and back camera is not very good, pictures taken from it are a tad grainy and noisey - when viewed from the device itself. But hey if you're gonna be picky, you just saved several hundred bucks so you CAN go buy a real camera!!

Cable that comes with is about 3' long, users might find it a tad short to be plugged in while in use.

Though I pointed out some of the negatives just to make folks aware, in my eyes, they are not dealbreakers. The apps and browsing mechanism works reasonably well and I've used it for a few weeks now with no problems.

Overall, a handy device and best bang for your buck on tablets released as of June 2012.

The tablet is the perfect size, fast, nice appearance. However, I wish it was more compatible with other devices. I was using an Acer IConia 10" and I regret not having bought that one, in a smaller size. That one is more compatible, more similar to a netbook; Samsung Galaxy Tab 7.0 resembles a smart phone, instead.

I've wanted a Kindle Fire since they came out but really wanted expandable memory and would have liked the rear facing camera to use Skype.  The Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7" does everything the Kindle Fire does PLUS I can use at 32 GB micro SD card AND it has dual cameras for ONLY $50 more.  I don't have a smart phone so this little tablet gives me all of that on a bigger screen as long as I have Wi-Fi.  The camera quality is decent and looks great onscreen.  If I want "memorable" photo or video, I'll use my real camera but it's great for on the go.  If you've never used a smart phone or tablet, it takes a little time to figure out how to set up the home page and apps.  The touch keyboard is sensitive but I'm getting better at that.  I've only had it a few days but I've already set up gmail, imported contacts, calendars, photos and music. My kids have downloaded several apps.  With the Kindle app, it acts just like the Fire but you still can download other types of digital books.  Loving it so far!

Just bought his Samsung Tab(2) with ICE. This apparently comes only with 8 GB and now has Ice Cream Sandwich. Ice Cream Sandwich has disabled the option to move Applications to the SD card.  You are limited to the 8GB space for Apps, and can only use the SD card for storage of pictures, Mp3's and files.  This is a change from Froyo Android on Samsung devices where you could easily move them.  8GB will be a problem as you find more apps to install. My 16GB phone would have run out of space long ago.

Other than that it seems to be a fine device. My first experience with a 7". I am rethinking a 10" and even an iPad now.  At least with Apple you get the GB's you buy without the promise of "expandable" memory that is really limit to file storage.

Samsung should be ashamed since this is really a deception.

I just received my Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 and its more than words can express! The screen is bright and you can adjust the lighting if necessary. It has a mute option for the sound and the controls for every app is simple and seamless to catch on to. I think even a newbie to the tech world would get a kick out of this device.

It was love at first sight with the browser connecting to download apps. I obtained an app and all my files from gmail account (which can be synched). And everything is just as nice as it was on my HTC G2 phone. Even apps that I forgot about .. .but that is ok lol.

This device definitely tops off the list when it comes to my favorite device to use. I only had it for an hour and I am already taken aback by its swift change from activities I select for it to run. Even the camera (which is HD quality) takes super clear pics as if I was using my 14mp camera. I am not sure how the resolution correlates but if you ask me it is quite comparable.

Needless to say, and I do mean to repeat it - get this device especially if you are a gamer. The quality is so superb you will say goodbye to your  television gaming consoles and Hello Samsung Galaxy Tab 2!

Very impressed with the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2. Going in, did not want top-of-the-line, and did not want to be tethered to any one content provider. Moreover, I've got way too many philosophical problems with Apple, which IMO, does not offer value pricing to the average person. Instead, I sought out a nice balance between capability, features, and cost -- and found it with this Samsung tablet! The whole family has logged time on this reliable little monster, and we're all impressed. Good job with the product, and of course, with the outstanding Amazon service.

I have owned and used several android tablets and I have to say that this is a really nice buy for your money. I currently own the ASUS transformer T101 and was looking for a smaller screen size that still has Ice Cream Sandwich. I needed the device to be able to stream movies over my network at home or on the go, and let me VPN to my work site and monitor equipment. The Galaxy does both with ease, and is just the right size to take with me to lunch and catch up on the news with Pulse or Newsreader. Compared to a Fire or a Nook Tablet this thing just blows them out of the water. This is not Android with a locked down interface thrown on top....this is pure ICS goodness with a few Samsung touches that can be bypassed with ease. What that really means is that you can customize the tablet to fit your needs. Example: Don't like the built in browser? Install Dolphin and enjoy fast tabbed browsing. Don't like the built in Samsung Music Player? Install Google Music, Rhapsody, TuneIn radio or any other player no questions asked. Add Kindle and Nook apps and you are good for reading, and apps like PlayOn let you watch Amazon video and Hulu on the go. You can do some of these things with Fires and Nooks, but you can do all of them with the Galaxy. Add a 15 dollar 32G Mini-SD card and you have plenty of room for your stuff. I even like the TV app. So check this Tab out, you won't be disappointed.

Samsung has won over yet another satisfied customer!  I am absolutely in love with my tablet!  I will never buy an apple product again :D  The tablet is cute, functional, sleek and fits in my purse.  My only complaint is the size of the digital keyboard T___T  The keyboard is really small :(  BUUUUT the positive aspects out weigh the negative and make the tablet worth purchasing!  THANK YOU SAMSUNG!

I knew within 10 minutes of buying this device that it was getting returned.  The browser is s-l-o-w...  It took 8 seconds from the time I tapped a webpage until it actually started loading, then another 4-5 seconds before the page was rendered.  (Comparison -- on my iPad3, the page is rendered before my finger even gets out of the way of the screen.)  Even getting a 'new tab' screen takes 3-4 seconds to be ready to browse.  Then, with only 4 pages active, the browser crashed.  The TV Remote app seemed like a cool feature, but it worked poorly--missing numbers when changing TV channel, despite pointing the IR blaster right at the TV.

I actually liked the Android 4.0 ICS interface and the LCD is really great, but the underlying operating system here seems to be garbage.  Maybe the tablet did not have enough RAM also.  The device seemed to struggle a lot, and the UI hitches a lot, even with only 2 or 3 active applications.  I made sure to check that I had the latest software, which I did.  It's just disappointing.

About a month ago I got this tablet for my birthday.  I am very grateful to my wife and kids for this device.  The Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 is a media  device that comparable to the Kindle Fire in size and price.  It has bluetooth, GPS, front and rear facing cameras, a micro sd card slot, and the Google Play store, the Kindle Fire has none of these.

It is a wifi only device.  I like that because there is no monthly fee for a data plan.  This device can function well offline.  I have used it for offline GPS navigation, played games, read books, listened to music and podcasts that were previously downloaded onto an sd card.  The battery life is very good and can be tweaked to be great.  I love this device.

We have the latest Apple's iPad 3 at home but one thing I needed for my personal use was for email and having something that's more compact to carry around.  As much as 10" tablets are nice, they are still hefty and aren't the easiest thing to type on especially on non-Android system (lack of aftermarket keyboard option for example).  I've also added some in-depth review towards the bottom.

Pro's:
- Lightweight slim tablet
- Excellent speed with dual core 1GHz processor to run latest application with no problem
- Excellent device to watch HD videos on YouTube and Netflix
- Smooth screen transition and snappy response
- Great browsing and gaming experience
- Flash is enabled
- Good battery life overall
- Bluetooth enabled

Con's:
- Subpar pixel density including color saturation
- Some bloatware loaded by Samsung you can't uninstall
- Slim but very slippery to hold
- Proprietary data/charging plug like the iPad

What this Tablet Has:
- Latest Ice Cream Sandwich (aka ICS) operating system
- 3.5" audio jack
- Power button and volume up/down button
- SD card slot
- Infrared port
- Proprietary plug for charging and data sharing
- Front and rear camera
- Internal GPS
- Comes with A/C wall charger
- 8GB internal storage, option to add up to 32GB with SD memory card

What this Tablet Doesn't Have:
- HDMI, Firewire, or USB port of any kind
- Removable battery

Design Impression (4/5):
The design is slim and lightweight like many 7" tablets.  It's slim enough it'll slip into your back pocket but of course with some bulk due to its width/length which is a given.  Everything is flush in design except the power button and the volume button located on the sides while I found pressing those buttons by accident often.  It doesn't seem to stick out much but wish Samsung had made them a bit more flush with the case.  The back side isn't perfectly smooth but not enough to give you any sort of grip.  Holding it, I can feel it slipping sometimes.  I have large hands (XL for gloves) and even then the back side alone felt slippery which I'm going to buy silicone case for it soon.  Overall, it's simple and lightweight design if you prefer something compact.  Much easier to carry around than a 10" tablet; this will sure fit your backpack, purse or any small compartment without an issue.

Interface (5/5):
Ice Cream Sandwich aka ICS is the latest operating system.  What this means is slick but simplified interface that run smooth.  I do like the ICS a lot compared to Froyo, Gingerbread and Honeycomb I've used in the past (see the alphabetic naming pattern Google uses?).  ICS does tend to require more processing power but this tablet does so very well with this dual core.  Geeky talk but basically it has more horse power under its hood.  Screen transition is smooth, can add multiple screens while you can also drag icons together to put them in a folder.

Typing (4/5):
By default it doesn't actually come with the popular Swype.  I did already purchase SlideIT keyboard with my phone so I've downloaded and enabled it since (if you've purchased apps from Play store, you can re-download them with your Google account no problem).  In landscape mode, believe it or not, thumb typing is 'okay' and is a bit wide to type even for my large hands.  Portrait mode you can type pretty quickly.  Of course with the Swype like typing it could be done much faster.  I like Android's way of being able to install aftermarket keyboard.  This is where I found the iPad 3 to be bulky and cumbersome to type on as much as their keyboard is generally intuitive and easy to type.

Storage (4/5):
8GB is okay but with system and other application already taking space, that 8GB can be filled very quickly if you start to load pictures and videos.  Of course with this capability to add up to 32GB SD memory it's not a bad thing either.  Nowadays SD memory card is low in price and can store quite a bit (you may not need it the memory if you're only browsing, playing videos and adding just apps).

Speed (4/5):
Dual core, 1GHz processors which gives this tablet a great processing power.  Sure, it's not quad-core but it's hard to slow this tablet down.  The only time I noticed any sort of lag is playing game and try to open another application right after.  But the lag wasn't enough to disappoint.  It's not snappy like the iPad 3 but for $250?  One fast tablet that won't disappoint.

Screen (3.5/5):
The screen resolution is something to be desired.  If you're using a tablet for the first time you obviously won't notice a difference.  But if you already have a device like the iPad or device with better screen resolution that pack in more pixels, you'll notice right away it's an okay display.  The color saturation also seems to be lacking and could use some help with the contrast.  The icons also doesn't use the whole screen; probably for the reason being so people can hold the tablet which will end up putting their thumbs on part of the screen.  That could all be corrected downloading apps like "Go Launcher" which will give you a customized interface with all sorts of skins and wallpapers that are free also.  Again, for a $250 tablet it's not a bad screen either.

Audio (5/5):
Loud.  It'll even give you a warning when you max out the volume about a hearing damage.  Though the speakers are located only on one side, you can hear the audio perfectly fine with TV playing in the background.  It maybe a plus if you like to use tablet and other device as a music player.  No audio distortion when playing music and movies.

Video (5/5):
I tested HD videos with Netflix, YouTube and few other application to see the HD quality.  Excellent pictures and smooth transition.  No ghosting effect or lag in any sort of way watching the latest video including action flicks.  More details on the application itself will be in the detailed reviews below.

Camera (3/5):
I'm not going into any details here but don't expect a superb quality photos and videos.  Cheaper phones and tablet do not come with a great lens and a sensor.  But to play around with it and take general pictures, it'll do just fine.  But don't try to take family portrait and expect a great photo.  Won't happen!

Connectivitity (5/5):
This tablet seem to connect to any router very quickly open or secured.  Once the credentials are entered and remembered, the tablet will connect in seconds which is refreshing.  It seems to pick up more Wifi signals compared to my phone which may have to do with the size of the device.  No dropped connections so far.  One minor issue reconnecting but turning on/off the Wifi solved the issue quickly and hasn't happened since.

Battery Life (4/5):
Not bad at all.  I tested and played a game for few hours and only drained to 60%.  This is with battery save mode on and screen brightness at about 70%.  Be sure to let the battery drain completely first and charge it in full.  From about 3% to 100% charge took about 3.5 hours using the A/C wall charger that came with the device.  Some people say that's slow but considering something as big as iPad 3, it's pretty fast.

*** Apps ***
I'll breakdown some of the apps that come with the Galaxy Tab 2.0 7" tablet and their overall impression.  I feel this is where the tablet shines and even with a mediocore screen, it does give a better impression overall.

YouTube:
Slick little interface on this tablet with subscribed and featured videos that scroll sideways with a 3D look.  Very responsive and what I personally like is that clicking on the video doesn't make it full screen automatically like the iPad.  Maybe some people will prefer this but I like seeing the small screen along with any other featured videos.  HD movies and clips play without a problem.  Combined with an excellent audio, you can play it anywhere.

Google Maps:
This Wifi version has GPS.  If you have the ability to tether to your phone, it's a big plus as you can run the tablet as a GPS navigation device.  For some reason, the 'street view' picture quality is horrible on this device.  Not sure if they did this on purpose but the only time I find that the pictures seem like it was taken with a 1-mega pixel camera.  But the interface and browsing in the map is smooth and responsive.

Calendar:
If you use Google calendar it will notify any tasks/appointments scheduled and while giving you an excellent interface.  You can add it as a widget also so that's a plus if you often use your phone to schedule meetings, etc.

Gmail:
Another great Google product with slick interface.  Split into two screens with inbox/folders and the right pane for reading and replying.

Netflix:
Amazing HD quality and also connects to the server VERY fast on Wifi network.  Even skipping through the videos it'll resume playing within 2-3 seconds which I found to be a great speed like playing on a regular computer.  One negative here though; scrolling through the homepage of multiple video screen lags a bit with this device.  Not a big deal but a minor annoyance.

Browser:
Default browser like many browser on Android is very basic.  Some people may like it, some people may not.  But of course you can run Dolphin, Opera Mini, etc all free from the Play Market.  Everyone has their different taste when it comes to browsers so test them out to your liking.

*** Some In-Depth Tech Review ***
This is where it gets a bit nerdy but reserved for those expecting more in-depth review.  As we all know, the Android vs. iOS debate as well as what this $250 tablet offers.  I've used the iPad 3 for the last few months and I can honestly say this Galaxy tablet does well for it's price and in some ways if you're on a budget it also won't disappoint.

Interface:
By default you have this 1/2" empty screen on both sides with the stock ICS.  So I ended up downloading the "Go Launcher" which I've used on my phone forever.  Same as "ADW" launcher (costs money for this one) it allows you to customize the interface including icons and wallpapers.  You can cram say seven columns and rows of icons on the tablet without a problem.  I haven't read anything about a custom ROM but hopefully there is one out there already if not sooner.  I have CM7.0 on my phone overlocked by 160MHz or so and love how much it saves on storage let alone not having all sorts of bloatware you cannot uninstall by default.

Screen:
The screen, I've tried adjusting the contrast with another app but as a photographer I can see some people getting very picky.  Color saturation, strong black and white isn't all too impressive with this device.  iPad 3 blows this tablet out of water when it comes pixel density but for its price that's a given for either tablets.

Google Accounts:
Yes, if you have already downloaded and purchased from another device using your Google account, all contents can be re-downloaded including paid apps.  This is one thing I love about the Android system.  Hopefully that will not change!  Everything syncs seemlessly including Gmail, YouTube and any other associated accounts.

GPS:
I needed the GPS function to use with my car as I drive a lot.  Running Google Maps but often times Waze to know any accidents, traffic, etc (as Google stopped doing live traffic awhile ago).  I'm also a radar/laser detector enthusiast (run Escort Redline) so having another counter measure device is also a plus.  Tethered to my phone, I can run Waze and Google Maps just fine and gives a better view while driving.  It's really all I use it for while driving and one of the reasons why I snagged this $250 tablet.  If I want to pull over and find places to eat, take my daughter to a new park, etc it's another great way to do so on this device.  If you can  tether to another live connection, it's a great tablet unlike spending $100+ on a Garmin (as much as I used to love Garmin).  Very accurate GPS for the most part with the Wifi and GPS enabled at the same time.

Battery Life:
Turn on the 'battery saver' mode on.  Noticed a huge difference in saving battery.  Before it felt like the unit was discharging within 5-6 hours.  Now I feel pretty confident it can go up to the manufacturer's claim; at leat around 9-10 hours with a light use.  Charging isn't bad at all.  iPad 3 takes forever to charge on the other hand BUT the thing lasts all day playing games and videos.  I haven't compared the specs but assuming it has a bigger battery and ways to save energy.  I haven't ran JuiceDefender on this device yet even though I've purchased the Ultimate edition awhile back.  Should be just as good though.

Proprietary Plug:
Not sure why Samsung opted for the 16-pin connector but looks almost identical to that of iPad but it's not.  Maybe because the mini-USB tends to lose connection and isn't as solid in design when plugged in?  Not sure but then again aftermarket cables are cheap nowadays on Amazon or other sites so not a big deal IMO.  The plug does seem to snap-in really well and is better than charging the iPad where it can be somewhat wobbly at times.

There's so much more to list but if you have any question feel free to leave a comment!  Overall I'm happy with the purchase.  It'll make a great gift as well.

I had begun to be interested in the world of tablets, and I started to look for a small, budget conscious device, and I found the Galaxy Tab 2 7 Inch, and I am pretty astounded by the quality and value of this device, it does not mimic the cheapness found in similar tablets of this price range, with a highly responsive screen, full Android 4.0, and a good build. Also being a 7 inch device it is very easy to hold with one hand, and it is very light, it is definitely a good choice for those who are on the move often. The device is not perfect though, with a few hiccups.

Performance

The device responds quickly to commands, plays media flawlessly, and runs every app without incident, but after a week of using the device, there was an odd slow down of the home screen that occurred for about 5 minutes, I did not get the issue again since, that is the only issue I have had with the performance. I think it was the stock TouchWiz interface, I have since switched to GOLauncher, it's great.

Battery Life

The battery life is great so far, after being charged to 100% I got 2 days of use without charging, tasks on the device included a little web browsing, browsing and installing apps, and some video/picture taking.

Networking

The device is WiFi only; I have had no issues with it, reception is no different than the other WiFi devices in my household.

Interface

The device uses Samsung's TouchWiz interface; which to my guess is a modified 4.0 interface, it is a nice interface, without lag, but the lock screen seems a little boring, I will probably look into using the default 4.0 interface, or something else.

Screen

The screen is very good in my opinion, it displays content nicely, and it is very responsive. There have been a few instances where I have sworn I tapped the screen and nothing happened, it could be my error, or the device's.

Audio

The device features two speakers at the bottom of the device, which sound nice but are not the best I have ever heard. The microphone is located at the top of the device near the 3.5 mm headphone jack, from a little use of the Google voice command feature, I have found no issues.

Cameras

The device features a front and rear camera, the rear camera is 3 MP which takes decent photos, while the front camera is a VGA camera that is good for video chat, it is no SLR camera, but has good cameras.

Ports

The Tab 2 features a 3.5mm headphone jack at the top, Micro SD slot with door, proprietary Samsung USB port at the bottom. The most interesting is a built in IR Blaster located on the right side, which is supposed to be used with the included Peel Remote app ( I had to manually update the app before being able to use it) which worked very well with controlling my devices (LCD TV, Sony Surround system, Comcast DVR). My only true gripe is the lack of a Micro USB or micro HDMI port to be used with projecting content onto a TV screen, one must purchase Samsung's adapter to do so.

Buttons

The Tab 2 features only 2 buttons, which are located on the right side of the device, the first button is the usual lock/wake button, and a volume up/down button, I would of liked to see a Home button, but the 4.0 interface takes care of that.

Build Quality

The Tab 2 has a solid hard plastic build, the back of the device features a soft metal like shell that feels good when held.

Pre-installed Apps

This is one of my gripes with the Tab 2, the device comes pre-installed with a suite of bloatware, that cannot be installed as far as I have discovered, I prefer the default Android apps, with apps I choose to install. It does come with some useful apps such as Netflix and Kindle bookstore.

Overall, it is a fantastic device, with a few hiccups that may only bother a select group of users, being a first time owner, I cannot compare this tablets to others personally.

I've been an Android user for a long time...I was looking for a tablet to read some books and have a bigger screen for some of my applications since I'm a computer tech and I work using remote software and other applications...after a lot of research and having a Samsung Galaxy S2 phone for a year (and extremely happy with it) I decided to go for the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0...

Had it original for one day...second day I decided to root (running original stock ICS rooted) it to get the same advantages I had in my phone; like: CPU control, able to dim the screen lower than factory settings, uninstall bloatware, etc...

After all the tweaks battery lasts 2.5 days (average of 4 hours a day of reading, browsing, playing games...plus receiving emails and using software for text messages), software works like a charm with no lag or freeze...widgets work great, been using the stock keyboard for now but looking for a more detailed one...charging time is normal for a large battery...screen size is great and device not heavy at all...screen resolution and colors are very clear and nice with a lot of details...tried a couple of movies and hi def pictures in it with great results...everything is really good...

My advice and only concern use headphones for movies or landscape games because of the speakers placed at the bottom of the device.

Overall 5 stars and great device!!!

I received this as an anniversary gift and what a wonderful gift! Not having a smart phone it took a little bit getting used to the touch screen, but being able to expand it and just using it made it a breeze to operate. I have only had it about a month and have already read about a book a day or more. It would have been nice to have a few more instructions with it as I still haven't figured out some of the applications...........but I will! Bought the memory card as well just in case I run out of room. Would recommend this to anyone!

I have owned several Android tablets but this is my first running 4.0. The OS is so intuitive and runs very well on this device. The option for expandable storage via SDHC card cannot be overstated. It is such a marvelous thing to have a card for movies and a card for my day-to-day things like music separately.

I don't understand why some users are complaining about the battery as it is one thing that I have been most impressed by. I use the device quite often and never have to charge it more than once every other day.

The form factor is marvelous and it really makes it a pivotal piece of my morning commute and is less onerous to drag around than my Transformer.

The device has been a delight and the freedom of Android is really marvelous with regards to operating efficiently on a tablet.

Thanks Samsung!

This is a great product, I bought it to use for email, occasional web surfing and reading books. All of the things I wanted I got and I have even been doing some other things with apps that I didn't expect to do.

The Smart Remote app is one thing I thought I would use, but it doesn't work well with my Samsung HDTV. So I haven't used it.  ??

This is a great tablet. It performs better than i expected and i couldn't be happier with the decision to buy it. The camera takes better than my canon digital camera (ive already had 5 people comment how clear and vivid the pictures are) and the video quality is great as well! Finally found the tablet for me.  Have an iPad in the family; too large for me, I prefer the 7" form factor. Have tried earlier Android tablets, found them to be lacking.  Tried the Kindle Fire, good device but missing some key features.

The size, price, features and performance of the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 are the exact fit for me.  I'm not going to rehash all of the pros/cons as they have been talked about quite a bit here.  But this tablet is smooth, reasonably fast, the screen is good for the price, it has access to the larger Andoid app market, and Ice Cream Sandwich is a huge leap forward for Android.

It may not be "the best" tablet money can buy, but it definitely hits the "sweet spot" of price/features/performance.

The GPS works great, but as said on other reviews, it works better when you have an active Wifi connection. The TV remote app works great and it was a breeze to set up, all in all its a fun function to play around with. I also have some sections in my house where Wifi is not as reliable, but the tab managed to get a lock and stay connected so I'm impressed with the antenna. The audio from the speakers is surprisingly loud although not that crisp. Also the option of having two cameras is great! As expected the front camera isn't that great but for video chatting it's just what you need and the back camera is better than the one I have on my phone so I'm happy with that. I haven't tested bluetooth or the headphone jack, but I expect they will work great. Finally for the specs you get the price is unbeatable!

Have owned an iPhone for 2+ years now, an Android 2.2 phone - and recently bought the Kindle Fire for my wife. I don't want to be locked or tied down - which is my experience with the Apple OS.  The OS just works ... but I wanted more freedom. I am agnostic when it comes to operating systems.
Here are my assessments on the Tab 2 after almost a week.

Pluses:
1. Screen is bright even at 50% which is my current setting.
2. 2 cameras - front and back. Though I won't be using this for video calls soon, it is good to have the flexibility. For video calls, the resolution is good enough. I still plan on using a real digital camera for videos and stills. I want to have full control over the ISO, shutter speed,  aperture etc.
3. The micro-SD slot is a big bonus for me. My wife's Fire did not have this. For my use case - which is keeping all my files local, I need that expandability. I use google drive only for backup.
4. Price is very competitive over the Fire (which I bought a week apart). Again, my wife wants an easy to use reader with the option of other 'screened' apps - so the Fire is perfect for her. For $50 more, I get 2 cameras, expandability - and more configurable experience.
5. I was able to install the Amazon App Store (app). This will replace the Samsung one which I didn't find too appealing for someone who already has an existing Prime account. Now I get a free app a day!
6. (Update) I just installed the Amazon Apps Appstore ... which basically gives me access (same look and feel) to the Fire's ecosystem of apps.

Cons: (Not weighed)
1. Charging is pretty slow - I am just used to my iPhone and Android phone with less than 2000mAH batteries - hence, faster to recharge. The Tab 2 came with a 4000+mAH battery - hence, it takes longer.
2. Out of the box, you cannot load apps on the SD card. This is a limitation on the OS.
3. Unless you change your power settings, the default settings will drain the Tab 2 pretty quick.
4. The Samsung apps cannot be uninstalled individually. Some are good - others are so-so - luckily, they don't take up too much space - so until I find a replacement for all of the individual bloatware, I will keep them.
5. The power switch/select button is too close to the volume controls. They should be spaced further apart as I have often inadvertently pressed it while simply holding the tab or changing the volume.
6. Samsung uses a proprietary connector (unlike the Fire which uses a standard micro-USB).
7. When charging, there is no indicator light to show that the battery is indeed charging (unlike the Fire). You would need to turn the tab on - and verify it is indeed charging.
8. This is lighter than the Fire --- but still, for a 7 inch tablet, I expected something a little bit lighter.

I am being picky here ... wanted to be as objective as possible.

I did look at the Acer and Lenovo tablets over at BB. The Lenovo would constantly flicker - while the Acer had no power. But based on reviews and ratings (and the fact that I get ICS 4.0 at $249), I went with the Tab 2. For my use cases, this is the perfect tablet for me.

I am not the type to write reviews but this tablet has been such an positive experience for me I have to share my experience. First and foremost size was my primary driving factor. I didn't want the standard 10' tablet. I wanted something bigger than my droid cell phone that was easy to hold and easy the hand to type on the keyboard without having to strain or remove my hands from holding the tablet. This does that perfectly! It was easy to set up my gmail account and sync all other email accounts along with my calendar. The camera and video camera work great and deliver quality resolutions images and there is pre-install editing software for both photos and videos. The web browser took a bit of time to figure out how bookmarks are set up and managed but aside from that it works great. The speakers are way more than I expected out of a tablet. This is a dual core processor tablet which is reflected in how well it responds when navigating from app to app or within a specific application. I was able to use the tablet for extended periods of time with heavy camera and video usage without having the battery drain on me. I would say I had the tablet on all day while traveling in Manhattan and was constantly taking photos and video from early am till late pm and the battery still had life to it. Very impressive. Navigation is easy from app to app to settings with easy access touch screen options for viewing active/open apps or navigating to the task killer (nice feature) to quickly getting to settings. The wifi works great in detecting wifi networks. The Samsung comes with a feature to track your tablet should it get lost/stolen.

Things that could be improved (but not deal breakers). In BRIGHT outdoor sun, viewing the screen image is difficult depending on the angle, even with the brightest screen setting set (which is easily accessed from screen).  It would also have been nice to have a USB port to easily transfer photos/file/etc to and from a flash drive (although the existing power cable easily connects to a USB port on your computer to get around this).

Side note: My first couple of days after setting up the wifi connection in my home, the internet connection would repeatedly drop for a few seconds and immediately reconnect. After a bit of online research I found out it was not the tablet but rather the channel my router was set to. This was easily resolved by installing a wifi analyzer app from Google Play, seeing what channels had less usage in my area and switching to one of those channels. My tablet has internet connection and has yet to drop the connection.

I really am very impressed with this gadget/tablet and would recommend it to anyone.

I have been using the tablet for about a month now. I ordered both the playbook and the tab since their specs are very similar. I liked the Tab for reasons mentioned below and returned the Playbook after a week. I'm quite happy with it's performance, if not mind blown. Its definitely worth the money I paid but I still see a lot of scope for improvement.

Form factor: The biggest pro for the Tab I'd say is the weight. Even without getting into the specifics of the OS the Tab wins hands down compared to the Playbook given its much lighter build and better screen. The Playbook has a much solid build and the rubber finish on its back feels much better in your hands but it's a little too heavy for comfort.

Display: Speaking of the screen, the 1024x 600 display is vibrant and sharp. One of the best ones out there. It a joy to watch HD videos on this baby. The display is definitely much sharper than the Playbook. The auto brightness wouldn't work properly out of the box - the screen was always way too dim. But I got an over-the-air update 2 weeks after the release date and it's working fine now. I haven't noticed any other changes from the software update.

Battery: The battery is also good. This is my first tablet so I don't really know how long these things are expected to last. Checking my email 3-4times a day and about an hour of browsing/video means I need to charge it once every 90hours. Reading books with the display inverted (white letters on a black page) means you can go for two days without having to recharge.

Keyboard: One of the best things about a 7" tablet is you can type with two hands in portrait mode as if it were a smart phone. The stock keyboard is really miserable though. It's extremely slow and the auto correct behaves like a 5year old baby. I use the free version of GO keyboard and it's just brilliant. If not for this I'd have returned the Tab. There's a bug in the software that doesn't allow you to move the cursor to the second last line when composing email - which leaves some unnecessary space between the content and my signature. And removing the two extra lines takes more time than writing out the entire email since the keyboard doesn't have arrow keys. If you use the Tab for writing emails a lot you'll find this really frustrating. God bless Go keyboard! It is not only much faster and has a better layout, it has a better auto-correct (though not as good as that of iOS) and the much needed arrow keys.

Speakers: The speakers are loud and clear, with two separate speakers at the bottom. This however is a bad design - putting both the speakers next to one another. Isn't the whole point of stereo having one on each side? Unless you're holding the tab upside down in portrait mode you're blocking one or both speakers. The playbook does a much better job here with two front facing speakers. No wonder playing NFS on the Playbook gets your adrenaline going. The Tab on the other hand doesn't even have a supported version of NFS. Blah!

OS: This is my first Android device. And I'm pretty satisfied with the performance. The device is responsive and navigation is fairly intuitive. The device does slow down after continued usage though and a quick reboot brings it back to pace. Roughly 600MB of RAM is under use all the time - I'm not sure what causes the slowdown. I wish there were something like a favorites menu to access the most frequently used apps without having to put them on one of the home screen. The Playbook OS 2.0 is clean and minimalistic and does the job. But if you want to go beyond just emails and work, you would want to choose an Android or iOS device. One of my main reasons for choosing the Tab over the Playbook was the android eco-system.

Email: The default email client is buggy (like I mentioned before). The mail widget seldom doesn't respond when you click on unread emails. You have to open your inbox and then open the unread mail. The unread mail count on the email icon doesn't update when you've read your email, which is also really nagging. The Playbook has a much better email client; that's BB's home ground after all!
Music Player: Nothing out of ordinary. You can scroll down easily by the letters on the right side column for songs/artists only, but not for albums. I don't know why. The music player widget is convenient way to accessing your music player but the playlist always scrolls back to the top. This is really irritating when you have a long playlist with hundreds of songs and have to scroll down each time.

Really smooth with docs. Renders pdfs superfast, even the bulky ones with thousands of pages. I'm a grad student and this was my main reason behind getting the Tab.

I could go on and on. But I've hopefully touched base on the most important points.

tldr; The Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 still has a few kinks but it's the best 7inch tablet available in the market as of now if you're looking for a tablet for more than just reading. If its ebooks you're after you might as well stick the Kindle.

I bought this recently.  It is a fine tablet, except for one MAJOR flaw. You will never be able to do anything with your SD card other than use it to hold pictures and videos.  Even books cannot go on the card.  Instead, Samsung creates a fake SD card space inside your limited 4gb free internal memory, and any ap that wants to access the SD card is sent there.  I am unclear if this can be circumvented by rooting the device.  As far as I can tell, even those aps that use music and videos may have a hard time accessing the sd card to get to them.  So far I have only been able to copy stuff to the card via a PC and then if it is music or video the stock built-in ap can see it. But I am not sure even the normal music and video aps (like podcasting aps) can even write to the card (although that may be something I can overcome, I am not sure).

Anyway, I am forced to describe the SD card feature on this tablet as essentially useless.  And I think most of the 5 star raters are people who have not yet discovered the SD card limitation.

For those who think differently:

In answer to questions concerning their SD Card, here is the answer direct from Samsung on their support site:

We apologize for the delay in addressing your question. If we are understanding you correctly, are you asking if you can copy/store apps on an SD card? If this is the case, apps can only stored on the internal memory only. The only thing that can be stored on the SD card is pictures, music & video files.

Android OS (you have a lot more customization, widgets, full web, easier to download and move files unlike the walled garden that is iOS)

Remote ( Has the peel remote app and an IR which makes it compatible with most TVs and home theaters).
Price ($250 for all these feautres is not a lot, and considering it's only $50 more than the kindle and you're getting so much more this makes it an amazing buy) In some sense your getting more than the $499 new iPad 3.

Cons
Performance ( High end 3d games can stutter every now and then).
Screen (Small for long movie watching, but this can be rectified with a samsung hdmi adapter and then hook it up to the TV.)

Android 4.0.3 (Ice Cream Sandwich)
Externel Storage

Personally I prefer e-ink Kindle 3 (aka Kindle keyboard), which I have for 1.5 years, but in two weeks after release of Kindle Fire I bought it too, because my son, who is medical student, wanted something compact to read his color textbooks. I'm not a fan of gadgets, at least I do not like to have more than really necessary, but I'm quite experienced with them and my friends bring them to me to set up very often. So, I played a lot with different Android phones and tablets as well as with different IOS ones, like iphones, Ipods and Ipads. I do like Apple products quality, IQ and interface but for me they look like handicapped ones comparing to Android devices - no USB host and memory extension, limited number of supported file types, need of iTunes to copy files (no chance to download anything from other computer without it when you are travelling), so sometimes it is even not a lack of features, it is lack of freedom. Actually it relates to Kindle Fire in some aspects, too )))
Anyway, I wouldn't buy this tablet, but I'm going for vacation and it seems that it will be necessary not only check my e-mails, but to read some documents and to answer, my smarphone is not very convenient for this  and I do not want to carry my 13" laptop, so I decided to give this tablet (Samsung Galaxy Tab 2, WiFi, 8Gb) a try. I played with it for two days and may say the following:

GOOD

Screen: Excellent. Very similar to Kindle Fire, though of different type, probably viewing angles are a bit different, but anyway very good and comfortable screen for reading, browsing and watching movies.

Battery: Excellent. I fully charged it and it worked for 10 hours 43 minutes during two days, when I checked it yesterday (there is a battery meter in the Settings). Today it worked for about 20 min and switched off completely at 5%. I think that 11 hour is very good for first cycle of charging, usually it became a little better (10-15%) after 3-4 cycles of training. This 11 hours were active browsing, downloading applications, reset to  factory defaults, WiFi was on 80% of time, screen brightness - 30-40%, manual. Overnight it eats 2-3% in sleep mode, so the battery is really good. UPDATE for battery - the battery meter shows the time from the last charge of the tablet. Mine restarted after reset to defaults, but anyway, its estimated work time was more than 10 hours, it's why I desided it shows real operation time.

OS: Good. I did not notice any significant difference in speed and touch sensitivity over regular Cyanogens, Kindle or IOS, but I'm tolerable enough to some delays. Actually, after initial set up we do not work with OS, we work with applications and widgets, so I do not care what type of OS is hidden behind, as soon as it is stable. And I do not care if it requires 10 sec to find an icon and to start application, if after that it works okay without lags for hour. 10 sec may kill some guys, but I usually survive.  But it is not the case, Tab 2 OS is intuitive and responsive. The only thing I did not like - it is impossible to set two and more languages in Samsung keyboard, so I had to install additional keyboard. Well, it is stupid, any Samsung Android smartphone has this feature.

Applications. It seems that many applications are not optimized for ICS. I live in different country, but I usually set US as home country for the devices bought here - sometimes it helps to avoid stupid software limitations. But Skype could not be downloaded from Google Play, it told it is not available for my country. Probably they track IP, but even the version, downloaded from 1mobile market told that the device is not yet certified for it. Anyway, Skype works perfectly.

Quality: Good. It seems that it is assembled very well. A bit plastic, of course, but I put it into Roocase leather case immediately and now who cares what is inside?

WiFi: Good. No problems with connection to office, home, and restaurant WiFi networks.

BAD

No external LED battery indicator. Or it is hidden somewhere inside the case, but all the other buttons and connections are accessible. So you have no idea, if it is plugged in, is it charging or not and is it charged completely before you switch it on. Not very convenient. Sometimes you even could not see on screen battery indicator when the device is charging and off. And charging time is very long - at least 5 hours (from 5 to 100%). But its because of good battery )))

Proprietary cable. Well, it would be probably okay, but supplied cable is very short, it seems it will be very difficult to handle device when it is charging.

In general, very good tablet. I'm not going to use it for a long time, and after I'll be back from this travel, I'll give it to my son to replace Kindle Fire, which he will sell to his mates. At least it's what I recommended to him, though he likes his Fire and have laptop for any serious work. I'd recommend this tablet to anyone who wants good multimedia device. Frankly, all this stuff, including Ipads and other 10" tablets, is mostly for entertainment, if you want to DO anything, regular cheap netbook is better.
