I periodically review the comments on this product, and am disappointed in some of the reasons given for providing low ratings; therefore I am submitting the following general information and suggestions.

The following is a response from Michael S. to negative feedback on the SGT 2 7, recently published by an individual on Amazon.

Michael is obviously a very savy guy, as his comments provide numerous tweaks that every SGT 2 owner (and most ICS users) should be vividly aware of. This info will truly rectify most problems and help you get the most out of your SGT 2 7".
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Edited by the author on May 2, 2012 6:55:32 PM PDT
Michael S says:

Right now my Tab 2 stats show the device is going 2 days 14 hours on a battery charge with 43% left. I use the Tab a few hours a day web surfing, doing research, checking and responding to emails. There are a number of ways to save juice so I'll mention a few that I use; which some, all, or none, may be applicable to others' situations:

#1 - Go into "Settings", then "Wi-Fi". At the top right-hand side there is a icon of "3 bars and a small triangle" (basically an option button) click on it and when the "Advance" box shows on the screen, click it. Then click on "Keep Wi-Fi on during sleep" then check "only when plugged in". This will turn off the Wi-Fi when in sleep mode & running on the batteries. I use a login pattern to unlock my Tab and every time I unlock the screen it states "establishing Wi-Fi connection" I'm using WEP2 encryption on my network and the Tab starts Wi-Fi within seconds of waking from sleep. If one wants their Tab running multiple apps and to always have the most up-to-date information "pushed" to the device even while sleeping and running in battery mode, then one has to trade battery life for always-on information. The Wi-Fi will be active in sleep mode when it is plugged in. If you Always want the Wi-Fi off when in sleep mode then select "Never" instead of "Only when plugged in".

#2 - I mostly use my Tab at home or at the office. I have both Wi-Fi network settings saved in the device, so I turned off "Network Notification" in the same area as # 1 above. This stops the Tab from periodically searching the Wi-Fi Network for "Open Networks". If I go out and want to connect to a Wi-fi hot spot, I simply turn this feature back on.

Note: When you are in "Settings" and "Wi-Fi" mode you will notice that periodically the device shows "Scanning". Because you are in Wi-Fi mode, it scans to refresh the wi-fi networks its found, to help you connect to them. It does not continue to scan the network after you leave Wi-Fi settings, unless "Network Notification" is turn on, although the scan intervals may be different between the two modes.

#3 - In "Settings" then " Location Services" make sure "Use GPS Satellites" is unchecked. This requires more battery and a clear view of the sky, and is really only useful outside.

Those 3 settings will make a difference in battery consumption, and will not affect most people's use of the Tablet, although others' actual mileage may vary

#4 - In addition, as I stated earlier, I mostly use my Tab 2 at work or home, so I always know where I am. Therefore, I also turn off "Use Wireless Networks" (Found in the "Location Service" section). This use Wi-Fi to help determine your location for Maps and such. If a App or Apps are running in the background and they have a location feature, this stop them from updating while the Tab is sitting idle, or your while your using other apps.

#5- Because I use my Tab mostly at work or home and I know where I am, I usually turn-off GPS. Click on the "Clock" icon at the lower right-hand side, and then uncheck "GPS". If I ever need it, I quickly turn it back on.

#6- In "Settings" "Account and Sync" I have "Auto Sync" turned off. I turn it on when it's plugged in and then have it Sync. Then I turn if off once its done charging and back on battery power. I usually sync only 1-2 per week, same as my Skyrocket.

#7- Next, in "Settings" then "Developer Options" (I don't run a bunch of Apps and don't use a lot of "Notifications") so I check the box "Do not Keep Activities" This means when I leave an App, ICS closes the app instead of letting it run in the background, possibly sucking more juice. I saved this one for last, as it impacts the tablet operation the most. If a person uses "Notifications" or likes to multitask with many apps running and want to quickly switch between them, then thus option is not useful. What it does do is free one up from going into "Task Manager" and closing down a bunch of Apps you thought you closed but were only minimized when you exit-ed the App.

#8- Lastly, Usually the biggest drain on the battery is the display. Currently under "Battery" in "Settings" the Display has consumed 65%, with the next closest item "Internet" at 19%, and "Android System" & "Android OS" at 5% each, with everything else at less than 5% combined. Unfortunately, I'm unable to recommend the "Auto-Display" mode, as for me, it makes the display too dark most of the time (click on the "Clock" icon and then check the "Auto" box to engage).

I keep the display setting at about 20-25% as I mostly use the tab 2 indoors. As mentioned above, others' actual mileage may vary with Auto-Display turned on. I use Auto-Display on my Skyrocket, as I use it equally indoors and outdoors. When indoors, I find Auto-Display too dark also, but I live with it because when using the Skyrocket outdoors I find the Auto-Display is a must to see the display in bright sunlight, and therefore watch the battery drain accordingly. To compensation for this, I replaced the stock battery (1,850 mAh) with an extended battery (2,250 mAh) for a 22% capacity increase. This is obviously not a option on the Tab 2.(END OF QUOTE)
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Let me add, in addition, If one buys this tablet expecting to play graphics intensive action games then that person will be disappointed. That is not what these 7" tablets are designed for. Also, be aware that this is a transition period in the development of Android software; wherein developers are having to convert their programs to the new operating system (ICS), and this has resulted in some minor problem being experienced on all phones and tablets converting to ICS. The fact is, however that ICS is a big improvement over the preceding Operating Systems; and the Galaxy Tab 2 7" is a very good tablet for the money. THEY ALL HAVE SOME LIMITATIONS!

Hope this is of help!! I know it was to me, and I own five tablets.

I had high hopes for this device but, after using it for almost a month now, I am returning it because, to say the least, it simply fails to perform.

I don't know whether it's ICS or, maybe I've got some faulty hardware (though, I doubt the latter)?  However, the device, for me, has been CONSTANTLY plagued with performance/memory issues!  I hardly ever even keep the WIFI running or the browser open, and kill any/all apps as soon as I'm done with them.  Nonetheless, this thing is slow as hell!  Typically, I use it for very light tasks, such as, using the stock, Samsung music app, and/or reading via the Kindle app.  These two get the most use, by far.  Regardless, should I try and run another app, (for a total of 2 apps!!!) simultaneously, the device lags tremendously.  It becomes painstakingly slow for me to even swipe to the next screen, much less anything with the least amount of complexity.  The device has also made random crashes/restarts.

FWIW, I did install the update (for whatever, ICS or Samsung OS) immediately upon release, which did nothing regarding my experience.  I even followed some advice I found on forums pertaining to adjustments in the Settings under Developer Options, which also made no difference.

It has been a highly frustrating experience because I want so much for this thing to work.  The size, for me, would be perfect, able to fit right into my back pocket.

Other notes:
-I also find the keyboard pretty awful, and the cursor to have a mind of its own when trying to edit text, etc.  I did install Thumb Keyboard, which was a major improvement, though I still had the cursor issues to deal with.
-Battery life could certainly be better, as it struggles to go a day with only the display on, running a simple app like Kindle, and no WIFI.
-The speakers suck compared to those in my Samsung Galaxy SII (Skyrocket).

Beware:
-The 7" form factor!  I wasn't aware beforehand that I couldn't run all the apps I do on my phone on this device; another downer.
-I also didn't realize I'd need to buy all new cables/adapters for this device after having bought them all for my phone:  HDMI, USB female, etc.  The cable used here is not a mini-USB as I had anticipated.  I only mention as a Caveat Emptor, as this was the least of my concerns; I'd have been happy to buy all new cables had this device lived up to the performance my phone offers at half the size.

Should I tempt/convince myself to try another one to see if, in fact, my hardware was possibly faulty, I will obviously change my review.  I have been reading over all the reviews here on Amazon, however, and most of the positive reviews, I find to be short and sweet, and without having spent much time actually using the product, i.e., posted after a single day of use!  It seems they may not have given the device a proper test period or, are still just so happy to have joined the Tab Club for an affordable price, that perhaps they are overlooking its shortcomings? I bought mine at Best Buy.  Performance is good, price was right (or so I thought).  Everything is good except for one important aspect (for me):  With Android 4, the SD card is not good for anything but storing data.  This means you can't move your apps to the SD card. The internal storage is 8GB but after formatting and the operating system, you're left with a little over half of the internal storage remaining.  While you may put a thousand small apps on the internal storage, the quantity goes down drastically if you load larger apps and their associated data.  For example, the navigation app is larger than, say, a slot machine game, and the map data can be huge if you want to have a bunch of states loaded.  I'm not sure if the map data can be moved to the SD card and have the app know where to find it or not.  There are no instructions about how to use the space.

Samsung should have pushed Google to enable moves to SD card like the earlier versions of Android supported, or provided more internal storage.  And at least make it known to a potential buyer about this limitation.

...but, it doesn't solve world hunger.

I guess I raised my expectations too much. What made me decide to return is, for one, its (very) poor battery life which lasts me only about an hour of web browsing, watching video, listening to music, and playing games. Perhaps it's the device, perhaps the Android Ice Cream Sandwich, perhaps it's the general architecture, I would not not know.

I admit that I totally love this toy, and it would be the best electronic gadget I have ever owned -- except Samsung's dismal service and support completely suck the joy out of it. Unless you own the top of the line product and are signed up for the most extortionate data plan you can find, Samsung's attitude is "thanks for the money, now F off."

Here are a couple of things you should be ready for:

1. The included software will not work with your device. Not "will be hard to figure out" -- you will get an error message saying "this device is not supported." They could have just put a message that said "F You, Chump! <click OK>". Also, the software [Kies]it will take 15 minutes to install, probably crash several times, and blow up every file association on your computer, making recovering from being told you can't use their software into a nightmare.

2. Want a software update? Try CyanogenMod. You'll have to root it to get one. Fortunately, their sloppy workmanship also makes it fairly easy to do this.

3. The battery will crap out in under 6 months. Fortunately also, since they don't bother to seal the body with anything you can pop the thing open with a wine key and fix this yourself. No! Wait! You'll HAVE to fix it yourself, since you'll get no help from them. They'll refuse to just sell you a battery and will charge as much as a new one to fix it for you.

4. The hardware inside this tab is nearly identical to the hardware in a Barnes and Noble Nook Color, which is $100 less. Samsung does not tell you this, deliberately misleading you into thinking it will be the same as the version they actually care about.

In short, unless you're into rooting and tinkering, this toy will only be fun as long as it still has new toy smell. As soon as real ownership kicks in, you'll just get thrown under the bus.

I do not use any of the Samsung apps like Music Hub, etc.  It would be nice to be able to uninstall them to free up the space, but that is a minor quibble.

Another minor quibble is the proprietary dock connector.  I would prefer a standard micro USB port like my Galaxy Note phone.  Oh, well, at least there are relatively inexpensive adapters to allow the use of USB devices.

One caveat, the Tab 2 7.0 does NOT have HDMI video out capability (or any other video out that I can tell).  Period.  There is an HDMI adapter for some of the other Galaxy Tabs, but it does not work with the Tab 2 7.0.  I do not really care about this, but if you do, just be aware.  If anyone learns differently and verifies it with personal experience, PLEASE let me know.

ORIGINAL REVIEW
OK, I have put off posting a review because I thought all of the 5-Star reviews had already raved about the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7 sufficiently.  But I have been seeing too many low ratings that I consider unjustified so here it is.  This is such a great tablet I will simply try to counter some of the major cons that keep coming up.  As background, I have owned or extensively used an iPad, 4 Android tablets, and 4 Android phones.  I do not at all claim to be an expert with Android; I am still a bit puzzled by many things.  But I have used enough Android devices, from 1.6 to 4.0 to have a bit of familiarity with the OS and devices that run it.

As I mentioned, I do own an iPad, though my wife has stolen it from me.  I bought the iPad strictly to make sure she would be able to use it easily anyway.  But its loss meant I HAD to get the Android tablet I wanted to begin with, right?  Thank goodness because I am NOT an Apple fan.  Even I, an admitted Apple NON-fan has to admit that Apple devices work and work well.  Even to me, the iPad is the gold standard for tablets.

Battery life - this tablet has GREAT battery life, but you do have to practice reasonable power practices.  I charged mine overnight one night, unplugged it in the morning, used it, admittedly very lightly, and after 4 days battery still showed 75%.  I purposely used the tablet very lightly during this time since I was concerned with standby time.  Read Michael S' comment regarding power saving steps here:  http://www.amazon.com/review/R3EL7PM4TA0S2R/ref=cm_cr_pr_viewpnt#R3EL7PM4TA0S2R

Wifi - Many have reported wifi issues.  I don't think this tablet has a wifi problem.  In fact, it has the best wifi performance of any Android tablet I have tried, consistently showing at least one "bar" more than any other.  If you have wifi issues try powering your router off and on or unplug then re-plug.  I have ATT Uverse, and I have to do this EVERY time I try to connect a new device.  Every new device gets "Obtaining IP address from..." or  "Connected"/"Disconnected".  Even when I had cable and was able to use my own router I had to do this occasionally.  The Galaxy Tab 2 7 has wifi performance equal to or better than any of the numerous devices I have used.

Move apps to SD - No, as far as I have been able to determine you may not be able to move apps to sd even with App2SD or other such app.  But the device seems to have a TON of system space for apps - far more than normal users require.  Older versions of Android set aside System Storage for apps that might be 256, 512, or, if you were lucky, 1024MB.  On the Galaxy Tab 2 apps seem to be installed in general storage.  Apps space appears in the Total Space.  Right now, for instance, my Total Space area says apps are taking 533MB and shows 3.86GB available.  So how much apps space do you need? If you are super-gamer and need a bazillion GB of apps space, then no, this device might not be for you.  So go spend $400-500 on something else.  If you are a mere mortal, like me, I am pretty sure you will be EXTREMELY happy with this device.

Oh, yeah, the Tab 2 has only 8GB of internal storage.  I have never cared about internal storage because I immediately stick a 32GB micro SD card in and make sure photos, music, and videos get stored there.  This tablet will accept a USB OTG adapter so you can store unlimited extra videos on flash drives.  Speaking of OTG adapters, you can get less expensive ones, but this one is really neat:
http://www.amazon.com/GrayBean-T-Flash-Keyboard-Connection-SamSung/dp/B0072FJEA8/ref=sr_1_cc_3?s=aps&ie=UTF8&qid=1336783341&sr=1-3-catcorr
I bought one, and I can attest that it does work with flash drives.  I just got it and I imagine it will do fine with a USB keyboard.  It has THREE USB ports plus slots for SD and other memory cards.  Sorry, haven't tried those yet, either.  It also has a power input jack for supplemental power, but I don't seem to have a plug that fits.  I will do more testing and post a review for that product soon.  I also have this one
http://www.amazon.com/Black-Female-Adapter-Samsung-Galaxy/dp/B005YWIRBS/ref=sr_1_cc_2?s=aps&ie=UTF8&qid=1336783341&sr=1-2-catcorr
and I can attest that it works, too.

I can still put the Tab in my pocket.  It is a little pricey right now from reputable sources, but if you decide to go with one of the less expensive places make sure they actually have it. I had been wanting a tablet for a while, but I couldn't justify paying $500+ for something I didn't absolutely need.  I had considered other, less expensive options, but not been happy enough to actually purchase anything.  The Barnes & Noble Nook Color was an option, but I would have wanted to root it, and I didn't want the hassle.  I wanted to use my tablet, not work on it.  The Kindle Fire is nice, but it has limited storage (which isn't expandable) and doesn't have access to the Google Play store.

Then Samsung finally got my business.  A 7" tablet with a good processor, expandable memory, and decent battery life, all for the great list price of $250.

The screen on this isn't the highest resolution, but it is clear and represents color well.  I am not crazy about the auto-brightness control; it seems a little too bright in dark light and too dim in bright light.  But lock the screen brightness to 50% and I rarely have to touch it.  Plus, you can set up a screen widget to change the brightness if needed.

The body of the tablet is nice to hold, not too slick, but no rubbery feeling.  The heft makes it feel solid, but it is not too heavy to hold for long periods of time.

The battery life seems to be doing well for what I need.  The only caveat is that, as with all wireless devices, the wifi will drain the battery faster when it is searching for but not connected to a network.  Not a big deal if you are at home and connected, but you may want to turn the wifi off if you are taking a trip.

And the OS is Android 4.0 (Ice Cream Sandwich or ICS) straight out of the box.  There is no need to root this device to improve the software; its already as good as you can get (at least for now).

Is this going to match the experience of an iPad? No.  It isn't really meant to either, since the screen is only 7".  But it isn't locked into the iOS/iTunes ecosystem either, like an iPad.  This also isn't as expensive as an iPad.

If you don't plan to take the tablet away from wifi, don't need expandable storage, and are happy living in the Amazon ecosystem, the Kindle Fire is a good choice and a little less expensive.  If you are willing to spend $500+, there are tablets that can do more, run faster, or have more features.  However, if you want a tablet that can hold your music or movies while you travel, want the full Android ICS experience, and aren't made of money, this table it for you!

To sum it up, this tablet is the best value of quality, features, and value currently on the market.  I fully recommend this tablet.

Marketing seems to be legalized lying for the most part so I approach every purchase as a 6 month learning lesson ignoring all the marketing hypes and reading 'real' reviews from Amazon and other forums before trying a product out.

Amazon's Marketing for Kindle Fire was upfront stating the 8GB model has 6GB usable.

To be fair to Samsung, I liked the look and feel, and the price allured me...but in the end you have to be able to use the features it boasts and trust the company behind it to be honest with you in order to appreciate a product.  Samsung, please list the info the end user needs to know, otherwise it's deceptive.

I have been using a Kindle Fire since it came out, but was wanting a more full featured 7" tablet. I also have a iPad but due to its size I find that I rarely take it with me, the 7" form factor is far more portable. So, I began exploring the idea of the B&N Nook and then rooting it to use the latest version of Android on it, ICS. Then I read about this tablet. For only $250 it is shocking how much you get. GPS (yes, even without the cellular radio), front and back cameras (not the best quality but good enough for video chat). Dual Core 1ghz processor and 8GB of internal memory plus a microSD card slot.

This beats any other tablet in the price range. If you are looking for a full featured 7" tablet this is the one to get. You can access the Google Play store, the Amazon App Store and use it to read all of your Kindle books or B&N books, so you don't need to be locked into one vendor for your eBooks or Apps.

Ok, the title of my review might be a little extreme but I stick by it.  Anyone considering a Nook or Kindle should give this tablet a long, hard look.  For an entry level, low cost tablet it has a lot of features the purpose built readers leave out.  Not the least of which is this tablet is not tied to Barnes & Noble or Amazon.  With this tablet you can get content from anywhere you want.  Also, the Samsung has a GPS, front and rear cameras and a memory card slot.  I believe the Nook has a memory slot too but the Kindle does not.  The Samsung also has an IR blaster for controlling your home theater.

My only other Android device is my nearly 2 year old Motorola Droid X phone and this tablet makes my phone feel very inadequate in almost every way.  The tablets screen is bright, crisp and clear and it is very responsive with little to no lag.  I believe that this screen has a higher pixel density than many of the 10" tablets as it is nearly the same resolution as the larger tablets in a smaller screen.  I was holding out for a high res 10" tablet but decided to jump on this one because I was tired of waiting.  I am not disappointed.  It will be interesting to see if I end up preferring the 7" tablet after I use it a while.  It is very light, small and portable and the screen real estate is really quite usable.

Universal Remote:
I just got my tablet last night and setup my home theater easily.  I am disappointed with the interface of the supplied remote app though and will look around for a better version.  But at least the tablet provides the ability to do it.  To be fair though, I did not spend a lot of time with it so it may be better than I think.

Kindle Reader:
The Kindle reader app is very nice as the text is sharp and it turns pages very quickly.  I think anyone coming from an e-ink based reader will enjoy using this tablet as a reader as well.  My wife has the e-ink Kindle and has often wanted a back lit reader instead of using a book light.  This screen will not be as readable outdoors though but I think most of my and my wife's reading is indoors so there is always a trade off.

Streaming Music:
I have not tried other media yet other than Pandora radio.  You do get a little hiccup in the audio if you are surfing data intensive apps like Google Maps while you are streaming music.  This may be the result of my pitiful DSL connection at home though.  Will have to try it on a faster broadband connection sometime to see.

Maps:
Google Maps looks great on this device.  Fortunately this tablet has a GPS chip so location based services/mapping are possible.  It is a great size for mapping and once I get a 4G phone with WiFi ability, I will try it out as a navigation device.  Hopefully Samsung will come out with a car dock for this tablet.  Google Streetview is very nice on this tablet as well.

Gmail:
The Gmail app is extremely nice on this tablet.  Even in portrait mode you get the folder list down the left side and your email in the currently selected folder displayed on the right.  On my phone, you only get one folder at a time.

Google Reader:
I use Google Reader as my RSS app and it is very fast on the tablet compared to my phone.  I go cross-eyed staring at my phone for very long but I can tell from my limited use of the reader on the tablet that the tablet will be great.  The reader is really one of my most used apps and a big reason I wanted a tablet.

Facebook:
What can I say, Facebook is much nicer on a tablet than on the phone.

Real Estate Apps:
I am currently in the market to buy a house so I have the Realtor.com and Zillow apps.  Both are much nicer on the tablet than on the phone.  The photos on the Realtor app are much larger than what Zillow provides though which is odd.  Photos on the phone are ok, but are hard to tell much about.  With the tablet, the photos are much more usable.

I may come back and add more to this review as I use the tablet more but in my 1 evening with it so far I can tell that I am going to love this tablet.

**Update 5/9/2012**
I got a chance to play with the tablet some more and have a few more observations to add.

YouTube:
YouTube looks great on this tablet.  It will seamlessly flip from portrait to landscape without stopping the video.  I personally think the YouTube app has a much better UI than the internet webpage.

Speakers:
The speakers are on the bottom of the tablet when the tablet is in portrait position.  You have to watch that you don't rest it on your lap when listening to something using the speakers.  If you turn it to landscape position, you have to watch that you don't cover the lower speaker with your hand.  I found that if you hold the tablet with your fingers and cup the corner with the speaker it actually helps project the sound to you.  I don't know where else they could put speakers as almost anywhere they are you will have to watch you don't cover them when you hold them so I won't complain about it.

Games:
What can I say, Angry Birds is awesome on a tablet.  Words With Friends is nice as well.  I haven't tried other games yet but expect them to look much better than they do on a phone.

7" vs. 10" tablet:
I don't know what to think about the size yet.  I was trying to hold out for a high res 10" tablet that Samsung is rumored to be working on but got tired of waiting.  I am really enjoying the light, small form factor of this 7" tablet though.  So now I am not sure if I will want a 10" tablet or not.  My brother has an iPad and that thing is a brick compared to this tablet.

WiFi:
I am a little worried about the people complaining about WiFi issues.  So far mine has been working fine.  It is indicating the same signal strength that my phone and laptop show.  Maybe the problem is hit and miss but I hope if there is a real problem it is something a software/firmware update can resolve.  But so far I have no complaints.

Battery Life:
I charged the tablet overnight and took it off the charger in the morning.  I didn't use the tablet until I got home about 11 hours later.  It was at 98% charge so it only drained 2% in 11 hours of no use.  I used it for nearly 3 hours and it dropped to 66%.  So 3 hours was about 1/3 of the battery life.  That should translate to about 9 hours of battery life.  I could turn the GPS off since it isn't needed most of the time, I also saw a tip about having it turn the WiFi off when in sleep mode and I have manually set the screen brightness to around 25% which is plenty bright indoors.  Overall, I think it is going to have pretty decent battery life.  I should get about 3 good evenings or a full day on a charge.

**Update 5/21/2012**
I have lived with the tablet for a couple weeks now and have a few more observations.

Screen Sharpness:
I got to compare it with my brother's iPad 2 this weekend and the screen on the Samsung is much, much sharper than the iPad.  In fact, my dad's Nook was much sharper than the iPad with the Samsung being sharper than the Nook.  The difference was amazing.

Browser Speed:
I was completely happy with the browsing speed of the Samsung until I compared it to the iPad.  The iPad was much, much faster.  Not sure why, but it is very noticeable.  I installed the beta version of Google Chrome and it appears to be better than the built in browser but still not as fast as the iPad.  But like I said, I was happy until I found out there was better.

Connection Issues:
I have observed the connection problem some people are reporting.  If you hold the bottom left corner, the reception does drop down.  As soon as you left off, it goes up 1 bar.  But I also found out that my router was not operating at full strength.  I had the old standby Linksys WRT54G but recently upgraded to an ASUS RT16N.  As soon as I did, I noticed my cell phone and laptop were not showing nearly as strong reception as before.  I am running Tomato on the router and discovered that you can turn up the signal strength.  By default, Tomato is dialed back.  My nearest neighbor is a quarter mile away so I dialed up to full strength.  That upped my reception by 1 bar when covered and uncovered.  So now I have better signal strength, even when I cover the antenna. I am not worried as I don't lose connection and it is showing a similar signal strength as my phone and laptop.

Overall, I love this tablet.

Over all the tablet is ok, i did not expect the top of the line for 250 and did not get it. What i would like to have known before i bought it is that it's NOT POSSIBLE to store apps on the external sd card (data files are ok). I'm writing this review on the Galaxy Tab 2. Cons: 1. Samsung messed it up with "their" bluetooth stack! This device will not pair or stay paired with some bluetooth devices out there. It pairs fine with my media device to stream music, but it has issues with my OBD2 bluetooth adapter for my car. I bought this device mainly to dock it in my car to use with the Torque app (great app btw) via bluetooth to my car's OBD-II using BAFX Brand - ELM327 BLUETOOTH - OBDII OBD2 DIAGNOSTIC SCANNER - CAN ELM 327 SCANTOOL - CHECK ENGINE LIGHT CAR CODE READER. I can pair using my phone or other non-Samsung device. When using this Tab it would not stay paired and would keep prompting me for the passcode. I enter the code and it pops up again (yes I am using the correct code)! I have to unpair, reboot, then pair again to get it to work. Imagine having to do this every time you get in your car! They should have left the bluetooth stack alone. I have heard that this is the case with most of their products. A workaround would be to root it and flash a custom ROM with a proper bluetooth stack but it's not our responsibility to fix Samsung's half-baked bluetooth stack! I have read that Samsung is aware of this issue and will release an update *some day*. 2. Touchscreen does not respond well to LONG tap-and-holds. When tap-and-holding for long periods, it would become unresponsive and require you to retap-and-hold. Sometimes it doesn't respond on the first retap and you have to keep trying. It happens a lot when playing racing games where you want to tap-and-hold to accelerate. Out of nowhere it would lose track of my finger. Very annoying and my replacement unit has the same problem. 3. Wi-Fi reception is weak! Don't expect to be able to connect to your router if it's on the other side of the house. Where I can get 1-2 bars of signal on may laptop, this Tab says the network is out of range. 4. There is no way to remove the mini-apps (that arrow pointing up in the bottom-middle). The mini-apps are not that useful and it just takes up space. This should be optional. 5. The camera is very poor, then again you can't expect much from one with less than 8MP these days. 6. Charging is slow and requires Samsungs cable. Also, the supplied cable is too short. A standard USB plug would be ideal. Pros: -Good size where it's comfortable to type in portrait and landscape mode, and still fits in my pocket. -Not too heavy so I can hold it all day. -Somewhat quick and responsive CPU/GPU. -Decent screen (visible in direct sunlight). -Battery life decent with heavy use, power save mode on, and max brightness (a few more hours to get through the day would be nice). Not everybody will be using the Tab like me (pair with OBD2 bluetooth device or play racing games) so these issues may not be a problem. The Tab is still a great device and very robust. I would recommend it.

Original review:
For this review I thought I would provide some details about this tablet from a comparison point of view to the Asus Transformer Tf101. I won't focus on the obvious hardware differences (screen size, port differences, etc.) But instead will talk about some of the lesser known differences.

Pros
-mini app bar - this is a nice feature (but also a source of annoyance) and can provide quick popup access to some features (calendar, alarms, email (not gmail), calculator, music player, task manager, world clock). Asus provides nothing like this.
-a dedicated screen capture button on the Galaxy while Asus requires holding the Recent Apps Key.
-the Galaxy keyboard is way better than the Asus provided keyboard. It uses a much smaller percentage of space but yet is still easy to use. I am used to using Thumbs Keyboard app on the Asus and even that app occupies more screen space than the Samsung keyboard.
-Samsung provides a better application list UI than Asus does. With Asus you can just view the apps and jump to the store. With Samsung you can also customize the order, hide apps and create folders of apps on your home screens.
-Samsung doesn't require an insane amount of power to charge the unit. My Motorola droid USB charge adapter (which I have several for use with ipods ) is powerful enough to charge this. Asus on the other hand requires an insane amount of power.

Cons
-mini apps bar reduces visibility to notification icons when in portrait orientation. I can only see the battery, wifi, time, and weatherbug temp. No ability to see email notifications. When held in landscape, the other notifications become visible. It is odd because there is still about 3/4" of space between the mini app ^ and the last icon.
-mini app bar is not able to be disabled. This means if you value the notification area more than what this feature provides or get annoyed by hitting it instead of the spacebar there is no ability to shut it off.
-Asus provides the ability to disconnect wifi when screen is off setting to help preserve battery life although no similar offering exists with Samsung
-Asus provides the ability to disable the screen capture feature
-Asus provides several custom Widgets while the Samsung does seem to have anything special.

General notes I am disappointed that when adding a memory card it does not allow it be used like on a phone where you can install apps on it to recover some internal memory. This seems to be a flaw with Android's ICS OS and is not specific to this device, as the same is true for my Asus. I just didn't buy a memory card for my Asus since it has 32gb.  I am not certain if I would have got this had I known about this before. In any event I suspect that I'll be able to manage as I can have the camera use the sdcard and I can also store music on it.  And these should be the main consumers of space.

The home screens have grid dimensions of 6 cells wide by 5 high. On Asus it is 8 wide by 7 high (this makes sense given the resolution difference)

So far I have run into one app that I wanted on this that play store said isn't supported (peapod) but I was able to transfer it to this from my Asus and install it, and it seems to work just fine. I like knowing that this is an option that I can try if more apps have a similar issue.

Now if I can only find a better way to prevent purchasing content through one click through the Amazon Appstore I might be inclined to get this for the kids. The price point and features are certainly where I wanted it to be and I am happy with this purchase. My only wish was that it had a 1280x800 resolution but it seems less of an issue now that I have it.

UPDATE 12/2012 - Comparison to Google Nexus 7
So my kids wanted a tablet and they ended selecting the Google Nexus 7 (16gb) instead of this one (and at the time it was purchased the same price.  Now you get a 32gb Nexus for the same price).  Now that I have been able to use both I have a few comparisons to point out about the Nexus to this tablet.

The main issues I see with this device compared to the Nexus is the 8gb of built in memory.  Although true Galaxy allows a memory card for music/photos/movies and the Nexus doesn't, my wife often complains that she runs out of room for apps.  There are a few apps that are quite large that just limit what she can put on this.  The kids have 8gb of space still available so I don't foresee them complaining of space issues anytime soon.

Another issue I see in day to day use of the Samsung is with the size of the back, home, app manager on-screen buttons.  They seem to be a bit too close to each other and also seen to be harder to reach if a case is installed (they both have the same brand/style case) .  The design change that was done for the Nexus OS which puts the buttons in the middle with more space between them actually works very good for this size tablet.  I first didn't like the Nexus change but now I find that it was a good change.

As for speed comparisons I do feel that the Nexus is faster than the Samsung.  The Nexus is significantly smoother than the Samsung.  Its even smoother than my Asus.  As for network speeds, the devices are the same.  I saw 19k kbps/3.8k kbps on both units.  This is slower than my Asus which received 22k kbps/3.8k kbps.

So far, this tablet, an early entry for Samsung in relatively discounted tablets, has more or less met my expectations and I really like it (if Amazon would allow half star ratings I would have done 4.5).

One thing new buyers should be aware of is that as the operating system version, Ice Cream Sandwich, is still fairly new in deployment, there are still some shortcomings albeit on the whole minor.  The only prominent shortcoming I've seen so far, and it's significant but short-term, is that nearly all of the applications are not yet capable of taking advantage of the external SD card, and the very popular apps that allow one to move data and applications to an external SD card don't seem, from my experience, to function yet with this new version of the OS or at least on this hardware implementation.  It's clear this will change in fairly rapid order, but given it's only a 4 GB internal card it's quite easy to fill up the storage on your first day if you are a content-heavy person (I was loading the hundreds of songs I would typically put on, not realizing it wasn't going to the external card at first, even though one of the "move 2 SD" apps said the app in question had its data on the external card).

But the performance is great on this device, and I've already loaded dozens of apps and am able to run everything quite smoothly.

The only other notable disappointment is Samsung does a poor job of giving a user a good start on the device, at least in my opinion.  Instructions on how to start using it are quire spare.  If I were not an experienced Android user I think I'd be at least somewhat upset; even as an experienced Android user I experienced a few frustrating moments but nothing insurmountable or lengthy.  Some of this isn't Samsung's fault (though they really could have provided a far better guide), rather there's also the issue of the ongoing changes in Android's environment.  For example, when I went to use the Android App Market, I suddenly got the Google Play app asking for permission, and I had somehow totally missed the news about Play replacing the Android App Market.  This led to some issues as I tried to stop this "strange app" which was appearing with no explanation whatsoever.

For my uses, this is really an excellent product (or at least it will excel as soon as more data and apps work on the external SD, which clearly will happen), and I'm glad it came out so I didn't have to spend more on the prior "Plus" 7" tablet.  I think the design tradeoffs (the lesser camera, and some other things I read about that I don't recall) are quite fine and I look forward to using this device for some time to come.

Oh, one other frustration I should mention, the plastic door/gate/whatever it is that is supposed to hold the external SD card in is really wonky and at least feels like it's going to break off with any real use.  Just trying to open it I felt like I was breaking part of it, but I think that's because it hangs by a plastic thread, so to speak.  Not sure.  But I want to note that once I seated it back properly it has fit fine and so I cannot tell if my concern is mere perception or if over time, especially if the card is taken in and out on occasion (though not sure that will happen), it will detach.

Otherwise the hardware is really quite nice.

Great cheap device with some glaring problems.

I have a Galaxy Nexus, iPad 2 & 3, iPhone for comparison. I've had the Tab 2 since the 25th (1 day after launch).

Pros: Price, portability and form factor. Excellent video/music player.
I got a OTG cable and plugged in 3 USB sticks and that was fun but impractical.

Cons:
Only works if you are tied to Google's eco-system.
For example, mail & calendaring. Calendar does not support open-source caldav. No support for .ics calendars.
Mail does not support PUSH IMAP email unless you use Gmail. Even then, it has problem with certain Cyrus/Postfix mail servers using TLS authentication.
Sure there are apps on the PLay store but I found all of them to be flakey at best. VPN , like most Android devices, is flakey and unreliable.

Bottom line. Don't even think about using this device for work. This is a toy so I wasn't so hung up on the lack of business features.

However, there are some other bigger issues. I bought this tablet on the premise of expandibility. My 64GB iPad cost $829. I have about 6 32GB microSDHC class 10 cards.
So I figure I can have an inexpensive video player that I can swap cards with and use as a GPS/entertainment system in the car.

First of all. It has very poor file accessibility support. ICS drop USB Mass Storage so you have to use MTP which has problems.
On Macs, you have a 4GB limitation with the Google MTP application. Not only that, it only works 2 out of 10 times. The Galaxy Nexus doesn't have this problem.
There is virtually no or very flakey MTP support in Linux - CentOS/RedHat. Considering Androoid is based off linux, there should be better cohesion.
I guess you can install the SDK kit and do adb pull and push in the command line to get your files onto this tablet but I don't think most readers here are commandline Linux gurus.
Heck, even the iPad has drag-n-drop apps/files support in Linux. The micro-sd slot isn't going to help as I explain further..

So getting large files to the device is going to be a problem.

The Tab 2 is billed as 8GB but 1/2 of it is partition for the OS and the user is only left with 4 GB of free space.

The microsd card isn't very useful for these reasons:
You can only format FAT32. exFAT, NTFS, HFS does not work. I even tried formatting my cards EXT2, EXT3, EXT4 (Linux filesystem).
Why is this an issue? Well, most HD movies are 5-6 gigabytes and FAT32 has a 4GB limit.  So forget about copying your blu-ray rips.
OK. strike. I guess playing my movie collection isn't going to work.

Next, with only 4GB of user-accessible storage on the internal, apps will fill it up quick.
I installed Navigon ( I wanted to use my tab as a GPS for the car), Google earth and a few apps and my Tab 2 was FULL.
After a day's worth of emails, I had 48 megabytes free.

ICS does not support apps2SD where you can move apps to the external SD card.
And for apps that store their cache and support programs, the microSD slot is viewed as /extSD and not /mnt/sdcard

I have hundreds of apps on my Galaxy Nexus as the OS sees 29GB and the apps can install and see the virtual internal sdcard. With the Galaxy Tab 2, there is no luck due to how ICS handles internal storage and external micro-sd.
You can root your device but it is a known issue that apps2sd does not work for ICS. You cant "move" your apps to the external mounted microsd.

Other issues: poor wifi. I have 4 phones and 2 tablets of various makes and the Galaxy Tab 2 has the poorest range. It also drops Wifi N connections.
It doesnt support EAS-TL certificate wifi.
Bluetooth issues galore. I have an Incredible, ATT Captivate, Galaxy Nexus and all of them can pair to a ELM32 ODBC module to use with Torque.
The Galaxy Tab loses pair bluetooth keys. Older HDMI cables for the Galaxy Plus and 10" Tab does not work. I cannot get it to play video thru HDMI.

Sure, the iPad has a close ecosystem but it simply works better. I can copy 6GB HD movies to my iPad. I can connect to various Linux servers's email and  calendaring system.
Heck, I can even mount and copy files from a Linux machine to my iPad. E.G. copy movies over.
I am hoping a 7" model comes out soon because I like the form factor.

So I guess I will be returning this tablet and expect something to address the issues with ICS and storage.a

I have an aging iPad 1, and have been looking for suitable alternatives. First I tried the Kindle Fire. It's a nice device, but the restrictions from Amazon make the iPad look positively open source. I have an android phone, have had a rooted Nook Color, and a Wooted Xoom - so I think I've tested enough varied waters to avoid the inevitable fanboy accusation.

I do have pros and cons for the device, but first I have to say that part of the difficulties I've had have to do with expectations. While I didn't expect a 7 inch device to do what a 10 inch device can (I do a fair amount of remote computing) I don't think that I had a good idea what to realistically do with the smaller form factor.  At the end of the day, I think that the 7 inch tablet is best as a fancy e-reader, and to that extent, the Fire might be the better tab, more for what it doesn't do than what either of these devices can do with a lot of persistence. Perhaps it's best to have a restricted set of well performed functions in a limited space. I'm sure that depends on the user - I don't have to travel much, so portability isn't as big a deal as usability.

Pros:
Very thin and attractive
Good price
Nice screen with accurate colors
Camera -I didn't use it, but it's there
Minimal bloat
MicroSD slot (though it is a bear to insert a card in there)
Video player was excellent, seemed to play everything, including mkvs.

Cons::
MTP instead of Mass storage was an absolute fail. It doesn't mount on  XP or OSX, and really was a pain even on Win7 (it worked after I installed Kies). What I ended up doing was using File Expert on the Samsung and FTPing from whatever. Just silly.
Wireless drops occasionally, usually on waking.
Music - the native player doesn't read m4a's. You have to use something like PowerAmp, which is a great product. This isn't my idea of "open" especially when the video player can handle so many codecs. And while we're on this, Google music doesn't accept m4a's either. I don't understand this. Even Amazon will let me upload various music formats to their cloud player. I realize this isn't Samsung's fault. But still...
ICS - still a mish mash mess of GUI. Even on a 7 inch screen, you are tapping in all different directions to achieve a goal. The basic soft-key elements are fine and usually helpful, but I don't get the immutable dock, the applications icon in the upper right corner, and the horrible screen capture icon (I think this was added by Samsung). And lastly, though I am clearly the only person bothered by this, is the blue line that permeates all screen elements (it's there to separate the dock from the main screen). As an e-reader it was fine. Nice to have Kindle, Nook, Kobo, on the same device in one small form factor. Due to it's thin-ness, it is hard to hold for a long time, but I think a good  case would help.

I think that if I was going to take on this size device again, it would be more along the lines of the Fire  - a limited device that performs a few tasks well, and leave the more complicated tasking to larger devices. My hope is that the retina display type screens start appearing on more devices which should improve the reading experience even more, and that my expectations for a small devices extend to reading, some video and music, and light emailing. It will be interesting to see how the Google Nexus tabs compare in a couple of months.

Good evening, This is my first dive into the tablet market, I have over the years played around the the various kindles, nooks, android, BlackBerry and the Ipads, they for the most part were very impressive except for the price. and I wasn't about to contract a 4g account on one of these. This is my first tab and i love it with the exception that the browser force closes often.  Downloaded Dolphin hd and that does it as well.  Anybody else experience this and know of a fix?

I've been hunting down a 7" tablet since I saw the specs for the ASUS MeMo 370T and was happy to see this Samsung unit beat Google to the punch.

Overall the tablet has a great form factor and is a pleasure to hold for hours on end.  Obviously anyone expecting an iPad experience out of a 7" Android device will be disappointed.  Luckily I've been looking for a tablet to augment my iPad.

I bought this tablet primarily to use around the house for reading RSS feeds, doing light web-surfing and to check e-mail and my task manager (Springpad).

For the most part it does these tasks well though I have noticed some issues with scrolling through lists of news articles and longer web pages.  It's just a little glitchy and not as smooth as the Nook Tablet I tried earlier this year.

My main concern is battery life.  I have never seen a device suck down the juice quick as quickly as this one does. It seems to use 3-5% per hour rendering the idea of multi-day stand-by moot. What I've noticed is the wi-fi indicator says there's traffic almost constantly.

As a test I stared at the launcher (no widgets installed) for a minute and during that time wi-fi was almost constantly in use. I'm sure this has something to do with the poor stand-by performance but for the life of me I can't figure out WHAT would using wi-fi that much in the background.  When I check network statistics I see the ever helpful "System" uses the most bandwidth.

While using the tablet I am perfectly happy with battery performance. I was pleasantly surprised the other night to have only dropped to 63% after 4 hours of pretty continuous use.  The following morning I was down to 44% and by the end of that 9 hour work day the tablet was dead.  This seems very odd to me and is likely the fault of the Android OS moreso than Samsung.

The other issue I've had is that tapping alignment seems a bit off.  About 35% of the time I think I'm tapping on one icon or selection and a different item is selected.  This reminds me of the old Palm days where one could re-calibrate the digitizer if it started getting out of sync.

At present I'm not sure if I'll be keeping this tablet or returning it and waiting for the Google Tablet this summer.  The issues I'm experiencing may be SW related so I'll be keeping this unit for a few weeks to see if Samsung updates to resolve the issues I've seen.

I'd have given the device four stars but the stand-by battery issue really bothers me.  I didn't see it on the Nook Tablet and am at a loss in trying to track down what system process could be eating so much battery.

This Tablet is great for me.  I was going to buy the iPad3 but didn't want to spend the money.  I already own a Mac laptop. Also, I wanted something small  to carry and it was mainly going to be used for reading. I played around with the Nook and Fire but I liked the idea of adding memory and its more than a reader . The screen is clean and crisp without  glare. Easy to hold in one hand and no extra weight added to my bag. No problem with WiFi.  I love and use Swype on this machine.  Great tablet .

I am returning two tab 2's because they would not connect to wireless N.  I cannot even describe how upset I am about returning these.  It's small, pretty and powerful but since it is wifi only it must then be able to connect to all wifi connections.  I have a Galaxy S 2 phone and love it but after this tab 2 upset I may never consider Samsung anything ever again.  Come on SAMSUNG!!

I'm very happy with this tablet. I had every intention of buying an iPad 2 but played with this tablet in the store and thought I would give it a try. I'm very impressed and saved $100 to $150 bucks. The user interface Samsung laid on top of Android 4.0 is excellent. The screen is responsive. Syncing with Gmail and Google Calendar is perfect. To my eyes the screen looks better than its specs. The Wi-Fi signal seems consistent and strong. Definitely worth a try.

I am a newbie to tablets so I can't compare to many different  tablets except the Kindle, which I owned for about 3 days. Got the Kindle for a great deal, $139, special 1-day deal, refurbished direct from Amazon, 1-year warranty. Couldn't pass up this deal.  Played with it for about 3-days. Everything about the Kindle was OK. Nothing great, did everything as advertised.

Then I saw the SGT 2 7 advertised. There were 4 things that appealed to me as upgrades from the Kindle. Extra storage capability (huge), camera, availabilty to full android market and ICS (the newest android operating system). I decided if I was going to have a tablet, I wanted something I would be happy with for several years not just the next 6 months. So I pre-ordered the SGT 2 7 from Amazon.  Was told I would recieve on the 25th but was actually delivered on the 24th, nice suprise.  Have played with it for 3 days now, very impressed. Gave the Kindle to my wife. She loves it.  Now my wife and daughter can swap Kindle experiences, whoo hoo.

Review:
Overall, love the tablet.  Everybody has different reasons to get a tablet. This is simply a play toy for me. Do not need for business. Not looking for or needing the best tablet on the market.

* Look and feel are great, lighter than the Kindle. Not difficult at all to hold and read book for an hour or so.
* Screen is good!  Everything looks clear and sharp. Not the best on the market but definitly OK for the price.  Watched Neflix movie last night, picture and sound were great!
* Touchscreen very responsive, minimal delay in opening apps.
* Wi-Fi is good. Goes down from 4 bars to 2 bars when I go upstairs. Does not seem to effect reliability much.
* Sound is great.  Cranked the volume all the way up and had minimal distortion. Better that expected for this tablet.
* Love the ability to set my screens up the way I want (unlike Kindle)
* Many more apps available through Google Play then Amazon's App Store. Big plus.
* Camera sucks.  But I generally take pictures with a real camera (remember those). Good enough to take some pictures when you forgot you camera or your cell phone isn't working. No big deal to me.
* I have heard people complain about the proprietary cable. Really, get a get a life. Cable is used to charge and connect to my laptop to xfer video/music files to tablet. Works perfect.
* Only real issue is the remote control app.  Started Peel setup, recognized my Vizio OK, could not recognize DTV box though. After 2 trys, app loaded up email to send trouble tik to Peel, pre-loaded all info, I just needed to enter DTV model no.  Received email within an hour from Peel advising they had received my email and would look into it.  72 hours later no response. Not a Samsung issue but dissapointed Peel doesn't support there product better.

Overall, very pleased with the tablet and confident I will get many years of enjoyment. If your in the market for a good tablet to play games, watch movies, listen to some music or surf the net, you will not be disappointed with the SGT 2 7.

This is the first tablet I've owned, and overall i really like it. I already have a Galaxy S2, so I'm a fan of Samsung and the Galaxy series. The tab has a quick response, smooth transitions from screen to screen. Apps all load pretty quickly, and downloads are fast also. The camera is pretty low quality, but i can use my 8mp camera on my phone so i don't mind. I have yet to video chat on this, so i can't comment on the front-facing camera yet.

The battery seems long to me, but i only use this tablet at home when i have wi-fi, and my phone all day at work, so its not being used by me for 8hrs straight. I've used it for probably 3 or 4 straight in a day.

Since its running ICS, and I've never used a tablet, i had to adjust to the layout, with the commands being in the bottom left, along with the task manager/dropdown menu bar etc. The dedicated screenshot button is completely unnecessary and in the way, but once i was used to it being there it was avoidable.

I was very impressed by the inbrowser video playback. Youtube videos and flash were great and smooth. i watched an entire HBO show last night with no problems. Netflix runs smoothly, and so does HuluPlus (thought the Hulu app is not in the market yet).The IR remote is cool, but is really only needed if your feeling lazy, but when you are lazy its cool, and works well.

The screen isn't the best, but its nice. Again, its hard for me to be impressed by the screen and cameras since i've experienced the AMOLED screen on my GS2. If it weren't for the larger screen size, i'd be tempted to continue watching video on my phone. But once i buy a microSD card to expand the storage, i think i'll get more use out of this tablet.

I have a mac, so in order to transfer files to this tablet, you need to download a program to your computer to sync files, movies, etc. Also, you can only transfer files no larger than 4GB, which was disappointing for me since alot of my movies are HQ blu-rays that are 4.5+GB each. So a microSD card may be a must since large transfer can't be done via USB.

Summary: Basically, if you already have a Samsung Galaxy phone (S2, Note, etc) I wouldn't buy this tablet, just because your phone is probably better. But if you have $250 to spend for fun, it's not bad to have. Its good for watching movies in bed, surfing the internet, playing games. Also remember it's running Ice Cream Sandwich, so that could be incentive to buy for alot of people who want to play with the new OS.

it isn't a bad tablet for the price, and is definitely a great choice for a first time tablet buyer who wants something entry-level.

I own a Kindle Fire, and haven't had it long enough to be a dedicated fanboy. I AM an apple fanboy...now. I've always wanted an iPad and was saving up for a "the new iPad", but I can't spend that much on a tablet right now. So When I saw the Galaxy Tab 2 7" I got really excited. Finally a full fledged tablet at the right size at the right price, with awesome specs. I could return my Kindle Fire and get a machine without compromise...or so I thought.

I used to have an Android Galaxy S phone, but switched to the iPhone because I was tired of all my phone's random glitches and crashes. An example was being told I was in Sweden while I was in Tyler, Texas. My wife made fun of me because I used to gripe non-stop about how much I hated my Android phone, vowed to never get another one, and yet was drooling over the new Samsung Galaxy Tab 2. I called to every local dealer till I found one who would sell it on saturday (the day before official release).

Right out of the box I loved it. The screen was great, the smooth bezel and perfect size, the expandable data capability, and the control bar, which is one of my favorite features on the device, made everything so much easier. I could put icons and widgets wherever I wanted to. I had full access to the google play store. That's where the benefits started to fall off. I bought the Kindle Fire to read, surf the web, manage documents and have something for my 5 year old to play on, it worked great for all those things, but it's very limited by the Amazon Android shell. OH, and the speakers worked way, WAY better on the Galaxy Tab 2 than the Kindle Fire's anemic speakers.

All that being said, the Galaxy Tab 2 wouldn't/couldn't sync up to my Mac, MAJOR issue for me, I absolutely hate windows os. I tried installing the android software meant to assist with data transfer for macs directly from the Android website, to continually get a, "please connect device to initiate file transfer" (paraphrase) message. To transfer files I could only use dropbox, which ultimately is a slow and somewhat painful replacement for direct file transfer. Strike 1.

There were serious formating issues with my ebooks when I finally managed to get them to the Galaxy Tab 2.  I purchased and set up a handful of top rated ereader programs from google play, moon+reader ($4.99), aldiko (free), the Kindle app and a couple others. Paragraphs were separated by several lines of blank spacing, and the paragraphs were cut in odd locations not waiting for the actual end of the paragraph. I used epub and mobi formats to no avail. Calibre was also not able to be called on for assistance since my computer couldn't recognize the Galaxy Tab. Strike 2.

A smaller, yet still frustrating issue, probably fixable with a different browser program, is something I'd come to respect abou the Kindle Fire. On the Kindle Fire, when viewing text on a website, I could zoom in on the text and it would be reformated to fit my page. This made it so I wouldn't have to scroll around, thus easier to read. The Galaxy Pad did not have this feature and I was scrolling constantly when surfing. As I said minor issue, but still. Strike 3.

Then I couldn't get any of the Amazon HD apps to run on the Galaxy Tab 2, more of an Amazon issue really, but I didn't want to be forced to purchase all the same apps over again, expensive and a major hastle. Strike 4.

The reason I got rid of the Samsung phone was because it was glitchy and wouldn't work. I got rid of this for the same reason. I love my iPhone, it simply just works, and works really well. I started having PTSD when the Galaxy Tab started to throw problems at me and decided I would go back to the Kindle Fire, like my iPhone, it just simply, works. The Kindle doesn't do half the things I wanted to get the Galaxy Tab 2 for, but it works really well for the main reasons I wanted it. I'll get over the stuff I'll lose.

I know these aren't necessarily strong reasons not to get it. As I said there are a lot of benefits to using the Galaxy Tab 2, but it does not in any way replace a Kindle Fire if you are an avid reader, or if you're a mac user.

I'd wanted a 7" iPad. I had a first generation iPad and it was just too big and heavy for my intended use. I tried the Kindle Fire, found it lacking out of the box because it doesn't do well with Gmail and Google Calendar. I rooted the Kindle Fire, tried Cyanogenmod 7 and 9, and it still wasn't great for me.

Enter the Galaxy Tab 2 7". It's lovely hardware, significantly lighter than the Fire. With bluetooth, which the Fire lacks, it plays very nicely through my Creative D100 bluetooth speakers. And it is much more satisfactory than the rooted and modded Fire--recent OS, and much fewer bugs than the unofficial Cyanogenmod ports (blessings to all the devs at Cyanogenmod and XDA!)

The Tab operating system, Ice Cream Sandwich, is sleek, smooth and attractive. Although there are far fewer apps than for the iPad, my needs are met well. I really like the voice dictation and command interface that is very well integrated into the apps. Too, I'm using the SlideIt keyboard, available through the app store--much better than the stock keyboard IMO (and one of the reasons that in this instance I prefer Android to IOS since Apple doesn't make this kind of Swype-like input available in such a well-integrated manner).

Other reviewers have commented on the pros and the cons. I'll just add that while there are compromises compared to, say, the iPad 3, the compromises are reasonable and don't affect my enjoyment of the device.

It may be that new tablets such as the vaunted Google tablet will provide more bang per buck. But at the moment, the Galaxy Tab 2 7" provides plenty of bang, with a fluid and enjoyable user experience for this size of tablet. Glad I got it.

UPDATE May 2012: I have lowered the rating down to one star. I purchased this tablet to watch movies and stream video but it simply doesn't work, probably because the processor is vastly underpowered. I suggest getting a more powerful 5" phone instead of this paperweight.

Here is a list of what works and what doesn't on this new Samsung Tablet 2:

1) Bluetooth Audio = Hard to pair to headphones. Often the bluetooth devices don't register, however, once paired, the signal is strong. Skill level required: above average.
2) Bluetooth File Sharing = No two way file transfer with Macintosh. One way only.
3) HBOgo App = Is not yet available for Android.
4) Flash Video Playback = Random results, sometimes it works sometimes if does not.
5) YouTube = Works fine.
6) Samsung USB Adapter = Reads SD card files and can delete files. Very hard to transfer files. Skill level required: high.
7) 1080p High Definition video playback = often no audio, skips frames or crashes on all Android video players that I tested. The processor can't handle HD Video and sometimes not even SD video.
8) Audio Volume = Excellent. The best of all tablets on the Market.
9) TwitTV Apps = No Video. Some video podcasts exhibit audio synch problems.
7) Peel Smart Remote = Good luck getting this one to work, I am an expert and it took me 15 tries to figure it out. Also it requires a permanent Wi-Fi connection, no Wi-Fi, no workie. When it does work it does a nice job except for the slow volume control.
8) Nice battery life if you turn off the GPS and adjust Wi-Fi setting to "off" while at sleep. GPS is "on" be default.
9) Screen is not sharp but most people won't notice the difference or care if they do. Acceptable for movies of medium resolution which is all it can play anyway.
10) Wi-Fi seems to work fine, have not tested for distance.
11) Camera quality is very mediocre, who cares, right. Video is noisy.

Software review: the new Android Ice Cream Sandwich software that runs at the core of the Galaxy Tab is still marred by Google's inept programmers, you know what I mean, the pseudo-interface that get worse with every new version? Add to that the buggy software available in the Android Market and you get an overall unfriendly experience, still a potpourri of random hangs and crashes. Doesn't look like Google cares nor is capable of creating a friendly interface, too bad because it is Ice Cream Sandwich which really ruins the Samsung Tablet experience.

Conclusion: The "Galaxy Tab 2" sacrificed some key components in order to sale this tablet for $250 and it shows, the processor is underpowered, to make matters worse, Ice Cream Sandwich is still confusing and cumbersome for the average consumer. As much as I like to recommend this form factor my final recommendation is to hold off a few more months, Apple will soon release the next generation of 7" tablets for about the same price and so is Microsoft, yes, Windows tablets are supposed to be solid contenders.

More free advice: Amazon reviews of 5 stars are almost always fake and can be safely ignored, I suggest reading the 3-2-1 star reviews for a less biased experience before you buy.

If you are looking for a 7", well-functioning, affordable tablet to surf the web and consume content then this the Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 is one of the best options out there. I own a Kindle Fire and love it. It is all that I need when I'm ready to relax in the evening. However, the Galaxy Tab gets the advantage for being a budget media tablet. Here is why:

1) Hardware: Slightly lighter, slimmer. The Fire is a little easier to grip because of the back, but this is lighter to hold and carry. Front and back cameras. Who cares if they aren't the best because the Fire doesn't have either. Volume rocker makes volume adjustments simple.

2) Software: This is my first Android device and it runs smoothly and I haven't had any problems. There are a plethora of options for customizing this device to your needs.

3) Applications: No longer restricted by Amazon's App Store so you get to experience new apps that everyone is talking about sooner.

4) Media: Still have access to books and videos from Amazon either through Amazon Kindle app or Amazon's website. In addition, you now have access to Google's app, videos, music, games library. A strong ecosystem is important in the long run and like Amazon and Apple this device has that with Google.

I gave this device 5 stars because if you're looking at this tablet then you probably don't want to spend a lot of money and you want a smaller tablet. This is one of the best options out there.

Like some other reviewers, I also own an iPad and an iPod (but no iPhone). I think of the Galaxy Tab 2 as filling a niche between the iOS products, mainly because of its physical size. If Apple decides to make a 7-inch iPad, that would probably serve just as well. But I was eager to try the Tab 2 to give me a feel for how Android performs relative to iOS. In addition, the price was definitely right.

Bottom line: I'm happy. Not deliriously so, but happy. It does take a little time to get used to how to manipulate Android if you've been using iOS for a couple of years, but it's not a major hurdle. As a user of many Google products, I was impressed at how seamlessly Ice Cream Sandwich (ICS) integrates with them; no contortions are required to access them or sync with them. I also appreciate the greater flexibility in setting up screen views, the use of widgets, and the fact that seldom-used apps are kept in the background. Also, Android/ICS lets you keep track of your files in a number of ways, which iOS keeps hidden from the user.

A few minuses. First, the physical switches on the Tab 2 are easy to press by mistake; since the Tab 2 is relatively small, you're almost bound to hit one of them while holding it--I'm clumsy, to boot, which makes it even more likely. Second, the software keyboard has the small delete and enter keys right next to each other; I can't count the number of times I've pressed enter while trying to delete an entry. Third, the camera is nothing to write home about. And finally, there's very little documentation on how to use ICS; if you've been using a previous version of Android, it's probably a no-brainer, but those of us immersed in iOS could use a little help getting started.

As for overall value, no question about it: The Tab 2 is great value for the money. It's only fifty bucks more than a Kindle Fire, and it uses pretty much a generic version of ICS, not a proprietary version, which means that most apps from the Android store can run on it without bother (I've found exceptions, though). It's definitely found a permanent home with me, and is likely to be what I carry around with me day-to-day. The iPad is a heavier-duty big brother, most useful when I'm sitting and doing a lot of reading, or need the larger screen real estate that it offers.

After doing literally days worth of research on tablets within my budget, it came down to the Kindle Fire, B&N Nook, Blackberry Playbook, and this device. All retailing for less than $300, but after reviewing the specs of the aforementioned devices over and over, and watching many Youtube video's, and reading countless posts and discussions on this device I went ahead and pre-ordered it. First off, I tip my hat to Amazon, who got this sexy piece of technology to me a mere day after it's release (keep up the good work guys). Now on to the review.

Right out of the box, I love the way this device feels in my hand. It just cradles my hands perfectly, and has a nice weight to it, and the materials to me, feel like quality stuff. Upon fully charging it, I did the initial setup, and then proceeded to download all of the apps I would need on this device (SBM, Quickpic,Camera ZOOM FX, Aldiko, Rage of Bahamut, A Comic viewer, Evernote, etc.). After testing all of them under various conditions, I am very pleased with the performance the tab offers. There was no noticeable lag or performance issues at all in starting, using, or playing any of my favorite apps. The TouchWiz interface blends nearly seamlessly into ICS, and I for one like the the way Samsung integrated the two interfaces. The capacitive screen is very responsive, and I had zero problems using SBM on this device to keep my many invention ideas drawn and saved for further refinement. Speaking of which, the screen is gorgeous at 1024 x 600, and while not the highest end screen out, is simply stunning for the price range. I tested a variety of HD videos, and all of them ran without a single hiccup in the frame rate, and had all had bright crisp pictures, and awesome sound quality (the speaker was far better than I expected it to be). Watching the HD quality video of One Ok Rock Live at Shinjiku Loft was truly awesome on this screen, and didn't stutter a single bit.

Regarding reading e-books, it housed, ran, and performed far above my expectations, and I found myself reading in a variety of lighting conditions, in all of which it functioned perfectly as an e-reader. Haven't tested the camera's yet, or Poweramp, or some of the more advanced features yet but I'll update this review once I get a chance to play with them a bit more. Oh, and lest I forget, the battery life on this bad girl is beyond sweet. Since my initial charge, and using it moderately to heavily for three days, I haven't hit 60% of the battery use yet.  Also a quick note for those wondering about cases, the device fits in my Navitech case like a glove, with none of the buttons or ports being blocked (besides the rear camera of course). So far, after testing all of the aforementioned tablets, the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 is serious contender with all of them, especially the Kindle Fire. For only an extra $50 you get expandable memory up to 32GB (a huge plus in my book), two cameras, ICS without the need to root anything, full access to Google Play, and more. Unless you're a serious power user this tablet is more than capable of handing most anything you throw at it. While a bit of a downgrade from it's Samsung siblings, for the price you currently won't find a better tablet.

UPDATE 4-26-2012: Been using the Peel remote app with the built in IR blaster for over a day now and to say I'm impressed would be an understatement. I owned a 10.1 in galaxy tab for almost a year and ipad 2 the same period of time. I strayed from the apple (i-Shackle) product because I hate being told what form factors I NEED to buy or use to obtain seamless transfer.

To the 1 star due to seeing it had a proprietary port LOL yes lets give an item 1 star for that. Lots of companies are going this route because it helps in the development of far more future upgrades. The vast array of connectors gives developers more options on what they can come up with. i.e dock stations with keyboard and mouse. Yes a usb also can but since 2.0 has a VERY limited power source and a tiny contact patch it makes for pathetically slow connections when using something with multiple inputs. Say keyboard dock with mouse pad, 2 attached usb devices to the dock etc.

To the other 1 star review who likes gingerbread more, stick with the old form factor. Ice cream sandwich (ICS) aka android 4.0 is brand spanking new. When Gingerbread was first released we had to hustle to make all of our apps compatible. I have had no such problems with mine and I'm sorry you did.

So I did a lot of research; I've been in the market for a tablet for 5 or 6 weeks. I really wanted to wait for the Asus/Google Nexus announcement, but I don't want to hang out that long on the hope that it will be announced and have everything I want. This tablet has almost everything on my list I'll detail out why it got a 4 from me in a minute.

The Good
Pretty responsive over all, and while some folks might take issue with the picture, I've never been particularly concerned that my device have the deepest blacks, and the most staggering whites on the block. You might notice a small amount of lag if you have tons of apps open (as I tend to do) and if you have a samsung/nexus smartphone as I do, you may notice the setup is not quite as set it and forget it as that. I am still looking for a couple of apps/widgets such as my photos from my google accoutn. I've heard other reviewers say that ICS seems a bit cramped on a device this small, and I can't say that I disagree, but for the most part it does what it says on the box and I imagine you'll run into the same situation on nearly any 7 inch tablet with a similar resolution. I wanted this device for Netflix when I'm on the road, Google Reader for cooking in the kitchen, and Evernote for taking notes in meetings. This does that and then some and you can't say that about the kindle fire. To me that's worth $50. I haven't run through an entire battery cycle yet, but so far it seems solid, moreso than my phone in fact due to the lack of cell connectivity drain.

The Bad
As I said, the GB of RAM, and downgraded processor are noticeable vs beefier models only if you have lots of apps open. Other reviewers have talked about the junky camera and I will echo that sentiment, though if you'd just doing instagram or something of that ilk I doubt you'll be disappointed.

My wife took to it like a duck to water while watching TV last night. One other bonus, which I didn't know when I bought it was that it's incredibly easy to switch between accounts.
